scite3: "Chronological History of Arsons and Bombings Against Abortion Providers," National Abortion Federation.

summary: 05/14/1993: Several unidentified gunmen attacked the U.S. Consulate using automatic rifles. Nobody was injured in the attack, and the gunmen escaped. The degree of damage to the building was not reported.
propcomment: Bullets left marks on the entrance door of the Consulate.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.
scite2: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 05/15/1993: Fifteen people were injured when a car bomb, believed to have been planted by the Mafia, exploded in the Roman suburb of Pariolli.
weapdetail: The car was a Fiat 126 packed with explosives.
propcomment: The explosion destroyed windows and cars stretching for a mile.
addnotes: It is possible that the Mafia was trying to assassinate television presenter Maurizo Costanzo, whose show had become an anti-Mafia sounding board.
scite1: Ed Vulliamy, "Mafia Suspected as Car Bomb in Rome Leaves 15 Wounded," The Guardian (London), May 15, 1993.

summary: 05/18/1993: Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) rebels called for and launched a three-day armed strike against the government. In Arequipa, a dynamite blast cut off power to three Southern cities.
motive: Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) launched a general strike in protest against the Peruvian government.
addnotes: This was one of 3 related attacks (199305180002,3)
scite1: "Shining Path Launches Armed Strikes with Power Cuts, Three Killings," Agence France Presse, May 18, 1993.
scite2: Monte Hayes, "Rebel Strikes Call Cripples Public Transport, Shuts Business," The Associated Press, May 17, 1993.

summary: 05/18/1993: Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) rebels called for and launched a three-day armed strike against the government. In Ayacucho, rebels gunned down a woman in an attack where 20 houses were torched.
motive: Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) launched a general strike in protest against the Peruvian government.
propcomment: Houses and livestock
addnotes: This was one of 3 related attacks (199305180001,3)
scite1: "Shining Path Launches Armed Strikes with Power Cuts, Three Killings," Agence France Presse, May 18, 1993.
scite2: Monte Hayes, "Rebel Strikes Call Cripples Public Transport, Shuts Business," The Associated Press, May 17, 1993.

summary: 05/18/1993: Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) rebels called for and launched a three-day armed strike against the government. In Lima, a car bomb exploded at a crowded market, causing extensive damage but no casualties.
motive: Sendero Luminoso (Shining Path) launched a general strike in protest against the Peruvian government.
propcomment: The market district was damaged.
addnotes: This was one of 3 related attacks (199305180001,2)
scite1: "Shining Path Launches Armed Strikes with Power Cuts, Three Killings," Agence France Presse, May 18, 1993.
scite2: Monte Hayes, "Rebel Strikes Call Cripples Public Transport, Shuts Business," The Associated Press, May 17, 1993.

location: Northern Perimeter of security zone in the eastern sector (Southern Lebanon)
summary: 05/19/1993: An IDF officer was killed and two others were wounded by Hizballah fighters in heavy fighting near the northern perimeter of the security zone.
scite1: David Rudge and Yigal Kotzer, "IDF Officer Killed in South Lebanon. Two Other Men Injured, One Seriously," The Jerusalem Post, May 19, 1993.

summary: 05/18/1993: Six armed students set the Sudanese Embassy ablaze, causing extensive damage to the basement and first floor of the Embassy. No casualties were reported.
motive: Reports indicated that the students attacked due to dissatisfaction with government scholarship.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 05/19/1993: The offices of a Paris travel agency were damaged in an explosion similar to an explosion of May 8 in Marseille.
addnotes: The blast was possibly the work of a nationalist organization.
scite1: "Paris Travel Agency Hit By Blast," Xinhua General News Services," May 19, 1993.

summary: 05/19/1993: A Volkswagen, loaded with dynamite and ammonium nitrate fuel oil, exploded in front of the Chilean Embassy, damaging its façade. No injuries were reported. A second vehicle, containing 50 kilograms of urea and petroleum, left in front of the Embassy did not completely explode. The Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) was suspected of the attack.
weapdetail: A Volkswagen loaded with dynamite and ammonium nitrate fuel oil. (Also a second vehicle containing 50 kilograms of urea and petroleum, which did not completely explode.)
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 05/19/1993: Police in Bolivia intercepted two letter bombs, sent by unknown perpetrators, that were addressed to Presidential Candidates Carlos Palenque and Hugo Banzar Suarez. There were no casualties in this attack.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/20/1993: A bomb exploded on the staircase leading to the Ethiopian Airlines office in Lome. It was believed that the Ethiopian Airlines office was the target. There were no casualties in this incident.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/21/1993: A car bomb exploded in Cairo, spraying glass and nail-size shards downtown, killing 4 and injuring 16. There was no immediate claim of responsibility, but it conformed to the tactics of the Islamic Holy War Group.
weapdetail: The bomb sprayed glass and nails.
addnotes: The Islamic Holy War Group wants to install a Islamic government in Egypt.
scite1: "Car Bomb Explodes in Cairo, Kills Three, Wounds 15," The Associated Press, May 21, 1993.

summary: 05/21/1993: The Manuel Rodriguez Patriotic Front (PFMR) detonated a bomb in front of the Chinese Embassy. This incident reportedly caused no injuries and only minor damage to the building.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.
scite2: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 05/21/1993: Fifteen suspected Khmer Rouge guerillas attacked a police post and a United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia (UNTAC)  camp in Skun, Cambodia. Two Chinese engineers were killed and six others were injured.
target1: United Nations Transitional Authority in Cambodia
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: Security zone near Khardeleh Bridge over the Litani River (Southern Lebanon)
summary: 05/22/1993: Two South Lebanon Army (SLA) soldiers were killed and another badly wounded by a roadside explosive device.
weapdetail: Roadside bomb
addnotes: This was one of 2 related attacks. (199305220002)
scite1: David Rudge, "Two SLA men killed by security zone roadside bomb. Two terrorists killed planting explosives," The Jerusalem Post, May 23, 1993.

location: Near Dib'l Village in the Security Zone
summary: 05/22/1993: Two terrorists were killed by the mines they were planting along a route near Dib'l village in the Western Sector of the Security Zone.
weapdetail: Mines
addnotes: This was one of 2 related attacks. (199305220001)
scite1: David Rudge, "Two SLA men killed by security zone roadside bomb. Two terrorists killed planting explosives," The Jerusalem Post, May 23, 1993.

summary: 05/23/1993: Suspected Khmer Rouge rocketed the quarters of Chinese soldiers with a UN peacekeeping mission. Two members of a Chinese engineering battalion were killed, along with four injured.
target1: Soldier's quarters for the UN peacekeeping troop from China
motive: The Khmer Rouge wanted to disrupt UN sponsored elections.
addnotes: This was one of 2 related attacks (199305230002). It is unknown if the train was actually moving.
scite1: William Branigin, "Cambodian Guerrillas Attacks; Sihanouk On Election Eve," The Washington Post, May 22, 1993.

summary: 05/23/1993: Three Cambodian civilians were killed when a train was attacked. The Khmer Rouge was suspected.
motive: The Khmer Rouge wanted to disrupt UN sponsored elections.
propcomment: A train was destroyed.
addnotes: This was one of 2 related attacks (199305230001).
scite1: William Branigin, "Cambodian Guerrillas Attacks; Sihanouk On Election Eve," The Washington Post, May 22, 1993.

summary: 05/24/1993: Police suspected that the IRA was responsible for two car bombs that exploded in Belfast and in nearby Magherafelt. No serious injuries were reported.
addnotes: This was one of 2 related attacks (199305240002).
scite1: "No serious injuries in N. Ireland blasts," Chicago Tribune, May 24, 1993.
scite2: Rick Clark, "Bombs Damage Homes, Shops in Northern Ireland," United Press International, May 23, 1993.

summary: 05/24/1993: Police suspected that the IRA was responsible for two car bombs that exploded in Magherafelt and nearby Belfast. No serious injuries were reported.
addnotes: This was one of 2 related attacks (199305240001).
scite1: "No serious injuries in N. Ireland blasts," Chicago Tribune, May 24, 1993.
scite2: Rick Clark, "Bombs Damage Homes, Shops in Northern Ireland," United Press International, May 23, 1993.

summary: 05/25/1993: Yemeni tribesmen abducted two American engineers working for the Hunt Oil Company, along with their Yemeni driver. The men were released on May 25, 1993, both in good health.
target1: American employees of Hunt Oil Company
target2: Driver for Hunt Oil Company Employees
motive: Members of the tribe had been sentenced to death by the Yemeni government and this kidnapping was intended to pressure the government into commuting those sentences.
addnotes: The tribesmen had lost appeals in court the day before on different charges and it is believed that these kidnappings were meant to pressure the Yemeni government into commuting the sentences.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/25/1993: Unidentified gunmen shot at an armed United Nations convoy in Kratie Province, Cambodia. A Uruguayan soldier returned fire, but no casualties occurred as a result of this incident.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/26/1993: Unidentified gunmen shot at an armed United Nations convoy in Kompong Thom Province. An Indonesian soldier returned fire, but no casualties occurred as a result of this incident.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/27/1993: A car bomb exploded near Florence's Uffizi Gallery, killing five people and destroying or badly damaging gallery masterpieces.
propcomment: Art masterpieces were damaged.
addnotes: The Mafia was suspected.
scite1: Warren Gerrard, "Terrorists Bomb Florence Museum," Toronto Star, May 30, 1993.

summary: 05/27/1993: The Khmer Rouge was suspected in an attack on a United Nations polling station in the Sot Nikun district. A Bangladeshi peacekeeper was injured.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 5/27/1993: Richard Thomas Andrews set a fire at the Women's Health Care clinic in Boise, Idaho, United States. There were no casualties, but the building sustained $100,000 in damages.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in Idaho.
weapdetail: Gasoline used as an accelerant
propcomment: Front door and surrounding area burned.  Extensive smoke damage throughout building.
addnotes: The fire was ignited around 3:00 AM.
scite1: "Arson Fire Damages Abortion Clinic," Moscow-Pullman Daily News, May 27, 1993.
scite2: Kelly McBride, "Fed Say Protests Escalated to Arson Man Suspected in 8 Fires at Abortion Clinics," The Spokesman Review, October 24, 1997.
scite3: "Attacks on the West Coast," The Oregonian, January 31, 1994.

location: Shots fired into family room and play room of Dr. Crist's son.
summary: 5/28/1993: Unknown perpetrators fired shotgun blasts into the Kansas City, Missouri, United States, home of Dr. Robert Crist. Dr. Crist had recently taken a position as the medical director of the Planned Parenthood of Greater Kansas City. There were no casualties, but the house was damaged.
target2: Medical Director of the Planned Parenthood of Greater Kansas City
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to instill fear in physicians who perform abortions.
weapdetail: Shotgun
addnotes: The attack took place at 1:45 AM while Dr. Crist and his family were asleep.  Nine days before the incident an anti-abortion hotline told callers that it was suspected that Dr. Crist had taken a position at the Planned Parenthood clinic.  Moreover, the message stated that "he will be monitored and appropriate action will be taken."
scite1: Peter Slevin, "Slaying Raises Fears on Both Sides of Abortion Debate," Washington Post, June 2, 2009.
scite2: Judy Lundstrom, "Abortion Providers Put Under the Gun," Wichita Eagle, August 7, 1994.
scite3: Patricia Baird-Windle and Eleanor J. Bader, "Targets of Hatred: Anti-Abortion Terrorism," Palgrave, 2001.

summary: 05/29/1993: 1 October Antifascist Resistance Group (GRAPO) launched their bomb attack on the election eve by bombing the headquarters of the Socialist Party in Madrid.
gname: First of October Antifascist Resistance Group (GRAPO)
motive: The attack was targeted against the Spanish government.
scite1: "Spanish Terrorists Launch Election Bomb Campaign," The Herald, May 29, 1993.

summary: 05/29/1993: 1 October Antifascist Resistance Group (GRAPO) launched their bomb attack on the election eve by bombing an election center of the Socialist Party in Madrid.
gname: First of October Antifascist Resistance Group (GRAPO)
motive: The attack was targeted against the Spanish government.
scite1: "Spanish Terrorists Launch Election Bomb Campaign," The Herald, May 29, 1993.

summary: 05/29/1993: Javier Cirujano Arjona, a priest from the church in San Jacinto, Colombia was abducted and killed by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and the Popular Liberation Army (EPL). The priest had been protecting former guerillas who had returned to civilian life.
motive: The priest was killed because he had been protecting former guerillas who had returned to civilian life.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/29/1993: A Berlin hostel occupied by Poles, Croats, and Bosnians was set on fire injuring fourteen. Neo-Nazis were suspected in the attack.
target1: Non-German occupants of the Berlin Hostel
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/29/1993: A Munich house holding a family of African asylum-seekers was set on fire, causing no injuries. Neo-Nazis were suspected in the attack.
target1: Non-German occupants of the Munich House
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/30/1993: Suspected skinheads in Wolfsburg attacked Romanian refugees, injuring one man.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/30/1993: An asylum-seeker's shelter in Cuxhaven was set on fire. German neighbors were suspected in the attack.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 05/31/1993: Right wing racists set fire to a house containing a 20 member Turkish family in the German city of Solingen. Five members of the family were killed.
motive: The attack appeared to target Turkish minorities in Germany.
propcomment: The house was destroyed.
addnotes: The perpetrator was probably a neo-Nazi group.
scite1: "Nazi Fear after Blaze Kills Five," Reuter, May 31, 1993.

summary: 05/31/1993: Suspected Khmer Rouge members ambushed a United Nations armed convoy in the Mimot District of Cambodia. One Uruguyan United Nations Peacekeeper was killed and another Uruguyan and two Polish Peacekeepers were injured.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/01/1993: Premkumar Sharma, leader of the Bharatiya Janata party and member of the Maharashtra state assembly, was shot and killed outside of his home in Mumbai.
scite1: Stefan Wagstyl, “Fears of renewed unrest in Bombay,” Financial Times, June 3, 1993.
scite2: “Army troops called out after slaying of second Hindu leader,” United Press International, June 2, 1993.
scite3: “Bombay tense following murder of Hindu party leader,” Agence France Presse, June 2, 1993.

summary: 06/01/1993: Unknown arsonists attacked a Munich shelter for foreign asylum seekers. No casualties resulted from this attack.
target1: Munich Shelter for Foreign Asylum Seekers
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/01/1993: An explosive device apparently thrown by protesters fell in the yard of the Bulgarian Embassy causing no injuries and minor damage.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/02/1993: Police defused a car bomb in central Rome 200 yards from the Prime Minister's office. No one was hurt.
scite1: The Associated Press, “Italy’s premier defies terrorism, car bomb,” Chicago Tribune, June 3, 1993.
scite2: Robert Graham, “Bomb defused in Rome near PM’s office,” Financial Times, June 3, 1993.
scite3: “A car bomb defused by police in Rome,” Agence France Presse, June 2, 1993

summary: 06/03/1993: Neo-Nazis were suspected of setting fire to the house of a Turkish woman in Hattingen, Germany. The woman and her five children escaped unharmed, but the home was destroyed.
propcomment: The fire gutted the home.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/04/1993: A Turkish restaurant was burned down in Konstanz, Germany by unknown assailants. No injuries were reported, but the damage was estimated at 500,000 German Mark ($312,676).
propcomment: The restaurant was burned down.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/06/1993: Pakistani peacekeepers were ambushed while on patrol in Mogadishu. 23 soldiers were killed and 74 were wounded.
scite1: Paul Alexander, “Radios, Timing Point to Well-Planned Attack,” The Associated Press, June 11, 1993
scite2: “Pakistanis protest massacre of U.N. troops in Somalia,” Agence France Presse, June 11, 1993.

summary: 06/06/1993: Suspected Kashmiri Muslim separatists ambushed an Indian army patrol in the village of Budhan Rafiabad, nine miles north of the city of Sopore. During the ensuing gun battle, 8 were killed and one injured.
addnotes: The gun battle lasted 40-minutes. One source claimed that four victims were killed while the other claimed that eight died in the incident (in addition to the perpetrator fatalities).
scite1: Qaiser Mirza, “Guerrilla Ambush Kills Army Officer in Kashmir,” The Associated Press, June 7, 1993.
scite2: Ghulam Nabi Khayal, “Kashmir Ambush,” The Guardian (London), June 7, 1993.

summary: 06/06/1993: Suspected PKK members attacked in Dortboluk, a village located in the township of Sason in southeastern Turkey. Five died and two were wounded.
scite1: “Four villagers, one Kurdish rebel killed,” Xinhua General Overseas News Service, June 7, 1993.
scite2: “300 slain in 2 weeks in Kurdish part of Turkey,” Chicago Tribune, June 8, 1993.

summary: 06/06/1993: Suspected right-wing radicals threw a firebomb into the home of a Lebanese family in Dortmund, Germany. One person was injured in the attack.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/07/1993: Unknown perpetrators threw a bomb at a tour bus in Cairo, killing one person and injuring 14 other people.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 06/07/1993: Unknown persons threw four incendiary devices into a Turkish restaurant in Oberhausen-Rheinhausen, Germany. One injury was reported.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/07/1993: Several incendiary devices were placed in the cellar of a Turkish restaurant in Hamburg, Germany. The perpetrators were unknown and no casualties were reported.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/07/1993: Unknown persons tried to set fire to a Frankfurt am Main building occupied mainly by foreigners. The fire was quickly extinguished and no injuries were reported.
target1: Foreign civilians in a building in Frankfurt
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/07/1993: Unknown persons set fire to the home of a Turkish family in Bergisch Gladbach, Germany. No injuries and little property damage was reported.
target1: Turkish family's home in Bergisch Gladbach
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/07/1993: Four male Turks set fire to the Christian Social Union offices in Aschaffenburg, Germany. The men claimed the attack was a retaliation for the recent anti-foreign attacks that had occurred in Germany. No casualties were reported.
target1: Christian Social Union office in Aschaffenburg
motive: Retaliation for anti-foreign attacks that had recently occurred in Germany
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: The attack occurred just south of the city
summary: 06/07/1993: About 150 Khmer Rouge members ambushed a platoon of Pakistani United Nations Peacekeepers just south of Phnum Tbeng Meanchey in Cambodia. Two of the Peacekeepers were injured and five Khmer Rouge members were killed.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/07/1993: Suspected right-wing radicals set fire to a building in Wuelfrath which housed several Turkish families. Fourteen injuries were reported.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: On the road to the Pyramids
summary: 06/08/1993: Suspected members of Al-Jama a al-Islamiyya (The Islamic Group) planted a nail bomb on a bicycle under an overpass on the highway to the pyramids. One person was killed and twenty-two others were wounded when the bomb went off in front of a tourist bus carrying British tourists. The car traveling in front of the bus took a majority of the impact.
target1: Tourists on their way to see the Pyramids
weapdetail: The bomb contained a maximum of 3 1/2 lbs. of explosives (probably TNT) and at least 2 lbs. of nails.
addnotes: Initial reports stated that 15 had been injured, but it appears that the final number was 22.
scite1: “Bomb near Pyramids kills one,” Chicago Tribune, June 9,1993.
scite2: David Daure, “Egyptian Dies in Nail Bomb Attack on Bus,” Chicago Sun-Times, June 9, 1993.
scite3: Al Aham Weekly, “Single handed suspected behind time-bombings in Egypt,” Moneyclips, June 10, 1993.

summary: 06/08/1993: The IRA exploded a bomb at a gasometer in Dunston, Gateshead. One firefighter was hurt in the aftermath of the attack.
addnotes: This was two of three related attacks (19930608003, 199306090004).
scite1: Malcolm Pithers, “Terrorist link suspected in gasometer explosion; Attack bears hallmarks of the IRA,” The Independent (London), June 10, 1993.
scite2: Martin Wainwright, “Tyneside Bombings Were IRA 'Lesson'; Belated statement suggests communication difficulties,” The Guardian (London), June 11, 1993.
scite3: “Tyneside is hit by second explosion,” The Herald, June 10, 1993.

summary: 06/08/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) exploded a bomb at a gasometer in Gateshead. No one was injured.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (199306080002, 199306090004).
scite1: Malcolm Pithers, “Terrorist link suspected in gasometer explosion; Attack bears hallmarks of the IRA,” The Independent (London), June 10, 1993.
scite2: Martin Wainwright, “Tyneside Bombings Were IRA 'Lesson'; Belated statement suggests communication difficulties,” The Guardian (London), June 11, 1993.
scite3: “Tyneside is hit by second explosion,” The Herald, June 10, 1993.

summary: 06/08/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) detonated a bomb at the Tyneside gas depot. The IRA claimed credit for this attack which caused minor damage.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 06/09/1993: The Ulster Freedom Fighters threw a grenade at the home of Gerry Adams in Andersontown, West Belfas. Adams was not home at the time. His wife and son suffered from shock as a result of the attack. The home only had minor damage.
addnotes: The Ulster Freedom Fighters, a branch of the Ulster Defense Association, claimed responsibility for the attack. This is not the first time they attempted to kill Mr. Adams.
scite1: John Hicks, “Midnight Grenade attack on Gerry Adam,” The Evening Standard, June 9, 1993.
scite2: Owen Bowcott, “Grenade attack at home of Sinn Fein President,” The Guardian (London), June 10, 1993.
scite3: “UDA admits to Adams attack,” The Irish Times, June 10, 1993.

location: Outside of the Ein el-Hilweh refugee camp
summary: 06/09/1993: Unidentified gunmen shot and killed Capt. Ahmed Mohammed Makhzoumi outside of the prison he ran inside of Ein el-Hilweh, a PLO refugee camp in south Lebanon.
addnotes: This incident was believed to be part of a feud between Fatah and Abu Nidal's Fatah-Revolutionary Council.
scite1: “Fatah movement official assassinated in Lebanon,” Xinhua General Over News Service, June 10, 1993.
scite2: “International News Briefs,” The Associated Press, June 10, 1993.
scite3: Reuters, “Fatah Official Shot Dead,” The New York Times, June 11, 1993.

summary: 06/09/1993: Irish Republican Army (IRA) exploded bomb at the Esso oil terminal in North Shields. No one was hurt.
addnotes: This was three of three related attacks (199306080002, 199306080003).
scite1: Malcolm Pithers, “IRA admits bombing terminal and gas tank; Terrorists 'ahead of the game' as safety fears grow in North-east” The Independent (London), June 11, 1993.
scite2: Roger Scott, “The Night Fear Lit Up The Sky; Hundreds Flee Gasworks Blasts,” Daily Mail (London), June, 10, 1993.
scite3: David Sharrock and Martin Wainwright, “New Tyneside Blast At Bomb-Hit Oil Terminal,” The Guardian (London), June 10, 1993

summary: 06/08/1993: Two bombs exploded near an empty petrol tank and pipes causing no injuries and only minor damage. The Irish Republican Army (IRA) claimed credit for the attack.
weapdetail: Two bombs
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 06/10/1993: Hizballah fired RPGs/mortars and machine guns at the South Lebanon Army in Beit Yahoun. No one was hurt.
weapdetail: It is unclear from the reports if both RPGs and mortars were used, or just one type of explosive was used.
scite1: David Rudge, “SLA sapper killed by roadside bomb,” The Jerusalem Post, June 11, 1993.
scite2: “Shiite Guerrillas Attack Israeli-Backed Militiamen,” The Associated Press, June 10, 1993.

summary: 06/11/1993: Hizballah and the Revolutionary Army for the Liberation of Palestine were suspected of firing Katyushas rockets into Upper Galilee. No one was reported killed or injured.
gname2: Revolutionary Army for the Liberation of Palestine
scite1: David Rudge and Michael Rotem, “Katyushas hit upper Galilee after two gunmen are killed in security zone,” The Jerusalem Post, June 13, 1993.
scite2: “Katyusha rockets hit Northern Israel,” Xinhua General Overseas News Service, June 12, 1993.
scite3: “Guerrillas fire rockets at Israel,” Agence France Presse, June 12, 1993.

summary: 06/11/1993: Unknown individuals fired mortars into a police and army station at Crossmaglen. No one was injured.
weapdetail: It was suspected the Mark 15 mortars were used.
scite1: “Mortar Attack,” Press Association, June 11, 1993.
scite2: “Mortar Attack,” The Independent (London), June 12, 1993.

summary: 06/11/1993: A house occupied by foreigners was firebombed in Stuttgart, leaving one injured. Right-wing radicals were suspected in the attack.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/12/1993: Five armed members of the Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC) attacked the homes of two families in Sainte-Lucie-de-Ponte-Vecchio. The attackers removed the families then set off explosives that leveled the homes. No one was injured in this incident.
propcomment: The attack leveled two homes.
addnotes: This was one of two attacks with very similar incident characteristics (cf. 199306120003).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/12/1993: Members of the Corsican National Liberation Front (FLNC) attacked the home of a family in Zonza. The attackers removed the family then set off explosives that destroyed the home. No one was injured in this incident.
propcomment: The attack destroyed the home.
addnotes: This was one of two attacks with very similar incident characteristics (cf. 199306120002).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/12/1993: Suspected right-wing radicals were believed to be responsible for a fire that broke out at a house occupied by three Turkish families in Bergisch Gladbach. Two men were injured.
propcomment: The home attacked was going to be condemned and torn down, so estimates about property damage could not be made.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/13/1993: Unknown individuals exploded a bomb outside the home of Uma Bharti, a leader in the Bharatiya Janata party. The home suffered some damage and four people were injured.
scite1: “Bomb explodes in India at Hindu leader’s home, wounding four,” United Press International, June 13, 1993.
scite2: All-India Radio, “Bomb explodes at BJP member's residence,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, June 15, 1993.
scite3: “Hindu MP escapes blast,” The Herald, June 14, 1993.

summary: 06/13/1993: A bomb exploded outside the offices of the Ecuadorian Institute of Agrarian Reform and Settlement in Quito. No casualties were reported. The police suspected the Maoist Inti Puka (Red Sun in Quechua) group.
corp1: Ecuadorian Institute of Agrarian Reform and Settlement
target1: Office of the Ecuadorian Institute of Agrarian Reform and Settlement in Quito
propcomment: The blast shattered windows and doors in the area.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/14/1993: Police defused four homemade bombs found in a bag across the street from the Coca-Cola bottling plant in the Cairo neighborhood of Dokki. No one was hurt.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (199306140002).
scite1: Santiago Lyon, “Bombs Defused In Cairo, Southern City Following Execution,” The Associated Press, June 14, 1993.
scite2: Bahaa Elkoussy, “Egypt prevents bombings, U.S. targets seen,” United Press International, June 14, 1993.

summary: 06/14/1993: Police defused two bombs near a railway line in the city of Asyut. No one was hurt.
addnotes: This was two of two related attacks (199306140001).
scite1: Santiago Lyon, “Bombs Defused In Cairo, Southern City Following Execution,” The Associated Press, June 14, 1993.
scite2: Bahaa Elkoussy, “Egypt prevents bombings, U.S. targets seen,” United Press International, June 14, 1993.

summary: 06/16/1993: Michel Azcueta, former leftist mayor of Villa el Salvador, Lima's oldest shantytown, was gunned down as he walked to work. Six other people were wounded in the attack. Shining Path was believed to be behind the attack.
scite1: Pamela Constable, “Series of raids has Peruvians fearing Shining Path rebirth,” The Boston Globe, June 18, 1993.
scite2: Malcolm Coad, “Sendero Strikes,” The Guardian (London), June 18, 1993.
scite3: “Police capture rebels who tried to kill former mayor,” United Press International, June 17, 1993.

summary: 06/17/1993: Members of the Islamic Resistance Movement attacked six South Lebanon Army posts at the border crossing, Beit Yahoun, with Katyusha rockets, RPGs, and machine gun fire. No one was reported injured.
weapdetail: Katyusha rockets, RPGs, and machine guns.
addnotes: The Islamic Resistance Movement is part of Hizballah.
scite1: David Rudge, “Hezbollah attacks 10 SLA positions IDF joins in hitting back terror targets,” The Jerusalem Post, June 18, 1993.
scite2: Abdel Mawla Khaled, “Guerrilla attacks wound five SLA militiamen,” United Press International, June 17, 1993.

summary: 06/17/1993: A gunman walk into the bar at the York Hotel in Belfast and shot dead John Murphy, and ex-RUC officer. The Irish National Liberation Army claimed responsibility.
corp1: Former Member of Royal Ulster Constabulary
addnotes: This was probably a revenge killing.
scite1: “Gunman shoots former policeman dead in Belfast bar,” Agence France Presse, June 18, 1993.
scite2: “International News Briefs By The Associated Press,” The Associated Press, June 18, 1993.

summary: 06/17/1993: The British army defused a bomb outside the front door of a SDLP councilor's home in the Tardee Grove section of Ballymena.
corp1: Social Democratic and Labour Party (SDLP) Party
addnotes: One source states that this attack is part of a larger plot to target SDLP council members.
scite1: “Ex-policeman shot dead,” Press Association, June 18, 1993.
scite2: Martin Cowley, “Man killed in Belfast had served in RUC,” The Irish Times, June 19, 1993.

summary: 06/17/06: Hizballah detonated a roadside bomb in the Jezzine District as a SLA patrol passed. One soldier was slightly injured.
weapdetail: Roadside bomb
scite1: David Rudge, “Hezbollah attacks 10 SLA positions IDF joins in hitting back terror targets,” The Jerusalem Post, June 18, 1993.
scite2: Abdel Mawla Khaled, “Guerrilla attacks wound five SLA militiamen,” United Press International, June 17, 1993.

location: The attack occurred in the Munsterland region.
summary: 06/17/1993: Two young men shot to death a Kurdish asylum seeker in Munsterland. The two men rang the front door of a hostel in Munsterland where 15 Kurdish asylum-seekers lived. A 6 year-old boy answered the door and called for his father. When his father answered the men shot him three times. He died in the hospital later the same day. Right-wing radicals were suspected in the attack.
addnotes: This was one of a number of attacks on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type. (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005)
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: The attack occurred in the 'Ayn al-Hulway Palestinian Refugee camp near Sidon
summary: 06/17/1993: A bomb killed Fatah Officer 'Ali Iskandar and his wife and wounded three other family members when it exploded at their home in the 'Ayn al-Hulway Palestinian Refugee camp near Sidon. The perpetrators were unknown.
target1: Home of Fatah Party Officer 'Ali Iskandar in the 'Ayn al-Hulway Palestinian Refugee camp near Sidon
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/18/1993: Suspected Islamic militants detonated a car bomb in the Cairo slum of Shubra. Three people were killed and 18 injured.
addnotes: One source claimed two were killed, while the others claimed seven and three. Two of the sources stated that 18 were injured, while the other source stated that 20 were injured. The lower figures have been cited here.
scite1: “Cairo Bomb Kills Three,” Press Association, June 18, 1993.
scite2: Bahaa Elkoussy, “Cairo explosion,” United Press International, June 18, 1993.
scite3: “Police blame Al-Jihad for deadly Cairo nail bomb,” Agence France Presse, June 20, 1993.

summary: 06/21/1993: ETA was suspected of setting off a car bomb during rush hour, under a bridge in the Salamanca district in central Madrid. Seven people were killed and 21 wounded. The dead were soldiers whose vehicle was parked next to the car when the bomb exploded.
target1: Rush hour commuters traveling in the Salamanca district of central Madrid
weapdetail: Eighty-eight pounds of high-explosives
propcomment: Broken windows
addnotes: This is one of two linked incidents (cf. 199306210002).
scite1: “Seven dead, 20 injured in car bomb attacks – police,” Agence France Presse, June 21, 1993.
scite2: Susan Linnee, “Two Car Bombs Show Weakened ETA Still Capable of Death Blows,” The Associated Press, June 21, 1993.
scite3: Ciaran Giles, “Car Bombs Rock Madrid Rush Hour; Seven Dead, 25 Injured,” The Associated Press, June 21, 1993.

summary: 06/21/1993: Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) was suspected of setting off a car bomb on Serrano street near the American Embassy and the French ambassador's residence. Three people were injured.
addnotes: This is one of two linked incidents (cf. 199306210001).
scite1: “Seven dead, 20 injured in car bomb attacks – police,” Agence France Presse, June 21, 1993.
scite2: Susan Linnee, “Two Car Bombs Show Weakened ETA Still Capable of Death Blows,” The Associated Press, June 21, 1993.
scite3: Ciaran Giles, “Car Bombs Rock Madrid Rush Hour; Seven Dead, 25 Injured,” The Associated Press, June 21, 1993.

summary: 06/22/1993: The IRA exploded a 300 lb. bomb in an Austin Metro van near the Mourne Country Hotel causing minor damage and injuries.
weapdetail: The 300lb. bomb was planted in a stolen van. Officials believed it was made of fertilizer.
propcomment: The front wall of the hotel fell down and some minor damage was caused to surrounding homes.
addnotes: Reports stated that the IRA warned officials beforehand, but it did not specify how. The IRA usually phoned in such warnings.
scite1: “Bomb injuries two after terror blitz warning,” Press Association, June 22, 1993.
scite2: Owen Bowcott, “IRA van bomb damages country hotel and 70 homes,” The Guardian (London), June 23, 1993.

summary: 06/22/1993: Hizballah and the Believers Resistance fired rockets into the village of Shoumariya in an attempt to target SLA troops posted there. No one was reported hurt.
scite1: David Rudge and Itim, “Hizbullah again hits security zone targets,” The Jerusalem Post, June 23, 1993.
scite2: “Shiite Guerrillas Attack SLA Posts,” The Associated Press, June 22, 1993.
scite3: “Guerrilla attacks prompt Israeli shelling,” United Press International, June 22, 1993.

location: Central area of the security zone in southern Lebanon
summary: 06/22/1993: Hizballah fired mortars and RPGs at SLA patrols in the central area of the security zone. No one was hurt.
weapdetail: Mortars and RPGs
scite1: David Rudge and Itim, “Hizbullah again hits security zone targets,” The Jerusalem Post, June 23, 1993.
scite2: “Shiite Guerrillas Attack SLA Posts,” The Associated Press, June 22, 1993.
scite3: “Guerrilla attacks prompt Israeli shelling,” United Press International, June 22, 1993.

summary: 06/22/1993: Somali gunmen attacked the headquarters of the United States Logistics Support Command with sniper fire and rocket-propelled grenades. Two of the Somali gunmen were killed in the attack. No other injuries were reported.
target1: United States Logistics Support Command in Mogadishu
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/22/1993: A bomb sent by the Unabomber (later discovered to be Theodore Kaczynski) exploded in the office of Professor Charles Epstein, a geneticist at the University of California San Francisco. Epstein was injured in the attack.
motive: Kaczynski's attacks were meant to draw attention to the dangers of modern technology.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/23/1993: The IRA killed Joseph Mulhern, a suspected police informer. They dumped the body along the border with the Republic of Ireland in County Tyrone.
addnotes: The victim was probably shot.
scite1: “IRA kills suspected police informer,” Agence France Presse, June 23, 1993.
scite2: “IRA shoots ‘informer’,” The Guardian (London), June 25, 1993.
scite3: Martin Crowley, “IRA kills former member of UDR,” The Irish Times, June 25, 1993

summary: 06/24/1993: A bomb sent by UNABOM (later discovered to be Theodore Kaczynski) exploded in the office of Professor David Gelernter, a computer-science instructor at Yale University. As a result of the attack, Gelernter lost sight in one eye, hearing in one ear, and part of his right hand
motive: Kaczynski's attacks were meant to draw attention to the dangers of modern technology.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.
scite2: “The Unabomber: A Chronology,” Court TV Online, December 1999.

summary: 06/24/1993: In a series of related Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) attacks against Turkish targets across Europe, about 50 suspected members of the PKK tried to storm the Turkish Embassy in Berne. One Kurd was killed and 7 people were injured, including a policeman. About 50 Kurdish protesters tried to storm the Turkish Embassy in Berne, Switzerland.
addnotes: This was one of seventeen related attacks (cf. 199306240001-4; 199306240006-16; 199306240019-20).
scite1: “Terrorism Militant Kurds attack Turkish holdings in five European countries; one dies,” Chicago Tribune, June 24, 1993.
scite2: Cayol T, “Kurds seize hostages,” Herald Sun, June 25, 1993.
scite3: “Kurdish activists hit Turkish targets across Europe as coalition govt pact is signed,” Mideast Mirror, June 24, 1993.

summary: 06/24/1993: In a series of related Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) attacks against Turkish targets across Europe, a group of PKK members attacked and took over the Turkish Consulate in Munich along with 21 hostages. They surrendered after 14 hours. No injuries were reported.
weapdetail: The Kurds put gasoline all over the building and threatened to light it if anyone stormed the building.
addnotes: Two hostages were released almost immediately due to a heart attack and shock. The women were released at dusk and the others sometime later. The incident lasted 14 hours. This was one of seventeen related attacks (cf. 199306240001-4; 199306240006-16; 199306240019-20).
scite1: “Terrorism Militant Kurds attack Turkish holdings in five European countries; one dies,” Chicago Tribune, June 24, 1993.
scite2: AAPINTNEWS, “Militant Kurds free hostages,” Courier-Mail, June 26, 1993.
scite3: Cayol T, “Kurds seize hostages,” Herald Sun, June 25, 1993.

summary: 06/24/1993: In a series of related Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) attacks against Turkish targets across Europe, members of the PKK, who claimed to have bombs, took over the Turkish Consulate in Marseille along with 10 hostages. No injuries were reported and the hostages were released without incident after three hours.
weapdetail: The hostage takers claimed to have explosives, but it was unclear from the reports if they actually had them.
addnotes: This was one of seventeen related attacks (cf. 199306240001-4; 199306240006-16; 199306240019-20).
scite1: “Terrorism Militant Kurds attack Turkish holdings in five European countries; one dies,” Chicago Tribune, June 24, 1993.
scite2: Cayol T, “Kurds seize hostages,” Herald Sun, June 25, 1993.

summary: 06/24/1993: In a series of related Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) attacks against Turkish targets across Europe, members of the PKK blockaded the Turkish Consulate in Karlsruhe. A group of Turks attacked the Kurds and 6 people were injured. At least 100 people were arrested in the attacks.
addnotes: This was one of seventeen related attacks (cf. 199306240001-4; 199306240006-16; 199306240019-20).
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 06/24/1993: In a series of related attacks, ten Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) members attacked the Turkish Pamuk Bank causing extensive damage. No injuries were reported.
addnotes: This was one of seventeen related attacks (cf. 199306240001-4; 199306240006-16; 199306240019-20).

summary: 06/24/1993: Three unknown black gunmen shot AK-47 rifles at Caucasians who had parked their cars outside a factory. Three Caucasians and one black passerby were killed.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 06/26/1993: A British soldier was killed by a sniper. The soldier was on foot patrol in Belleeks near the border with other troops when the sniper opened fire on them.

location: Various IDF and SLA posts in the area
summary: 06/29/1993: Hizballah fired Katyushas at various Israeli Defense Force and South Lebanon Army locations in the Security Zone. No casualties were reported.
weapdetail: Katyusha rockets
addnotes: Some damage was caused when the Israeli Defense Force and South Lebanon Army responded to Hizballah's attack. The attack details were not very clear.

summary: 07/00/1993: Masked Irish Republican Army (IRA) men seized control of a house and then kept watch over a Catholic prayer session as the perpetrators tried to bomb the Stormont Hotel in Belfast. Nineteen people attending the meeting were held hostage in the home of Danny McCaffrey, 52, whose car was used to transport the 500lb bomb across the city. Army explosives experts called to the Stormont Hotel defused the bomb.
addnotes: Even though they were held captive, members of the prayer group carried on with the meeting at the house in Stewartstown Park, Lenadoon. They moved to a kitchen while the terrorists kept watch from the front room.
scite1: Deric Henderson, “Masked IRA Men Hold Praying Catholics Hostage,” The Press Association Limited, July 9, 1993.

summary: 07/00/1993: St. Patrick's Church on Victoria Street in Newtownards, Ulster was firebombed. Father Dan White, a Roman Catholic parish priest from the church blamed loyalist extremists for the attack, saying he believed it was "misguided revenge" for a devastating IRA car bomb attack in the town.
propcomment: The firebomb attack left the vestry and school of St Patrick's church in smoking ruin.
scite1: Garry Moriarty, “Petrol Bombs used in Loyalist Attacks,” The Irish Times, City Edition, July 12, 1993.
scite2: Tim Miles, “Firebomb Attack on Church ‘Misguided Revenge,’” The Press Association, July 10, 1993.

summary: 07/01/1993: In Jerusalem, two Palestinian gunmen and a hostage were killed following an attack on an Egged Bus commuter bus. The gunmen opened fire inside the bus, wounding two Israelis and a Palestinian. The suspects then commandeered a car driven by an Israeli woman. All three were killed when security troops opened fire at a roadblock and a grenade apparently went off in the car.
target2: Jeanette Kadosh Dayan (39-year old Israeli woman)
propcomment: A Private car was damaged.
addnotes: Approximately 75 passengers were able to flee the bus when the bus driver attempted to overpower the gunmen. The two suspects then commandeered a car driven by an Israeli woman. All three were killed when security troops opened fire at a roadblock and a grenade apparently went off in the car.
scite1: Bill Hutman et al, “Woman Dies after Capital Bus Attack Police Identify Terrorists as Hamas Members,” The Jerusalem Post, July 2, 1993.
scite2: David Horovitz, “Palestinian Raid Seen as Effort to Halt Talks,” The Irish Times, July 2, 1993.
scite3: Clyde Haberman, “Attackers of Bus Sought Hostages, Israel Says,” The New York Times, July 3, 1993.

summary: 07/01/1993: The Revolutionary Anti-Racist Action (RARA) planted and detonated a time bomb at 3 a.m. in a toilet at the Dutch Social Affairs Ministry creating a six-meter-wide hole in the 5th floor. Damage was minor and there were no reported injuries.
propcomment: The bomb caused a six-meter-wide hole in the 5th floor.
scite1: “Bombing at Ministry of Social Affairs,” United Press International, July 1, 1993.
scite2: “Dutch Terror Blast,” The Press Association Limited, July 1, 1993.
scite3: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 07/01/1993: A rocket was fired at the Yokota United States Air Force Base. No injuries were reported. The rocket exploded prematurely before reaching the base. However, it caused damage to a nearby apartment complex. The group Kakurokyo claimed credit.
propcomment: Damage to a nearby apartment complex.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 07/02/1993: Thirty-five people were killed and about 60 injured when Turkish fundamentalists, engaged in a protest against the visit of Salman Rushdie's editor, set fire to the hotel in which he was staying.
target1: Turkish author Aziz Nesin, who had translated Salman Rushdie's novel The Satanic Verses.
motive: To protest against Salman Rushdie's novel The Satanic Verses.
scite1: “35 dead, 60 injured in hotel fire set by Turkish fundamentalists,” Agence France Presse, July 3, 1993.
scite2: “Rushdie appalled as 40 die in book protests,” Agence France Presse, July 2, 1993.

summary: 07/05/1993: A woman (Batsheva Hillel, 56) was stabbed in the Yemin Moshe section of Jerusalem, the second terror attack in the capital in five days. One or two perpetrators stabbed her five times in the back in the Neri Bloomfield Gardens. The woman was taken to Hadassah-University Hospital and was in satisfactory condition.
scite1: Bill Hutman and Judy Siegel, “Terrorist stabs woman in Jerusalem,” The Jerusalem Post, July 6, 1993.

summary: 07/06/1993: Members of the Kurdish Workers' Party (PKK) attacked the village of Basbaglar in Erzincan province. The guerrillas massacred 32 people and burned down 50 of the 57 homes.
propcomment: Guerrillas burned down 50 of the 57 homes in the village.
scite1: “Attack on Eastern Turkish Village Kills 28,” United Press International, July 6, 1993.
scite2: Pam O’Toole, “Kurdish Militants Murder 32 in Raid on Turkish Village,” The Guardian (London), July 7, 1993.

summary: 07/07/1993: As many as six Somali employees of the United Nations were slain in an ambush in Mogadishu. Two of the Somalis were dragged from their car and shot dead in a busy street market while four others wounded in the attack were abducted and presumed dead. Gunmen were believed to be loyal to the fugitive warlord Mohamed Farrah Aidid.
addnotes: The Hostages were presumed dead.
scite1: Angus Shaw, “United Nations Workers Slain In Ambush,” The Associated Press, July 7, 1993.
scite2: “Somali Employees of UN Ambushed: 6 Feared Dead,” Los Angeles Times, July 8, 1993.

summary: 07/07/1993: This was one of two attacks carried out by a small militant group, the Kakurokyo (Revolutionary Workers), in protest to the G-7 Summit in Tokyo. In this incident at least five projectiles hit Camp Zuma, a U.S. military base south-west of Tokyo. There were no injuries.
motive: To protest against the Tokyo G-7 summit.
propcomment: The bomb created a large hole in the ground
addnotes: This case was one of 2 related attacks (cf. 199307070004)

scite2: MIPT Terrorism Knowledge Base. "TKB Incident Page: Kakurokyo attacked Military target (July 7, 1993, Japan)." Website. Available from http://www.tkb.org/Incident.jsp?incID=5111.

summary: 07/07/1993: Katyusha rockets fired by Hizballah exploded near homes in Western Galilee causing minor damage but no casualties. The aim of the attack was to try and disrupt peace talks.
motive: This attack was an attempt to derail peace talks.

scite1: David Rudge, “Residents Rocked by Morning Attack,” The Jerusalem Post, July 7, 1993.

scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

location: On the roadside, 15 miles east of the southern port city of Sidon
summary: 07/08/1993: Guerrillas of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine- General Command planted a roadside bomb on a dusty path in the eastern sector of the ''security zone'' imposed by Israel, some 15 miles east of the southern port city of Sidon. Two Israeli soldiers were killed and three others were wounded, while the attackers escaped unharmed, the security sources said.
gname: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, Gen Cmd (PFLP-GC)
propcomment: An  Armored vehicle was damaged.

summary: 07/11/1993: A group of Kurdish rebels attacked a gas station in the southeastern Mutki district, killing two watchmen. The rebels - believed to be members of the outlawed Kurdish Workers' Party (PKK) - set fire to a building where the two watchmen were staying. The perpetrators set the whole station ablaze before the watchmen were able to escape.
motive: This attack was part of a campaign to establish an independent state in the southeast.
propcomment: The building in which the two watchmen were staying.
scite1: “Two Killed by Kurdish Rebels in Turkey,” Xinhua, July 12, 1993.

summary: 07/13/1993: A homemade bomb exploded near a sports club in the upper-class residential area of Zamalek in downtown Cairo in the early morning, causing no casualties, police sources said. The relatively minor explosion caused slight damage to the fence of the Gezira Sports Center. No one claimed responsibility for the bombing.
propcomment: The attack caused slight damage to the fence of the Gezira Sports Center.
scite1: “Bomb Blast near Sports Club in Cairo,” Xinhua, July 13, 1993.
scite2: “Bomb Explosion in Cairo,” Tass, July 13, 1993.

summary: 07/14/1993: A man was arrested at a north London bus stop carrying a large Semtex bomb in a shoulder bag. The perpetrator is believed to be a key figure in the Irish Republican Army's (IRA) mainland bombing campaign. Police believe he intended to take the 8 lb bomb into the City of London by public transport. The motive for the attack was cited as the IRA's response to new traffic restrictions.
motive: This was the IRA's response to new traffic restrictions.
weapdetail: 8 pound Semtex bomb with a timing device and detonator
scite1: Peter Burden, “Bomber at Bus Stop: Dramatic Moment when Armed Police Swooped on IRA Suspect,” Daily Mail (London), July 15, 1993.
scite2: “Police Question Bomb Suspect,” Agence France Presse, July 14, 1993.
scite3: Edward Pilkington, “Bomb-in-Bag Suspect Held in Street,” The Guardian (London), July 15, 1993.

summary: 07/15/1993: Belfast's main rail terminus, Central Station, was reported as extensively damaged in a suspected Irish Republican Army (IRA) bomb attack early in the morning. There were no reports of any injuries, but the building was badly damaged.
propcomment: The building was badly damaged.
scite1: Gerry Moriarty, “ Belfast Station Bomb,” The Irish Times, July 15,1993.
scite2: Reuters, “Bomb Explodes in Belfast,” The New York Times, July 15, 1993.

summary: 7/16/1993: Unknown perpetrators threw a firebomb at the front door of the Planned Parenthood of Lancaster, Pennsylvania, United States. The incendiary device failed to ignite but still managed to cause minor damage to the abortion clinic.
target1: Planned Parenthood clinic in Lancaster, Pennsylvania
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in Pennsylvania.
weapdetail: Firebomb consisting of a bottle full of gasoline with a wick
addnotes: Two months after the incident, the same abortion clinic was destroyed by a firebomb (199309300001).
scite1: Nathan Lee Gadsden, "Firebomb Destroys Lancaster Clinic/Agency Plans Tighter Security," Patriot-News, September 30, 1993.
scite2: "Lancaster Planned Parenthood Clinic Firebombed," Associated Press, September 29, 1993.
scite3: Patricia Baird-Windle and Eleanor J. Bader, "Targets of Hatred: Anti-Abortion Terrorism," Palgrave, 2001.

summary: 07/17/1993: One of three attacks seemingly carried out by the PKK. In the Mediterranean resort city of Antalya, grenade attacks on three hotels killed one Turk and wounded two others. According to Anatolia News Agency, a grenade was lobbed from a speeding car at the entrance of Mithat Hotel, killing a 20-year-old man and causing minor injuries to a teen-ager and a 5-year-old boy. In other incidents Grenades were thrown simultaneously at the Kanarya and Ozkonak hotels, but caused no damage or injuries. Anatolia News Agency also stated that there were no foreign guests at any of the hotels.
addnotes: This case was one of three related attacks (cf. 199307170002; 199307170003) The Sources' information was gathered from a local “semi-official news agency.”
scite1: “One Killed, two Injured by Grenades in Turkish Resort,” Agence France Presse, July 17, 1993.
scite2: “Terrorist bombs Kill one in Resort City, The Associated Press, July  17, 1993.

summary: 07/19/1993: The Moslem extremist group al-Gamaa al-Islamiya claimed responsibility for an attack on the car of an Army General in Cairo, which led to four deaths. A member of the group said the move was taken to avenge the government's executions of five militants on Saturday, July 17th.
target1: Maj. Gen. Osman Ahmed Metwalli Shaheen, commander of the Central Zone
motive: This attack was revenge for the Government's assassination of militants.
scite1: Chris Hedges, “4 Die in Egypt as Militants Attack General’s Car,” The New York Times, July 19, 1993.
scite2: “Moslem Extremists Claim Responsibility for Attack on Army General,” Xinhua, July 19, 1993.
scite3: Caryle Murphy, “Egyptian Ambush Leaves 4 Dead; Extremists Attack Police Patrol in Apparent Retaliation for Hangings,” The Washington Post, July 19, 1993.

summary: 07/20/1993: The firebombing of the NAACP's Sacramento office resulted in the destruction of the building. Fire officials say "a flammable liquid-type device" was thrown through a window of an unoccupied office. Wayne Paul Wooten, 18, Jeremiah Gordon Knesal, 19, and Mark Kowaalski, 24, were held by the FBI as suspects.
corp1: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)
target1: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) office in Sacramento
propcomment: The early morning blaze destroyed the building.
addnotes: The men were reportedly members of the neo-Nazi Church of the Creator. Authorities believed that the perpetrators were intent on starting a race war. This was one of three linked incidents (cf. 199307200001, 199307200003, 199207220001).
scite1: “Racists’ Terror Plot,” Newsday, July 30, 1993.
scite2: John Snell, “FBI Says Terror Group Had Plans to Bomb Synagogue in Portland,” The Oregonian (Portland, Oregon), July 30, 1993.
scite3: Wayne Wurzer, “3 Suspects in NAACP Bombing in Custody—Two Tacoma Men Arrested in Calif.,” The Seattle Times, July 29, 1993.

summary: 07/20/1993: Loyalists from The Ulster Freedom Fighters launched coordinated bomb attacks at the Belfast homes of three prominent members of the nationalist SDLP. No one was hurt in the attacks.
motive: The perpetrators claimed that SDLP was linked to the IRA and Sinn Fein.
weapdetail: Three one-pound bombs
scite1: “Terrorists in Bomb Attacks on SDLP Politicians; Blasts Display UFF's Increasing Sophistication,” The Independent (London), July 21, 1993.

summary: 07/20/1993: A pipe bomb was thrown into a National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) office in Tacoma, Washington, USA, causing minor property damage. The office was empty at the time, and no casualties resulted. Supremacist Mark Kowaalski pleaded guilty to this incident in October 1993 and fellow supremacists Jeremiah Gordon Knesal and Wayne Paul Wooten Jr. were arrested in December 1993 for this attack.
corp1: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP)
target1: National Association for the Advancement of Colored People (NAACP) office in Tacoma

addnotes: The men were reportedly members of the neo-Nazi Church of the Creator. Authorities believed that the perpetrators were intent on starting a race war. This was one of three linked incidents (cf. 199307200001, 199307200003, 199207220001).

scite3: Stephen Schwartz, “Arson Destroys Sacramento NAACP Office,” The San Francisco Chronicle, July 28, 1993.

summary: 07/22/1993: The Elite Tavern, a gay bar in the Capital Hill neighborhood of Seattle, Washington, USA, was bombed. There were no casualties in this attack. Supremacists Jeremiah Gordon Knesal, Mark Kowaalski and Wayne Paul Wooten, Jr. were suspected in this incident. In February 1994, Wooten pleaded guilty to pleaded guilty in February to aiding and abetting in this attack. In September of that year he was sentanced to four years and nine months in prison.
weapdetail: Pipebomb
addnotes: The men were reportedly members of the neo-Nazi Church of the Creator. Authorities believed that the perpetrators were intent on starting a race war. This was one of three linked incidents (cf. 199307200001, 199307200003, 199207220001).
