summary: 07/25/1993: Rebels from Liberation Tigers of Tamil Eelam (LTTE) fired mortar bombs and automatic weapons against strategic army detachments in northeast Sri Lanka, killing 22 soldiers and 15 civilians.
scite1: “Tamil Tigers Kill 37 in Camp Raids,” Agence France Presse, July 25, 1993.

summary: 07/25/1993: A small bomb hidden in a trash can near an ATM at a money exchange post exploded near the Haya Sophia Cathedral Museum in Istanbul. Three tourists and one local were injured. Kurdish militants were suspected.
target1: An ATM at a money exchange post
scite1: “Four Persons Injured In Bomb Explosion in Istanbul,” ITAR-TASS, July 26, 1993.
scite2: MIPT Terrorism Knowledge Base. "TKB Incident Page: Other Group attacked Tourists target (July 25, 1993, Turkey)." Website. Available from http://www.tkb.org/Incident.jsp?incID=7128.

summary: 07/25/1993: A car-bomb packed with 30 kilos of explosives exploded outside the Champanac Catholic School in the Miraflores residential district of Lima. Although no deaths or injuries were reported, the explosion caused major damage to the school building and neighboring businesses. Shining Path rebels were suspected.
weapdetail: A vehicle packed with 30 kilos of explosives.
propcomment: The explosion caused major damage to the school building and shattered the doors and windows of neighboring shops and businesses.
scite1: “Peru: Shining Path Blamed for Car-Bomb Explosion Outside School,” Inter Press Service, July 26, 1993.

summary: 07/25/1993: Five gunmen attacked a crowded church congregation in Kenilworth, a suburb of Cape Town, killing 11 people and wounding 52.
motive: The attack was an attempt to derail peace negotiations.
scite1: Bill Keller, “Attack on Cape Town Church Keeps a Rattled Nation Edgy,” The New York Times, July 27, 1993.
scite2: Dele Olojede, “ S. Africa Shaken but not Cowed: Talks Despite Church Slaughter,” Newsday, July 27, 1993.
scite3: “Death Toll in Church Massacre up to 11 as Police Hunt Killers,” Agence France Presse, July 26, 1993.

summary: 7/25/1993: Richard Joseph Campos, the sole member of the Aryan Liberation Front, threw a Molotov cocktail at Congregation B'nai Israel in Sacramento, California, United States. The firebomb bounced off of a plexiglass window and ignited a fire in a tree outside of the building. The synagogue was not damaged.
motive: Richard Joseph Campos adopted the racist ideology of the White Aryan Resistance (WAR) and wanted to create an all-White society.
weapdetail: Molotov cocktail thrown at the building
propcomment: Tree outside of building damaged
addnotes: Richard Joseph Campos bombed four other buildings in the Sacramento area including the NAACP headquarters, the Japanese American Citizens League building, the home of city councilman Jimmie Yee, and the state Office of Fair Employment and Housing building (199310020003, 199310050004, and 199310140009).  After he firebombed the house of Jimmie Yee, Campos called the Sacramento television station KOVR claiming that the Aryan Liberation Front carried out the firebombing of the synagogue.  Campos was the only member of the Aryan Liberation Front.  Before carrying out his bombing campaign, Campos called the White Aryan Resistance (WAR) hotline 34 times to listen to messages from the organizations leader Tom Metzger.  Campos had a WAR poster in his bedroom when he was arrested.
scite1: Ann Bancroft, "Councilman's Home Attacked In Sacramento," San Francisco Chronicle, October 6, 1993.
scite2: "Man Convicted Of 2 Bombings Tied to Racism," New York Times, August 31, 1994.
scite3: Mareva Brown, "Racist's Rampage Was 'Wake-Up Call.'  The White Supremacist Convicted in '93 Bombings is Out of Prison," Sacramento Bee, July 7, 2003.

summary: 07/27/1993: Three bombs exploded overnight in Milan and Rome. In this first incident a car bomb exploded in front of the Modern Art Museum Milan’s Gothic Cathedral. 5 died and 20 were wounded. The "Armed Phalange," claimed responsibility.
target1: The Modern Art Museum (Milan’s Gothic Cathedral)
motive: The perpetrators were demanding political reform in light of the nation's massive corruption scandal
weapdetail: A fire was set to a car in an effort to draw firefighters and police to the scene. The bomb explode soon after their arrival.
addnotes: Police discounted the "Armed Phalange" as a real force, pointing out that the organization, if it really exists, only calls in after terrorist acts have been reported by the media.    This case was one of three related attacks (cf. 1993072702;1993072703).
scite1: Charles Ridley, “Car Bombs in Rome and Milan Kill Five, Wound at least 32,” United Press International, July 27, 1993.
scite2: “Mystery of Car Bombings Deepen,” Hobart Mercury, July, 30, 1993.
scite3: “Terror Bomb Blasts Kill Five, Wound 29, Agence France Presse, July 28, 1993.

summary: 07/27/1993: Three bombs exploded overnight in Milan and Rome. In this second incident a car bomb exploded by the 17th century Church of St. John the Lateran in Rome. The "Armed Phalange," claimed responsibility.
corp1: Church of St. John the Lateran
target1: Church of St. John the Lateran in Rome
motive: The perpetrators were demanding political reform in light of the nation's massive corruption scandal
propcomment: The explosion damaged an obelisk and part of the rear of the basilica.
addnotes: Police discounted the "Armed Phalange" as a real force, pointing out that the organization, if it really exists, only calls in after terrorist acts have been reported by the media.  This case was one of three related attacks (cf. 1993072701;1993072703)
scite1: Charles Ridley, “Car Bombs in Rome and Milan Kill Five, Wound at least 32,” United Press International, July 27, 1993.
scite2: “Mystery of Car Bombings Deepen,” Hobart Mercury, July, 30, 1993.
scite3: “Terror Bomb Blasts Kill Five, Wound 29, Agence France Presse, July 28, 1993.

summary: 07/27/1993: Three bombs exploded overnight in Milan and Rome. In this third incident a car bomb exploded by a 12th century church near the Forum in Rome The "Armed Phalange," claimed responsibility.
corp1: The Church of San Giorgio di Velabro
target1: A 12th century church near the Forum in Rome
motive: The perpetrators were demanding political reform in light of the nation's massive corruption scandal
propcomment: The explosion devastated the church of San Giorgio di Velabro
addnotes: Police discounted the "Armed Phalange" as a real force, pointing out that the organization, if it really exists, only calls in after terrorist acts have been reported by the media. This case was one of three related attacks (cf. 1993072702;1993072702)
scite1: Charles Ridley, “Car Bombs in Rome and Milan Kill Five, Wound at least 32,” United Press International, July 27, 1993.
scite2: “Mystery of Car Bombings Deepen,” Hobart Mercury, July, 30, 1993.
scite3: “Terror Bomb Blasts Kill Five, Wound 29, Agence France Presse, July 28, 1993.

summary: 07/27/1993: The U.S. Embassy and surrounding area suffered extensive damage when a van containing 200 kilograms of ammonium nitrate fuel oil and dynamite exploded, killing one and injuring six. Authorities suspected that the Shining Path (Sendero Luminoso) was responsible for planting the bomb. No further information was reported.
weapdetail: Van containing 200 kilograms of ammonium nitrate fuel oil and dynamite exploded. The van was pushed by perpetrators toward the building.
propcomment: The explosion shattered glass and caused fires in the four-story concrete building.
scite1: “Bus bomb explodes outside U.S. Embassy in Lima,” United Press International, July 27, 1993.
scite2: “Terror Bomb Explodes Outside U.S. Embassy,” Miami Herald, July 28, 1993.
scite3: Nathaniel C. Nash, “4 Wounded as Rebels Bomb U.S. Embassy in Peru,”  The New York Times, July 28, 1993.

summary: 07/30/1993: Eighteen people, including six foreign tourists, were hurt when a bomb planted in a garbage bin exploded in the Turkish resort town of Kusadasi. The Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) was cited as the perpetrator of this attack.
scite1: “Turk Bomb Hurts 18,” Newsday, July 31, 1993.
scite2: MIPT Terrorism Knowledge Base. "TKB Incident Page: Unknown Group attacked Private Citizens & Property target (July 30, 1993, Turkey)." Website. Available from http://www.tkb.org/Incident.jsp?incID=7131.

summary: 07/30/1993: A bomb exploded outside the Colombian Embassy in Caracas. No injuries were reported and no perpetrators were identified in this incident. The explosion caused minor damage.
scite1: MIPT Terrorism Knowledge Base. "TKB Incident Page: Unknown Group attacked Diplomatic target (July 30, 1993, Venezuela)." Website. Available from http://www.tkb.org/Incident.jsp?incID=7132.

summary: 08/00/1993: The Anti-Imperialist Resistance Cell Nadia Shehadah claimed credit for an attack on a house formerly occupied by a German GSG-9 officer in Solingen, Germany.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/01/1993: Suspected Muslim militants of the Moro National Liberation Front detonated a bomb at a Roman Catholic shrine in the city of Zamboanga, Philippines, injuring 13.
target1: Statue of Our Lady of Pilar Roman Catholic shrine
motive: To demand a halt to Philippine military operations in nearby Basilan island.
addnotes: Anggoling Sali, an MNLF commander, claimed responsibility over the radio.
scite1: “Troops hunt down Moslem guerillas after weekend bombings,” Agence France Presse, August 2, 1993.
scite2: “Blast At Catholic Shrine Injures 13,” The Associated Press, August 2, 1993.

summary: 08/01/1993: Separatist rebels assassinated both the military governor and regional commander in the Prigorodny District of Vladikavkaz, North Ossetia, killing 3 and injuring 3 others.
propcomment: Two vehicles, a Volga and UAZ, were riddled with bullets.
scite1: Liam McDowall, “Russian Brass Go to Caucasus after Horseback Slaying of Governor,” The Associated Press, August 2, 1993.
scite2: Nikolai Burbyga, Nikolai Gritchin and Aleksandra Lugovskaya, “Ingushetia and North Ossetia Blame Each Other for Murders of V. Polyanichko and A. Koretsky,” Izvestia, August 3, 1993.

summary: 08/02/1993: A Palestinian man carrying explosives hijacked a United Nations Relief and Works Agency (UNRWA) bus in the Gaza Strip, forced everyone off, then drove south, ramming the bus into oncoming vehicles carrying Israeli police and soldiers. One person was killed and 7 injured.
target1: Israeli Security Forces in Gaza City
weaptype1_txt: Vehicle (not to include vehicle-borne explosives, i.e., car or truck bombs)
propcomment: A bus and other vehicles were smashed.
addnotes: Islamic Jihad claimed responsibility through loudspeakers on the streets.
scite1: “Arab bus hijacker kills one Israeli, injures seven,” Agence France Presse, August 2, 1993.
scite2: “Israel’s war on Hezbollah spurs Islamic Jihad into action,” Agence France Presse, August 5, 1993.

summary: 08/03/1993: A bomb ripped through the ground floor of the Punjab Advocate in the Lahore High Court building in Pakistan, injuring 4.
propcomment: The ground floor of the building was blasted.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 199308030002, 199308030003).
scite1: “Ten injured in two bomb blasts in Pakistan,” Xinhua General News Service, August 3, 1993.
scite2: “Three blasts rock major Pakistan city amid election campaign,” Agence France Presse, August 3, 1993.

summary: 08/03/1993: A bomb exploded at a cycle stand outside the Pakistan Railway headquarters, injuring 3.
propcomment: About a dozen two-wheelers parked out in front of the headquarters were damaged.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 199308030001, 199308030003).
scite1: “Ten injured in two bomb blasts in Pakistan,” Xinhua General News Service, August 3, 1993.
scite2: “Three blasts rock major Pakistan city amid election campaign,” Agence France Presse, August 3, 1993.

summary: 08/03/1993: A bomb exploded at a Paramilitary Rangers' headquarters in Lahore, Pakistan. No one was killed or injured.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 199308030001, 199308030002).
scite1: “Ten injured in two bomb blasts in Pakistan,” Xinhua General News Service, August 3, 1993.
scite2: “Three blasts rock major Pakistan city amid election campaign,” Agence France Presse, August 3, 1993.

summary: 08/03/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) attempted to detonate a 1,000lb bomb at a British army checkpoint on the Carrickananny Road. The explosives were attached to the back of a remote-controlled tractor with a straw-filled dummy inside, but as the tractor approached, the vehicle veered into a ditch 125 yards from the checkpoint. No one was killed or injured.
scite1: Gerry Moriarty, “IRA tractor bomb attack fails,” The Irish Times, August 6, 1993.
scite2: Paul Cheston, “IRA dummy driver used in bomb attack,” The Evening Standard (London), August 5, 1993.

summary: 08/04/1993: Suspected National Liberation Army (ELN) militants exploded dynamite at an oil pipeline in Remedios (200 km northwest of Santa Fe de Bogota), which resulted in a 3,000-barrel oil spill. No one was killed or injured.
motive: The group believes that oil exploration by foreign companies violates national sovereignty.
addnotes: The spill caused severe ecological damage in surrounding creeks and fields.
scite1: “Government says guerilla attack causes 3,000-barrel oil spill,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, August 7, 1993.

summary: 08/04/1993: Unknown arsonists set fire to a Turkish restaurant in Pulheim, Germany. Three people were injured and the building was destroyed in this attack.
propcomment: The building was completely destroyed and swastikas were painted at the scene.
addnotes: One person suffered from smoke poisoning and two others sustained shock.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: This incident occurred on the road between Ramallah and Jerusalem.
summary: 08/05/1993: Three Palestinians kidnapped Yaron Chen, an Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) soldier, while he was hitchhiking. Chen was picked up in a van, which was found three hours later near the West Bank village of Beituniya, burning and with Chen's body inside. The perpetrators fled the scene.
target1: Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) soldier, Yaron Chen
propcomment: Burned van
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: This incident occurred near Beli Dogle.
summary: 08/05/1993: Somali snipers fired automatic weapons and an RPG on a U.S. supply convoy near Beli Dogle, Somalia. Two American soldiers were injured in the attack.
addnotes: Moroccan troops guarding the convoy of United States logistical support soldiers returned fire.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/06/1993: Masked men claiming to be from the Irish Republican Army (IRA) held a family hostage and stole their vehicle for use in a car bomb attack later the same night. No one was reportedly killed or injured.
motive: At least partial motivation seems to be to steal the family's vehicle for use in a car bomb attack.
scite1: Ian Graham, “Army Defuses Belfast Car Bomb,” Press Association, August 6, 1993.

summary: 08/06/1993: Police defused a 100lb Irish republican Army (IRA) car bomb packed into a five gallon drum in the back of the vehicle. Earlier, the suspects held a family hostage and stole their vehicle for use in the bomb attack. No one was killed or injured.
weapdetail: A 100lb IRA car bomb packed into a five gallon drum in the back of a vehicle
scite1: Ian Graham, “Army Defuses Belfast Car Bomb,” Press Association, August 6, 1993.

location: A military base near Deir Ballut
summary: 08/06/1993: Three suspected members of HAMAS fired on soldiers guarding the entrance to a military base near Deir Ballut, Israel. In the ensuing gunfight, two soldiers and one perpetrator were killed and one perpetrator was injured.
target1: Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) soldier, Lev Pishol
target2: Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) soldier, Tomer David
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/06/1993: Six mortars were fired by unknown perpetrators at the U.S. Embassy in Mogadishu, Somalia, killing one U.S. soldier and causing some damage.
propcomment: Shrapnel went through one building and into the window of another room.
addnotes: First Lieutenant Robert Mon, 25 years old, of Fort Drum, New York, was killed in the attack.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/07/1993: Muslim militants gunned down the Deputy Chief of Police, along with his driver and bodyguard when the gunmen opened fire on their vehicle in the city of Nag Hammadi, 460 kilometers south of Cairo.
motive: Revenge for the execution of 15 Muslim fundamentalists by Egyptian authorities.
propcomment: Vehicle was riddled with bullets
addnotes: The London office of Al-Hayat received a statement by Jemaah Islamiyah claiming responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Egyptian militants gun down police general,” Mideast Mirror, August 9, 1993.
scite2: “Mass trial of fundamentalists postponed,” Agence France Presse, August 9, 1993.

location: This incident occurred near Beli Dogle.
summary: 08/06/1993: Five Somali gunmen were killed and 15 captured when they attempted to ambush a Joint U.S.-French UN convoy with RPGs and automatic weapons near Bali Dogle, Somalia. Two U.S. soldiers were wounded in the one-hour attack, including Sgt. Jennifer Alloway.
target1: United Nations convoy of 30 United States and French military vehicles
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/07/1993: Euskadi ta Askatasuna (ETA) claimed responsibility for two bombs set off the Doblemar Hotel in La Manga del Mar Menor in Murcia, Spain. One of the bombs was planted in the back of an armchair, which a few days later had been taken out of a first-floor room and placed next to the elevator. A German tourist was injured and an Italian woman suffered a slightly injured ear. The ETA warned of the bomb in a call to the hotel receptionist.
addnotes: Eight-hundred hotel guests were evacuated.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/08/1993: The son of a prominent Sinn Fein City Council member was shot dead when gunmen opened fire on the family's home in Belfast. The gunmen drove by the house slowly and fired approximately 25 to 30 shots through the window before driving off.
target1: Bobby Lavery (Sinn Fein City Council member)
propcomment: The house was riddled with bullets and windows were shattered.
addnotes: Bobby Lavery's family was also targeted and his son, Sean Lavery, was shot dead. This was the second attack targeting Lavery.
scite1: “Sinn Fein councillor's son shot dead,” The Herald (Glasgow), August 9, 1993.
scite2: “Son of City Council member shot dead in Northern Ireland,” United Press International, August 9, 1993.

summary: 08/08/1993: At 4 a.m., unidentified gunmen in three cars opened fire on the ninth floor of the government building where Chechen President Dzhokhar Dudayev's office is located, injuring 2 of Dudayev's bodyguards. The gunmen also fired at the nearby Chechen Interior Ministry building.
scite1: “ITAR-TASS News Digest of August 9,” ITAR-TASS, August 9, 1993.
scite2: “Attempt to assassinate Chechen President Dudayev failed,” Komsomolskaya Pravda, August 10, 1993.

summary: 08/08/1993: The regional office headquarters of radical Hindu group, Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (RSS), was destroyed by a powerful "suitcase" bomb in southern India. The bomb, planted in the heart of the two-story RSS building, killed 11 people and seven other people were injured.
propcomment: The entire 2-story building was destroyed.
addnotes: Rashtriya Swayamsevak Sangh (National Volunteer Corps), RSS, is a radical Hindu revivalist organization that claims to have more than 1 million members. Although officially the group proclaims to be non-political, many of its members are activists and leaders in India's main opposition group, the right-wing Bharatiya Janata Party (Indian People's Party), or BJP. Muslim extremists recently threatened to blow-up RSS and BJP facilities.
scite1: “Police find another body in rubble of bombed Hindu headquarters,” United Press International, August 9, 1993.
scite2: “India jails Muslim cleric after bombing of Hindu headquarters,” United Press International, August 10, 1993.

location: This incident occurred on a road near Mogadishu.
summary: 08/08/1993: Near Mogadishu, Somalia, a landmine was detonated under a U.S. Army Humvee by the Islamic Salvation Movement, a previously unknown Somali militant group, killing four soldiers. Snipers then fired on the convoy.
propcomment: Two U.S. Army Humvees were destroyed.
addnotes: On August 11th, the previously unknown Somali Islamic Salvation Movement claimed responsibility for the incident in a press conference at a Mogadishu hotel used by the foreign press corps. The Movement blamed the U.S. for arbitrary killings and neocolonialism. The fatalities were: Spec. Gutting, 25 years old, Grand Rapids, MI; Spec. Keith Pearson, 25 years old, Tavares, FL (both from the 977th Military Police Co. from Ft. Riley, KS); Sgt. Ronald Richerson, 24, Portage, IN (300th Military Police Co. from Ft. Leonard Wood, MO); Sgt. Christopher Hilgert, 27, Blomington, IN (Ft. Riley).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/09/1993: Suspected Islamist militants shot dead a police intelligence officer outside his house in Aswan, 690 kilometers (440 miles) south of Cairo.
target1: Abdel-Hamid Gad el-Rab Rizk (Police intelligence officer)
motive: Possibly in retaliation for the recent execution of 15 Muslim militants by Egyptian authorities.
addnotes: This is the third attack against police in Egypt this week.
scite1: “Policeman shot dead in Upper Egypt,” Mideast Mirror, August 10, 1993.
scite2: “Suspected Extremists Strike Police in Third Fatal Attack,” The Associated Press, August 10, 1993.

summary: 08/09/1993: Muslim extremists killed a police guard in an attempt to storm a building housing police officers in the Egyptian city of Qussiya, 350 kilometers (217 miles) south of Cairo.
target1: Building housing police officers in Qussiya
motive: Possibly in retaliation for the recent execution of 15 Muslim militants by Egyptian authorities.
addnotes: A guard, Mohammad Rashwan, was killed in the attack.
scite1: “Fundamentalists kill policeman in Upper Egypt,” Agence France Presse, August 9, 1993.
scite2: “Another policeman gunned down by suspected militants in Egypt,” United Press International, August 10, 1993.

summary: 08/09/1993: Khmer Rouge guerrillas massacred six Vietnamese civilians in their home near Tonle Sap, Cambodia.
addnotes: The six victims were a 63-year-old man and a 17-year-old boy from one family, along with a 72-year-old man, a 15-year-old boy, a 13-year-old girl, and a 36-year-old woman from a second family.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/10/1993: A member of Sinn Fein was wounded upon opening a letter bomb, which was disguised in a brown paper parcel. The letter bomb was delivered to his home in the city of Hilltown, 60 kilometers (40 miles) south of Belfast.
weapdetail: The letter bomb was disguised as a brown paper parcel.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199308100003). The aunt of the targeted Irish nationalist also received a letter bomb the same day. The victim received injuries to the chest and leg.
scite1: “Letter bombs wound two in Northern Ireland,” United Press International, August 10, 1993.

summary: 08/10/1993: The aunt of a member of Sinn Fein was wounded when she received a letter bomb, which exploded in her home in the city of Hilltown, 60 kilometers (40 miles) south of Belfast.
target1: Aunt of a member of Sinn Fein
weapdetail: The letter bomb was disguised as a brown paper parcel.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199308100002). The victim's nephew also received a letter bomb the same day. The victim suffered eye and arm injuries.
scite1: “Letter bombs wound two in Northern Ireland,” United Press International, August 10, 1993.

summary: 08/10/1993: A Chinese passenger onboard an Air China flight from Beijing threatened to pour acid over passengers unless the flight changed course to Taiwan. Air China Flight CA973 left Beijing at 09:51 (Beijing time) and was hijacked at 11:15 (Beijing time). At this time, the plane was diverted to Taiwan and landed at the Taipei international airport, where the lone hijacker exited. The crew with all its passengers (save for the hijacker) returned to Xiamen, China at 16:03 (Beijing time). No one was injured.
target1: Air China Flight CA-973 from Beijing to Jakarta via Xiamen
weapdetail: Acid
scite1: “Taiwan authorities asked to help prevent airliner hijackings,” The Xinhua General Overseas News Service, August 10, 1993.
scite2: “Hijacker, whose weapon was acid, gives himself up,” Seattle Post-Intelligencer, August 11, 1993.

summary: 08/10/1993: An unknown individual took Russian Consul General Andrey Kiselev hostage at the Russian Consulate in Tehran, Iran. The hostage-taker threatened to kill himself and the diplomat during negotiations if he was not given safe passage to the U.S., France, or Switzerland. Iranian authorities rescued the Kiselev and killed the perpetrator.
target1: Andrey Kiselev, Russian Consul General in Tehran
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/11/1993: A bomb, planted at the rear of a car carrying a Catholic couple and their 20-month-old daughter, exploded and sprayed shrapnel, injuring the parents. The bomb exploded at 7:40 a.m. as the family was traveling along Saintfield Road towards Belfast.
scite1: “Baby caught in car bomb blast,” The Herald (Glasgow), August 12, 1993.
scite2: Gerry Moriarty, “Couple injured in UDA bombing of car,” The Irish Times, August 12, 1993.

summary: 08/11/1993: A bomb exploded in a busy marketplace in the southern Georgian town of Marneuli, 19 miles outside the capital, Tbilisi. Twenty people were injured, though no one was killed by the blast.
addnotes: Marneuli has a large Azerbaijani population. The attack at the market may be connected to hostilities between Azerbaijan and Armenia over the Nagorno-Karabach enclave.
scite1: “Bomb kills four in busy Georgian market,” United Press International, August 11, 1993.
scite2: “Georgia blast,” The Evening Standard (London), August 11, 1993

summary: 08/11/1993: In a series of linked incidents, Somali gunmen fired on United Nations Peacekeeping Forces in five separate locations in Mogadishu. In this case, the gunmen fired five mortar shells at a traffic circle where Pakistani UN troops were located.
target1: United Nations Peacekeepers at a traffic circle in Mogadishu
addnotes: This was one of five related attacks (cf. 199308110003-7).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/11/1993: In a series of linked incidents, Somali gunmen fired on United Nations Peacekeeping Forces in five separate locations in Mogadishu. In this case, two mortar shells exploded near the Mogadishu Airport, which was guarded by UN troops.
target1: United Nations Peacekeepers near the Mogadishu Airport
addnotes: This was one of five related attacks (cf. 199308110003-7).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/11/1993: In a series of linked incidents, Somali gunmen fired on United Nations Peacekeeping Forces in five separate locations in Mogadishu. In this case, a mortar shell fell near Mogadishu's port.
target1: United Nations Peacekeepers at October 21 Road in Mogadishu
addnotes: This was one of five related attacks (cf. 199308110003-7).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/11/1993: In a series of linked incidents, Somali gunmen fired on United Nations Peacekeeping Forces in five separate locations in Mogadishu. In this case, gunmen in a truck fired on two US helicopters. A United States Cobra helicopter returned fire against the gunmen, killing seven gunmen.
target1: United Nations Peacekeepers in two UN helicopters
addnotes: This was one of five related attacks (cf. 199308110003-7).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/11/1993: In a series of linked incidents, Somali gunmen fired on United Nations Peacekeeping Forces in five separate locations in Mogadishu. In this case, gunmen fired automatic rifles at Malaysian UN troops on 21 October Road and the Malaysians returned fire.
target1: United Nations Peacekeepers near the Port of Mogadishu
addnotes: This was one of five related attacks (cf. 199308110003-7).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/13/1993: A bomb exploded in front of the Government House on Independence Square in Minsk, though no one was reportedly killed or injured.
motive: To draw attention to the group's goal of restoration of the Soviet Union.
propcomment: The explosion left a 16-inch-deep crater and shattered windows in the metro office across from the government building.
addnotes: Belarus' Ministry of Internal Affairs reported that the left wing of an illegal Justice Party based in St. Petersburg claimed responsibility for the bombing.
scite1: Larisa Sayenko, “Terrorism in Belarus,” Moscow News, August 27, 1993.
scite2: 2. “Explosion Near Government Building in Belarus,” The Associated Press, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: Kurdish rebels, suspected to be from the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), shot and killed 5 villagers in Diyarbakir province for suspected collusion with the Turkish government.
motive: The villagers killed were suspected of collaboration with the Turkish government.
scite1: “Turkey intensifies pre-emptive attacks on Kurd rebels,” Chicago Tribune, August 15, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: A bomb exploded along the route of a planned march northwest of Belfast by Northern Ireland Protestants. No one was reportedly killed or injured.
target1: Parade route of Northern Ireland Protestants in Londonderry
addnotes: The parade celebrates the Protestant defense of Londonderry from the invading Roman Catholic King James in 1689. The bomb appeared timed to disrupt the march of 12,000 Apprentice Boys, a pro-British fraternal order loyal to the British crown. This was one of two related attacks committed by the IRA in Northern Ireland (cf. 199308140003)
scite1: “N Ireland – Bomb, 2nd Ld Cplte,” The Canadian Press, August 14, 1993.
scite2: “IRA admits planting bomb, injuring 9,” Herald Sun, August 16, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: The IRA planted a 112kg car bomb, which exploded outside a crowded restaurant in south Belfast, injuring 9 people.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks committed by the IRA in Northern Ireland (cf. 199308140002).
scite1: “Bomb outside restaurant hurts 9 in Belfast,” Times-Picayune (New Orleans), August 15, 1993.
scite2: “IRA admits planting bomb, injuring 9,” Herald Sun, August 16, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: A bomb planted by the IRA exploded at a pier at 4:33 a.m. in the seaside resort city of Bournemouth 105 miles southwest of London. No one was killed or injured.
propcomment: Bomb blew a hole in the woodwork
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199308140005, 199308140006, 199308140007, 199308140008, 199308140009). The IRA planted a total of 8 explosive devices in Bournemouth.
scite1: Peter Burden and Suzanne O’Shea, “IRA’s damp squib,” Daily Mail (London), August 14, 1993.
scite2: Chris Parkin and Paul Edwards, “We planted Bournemouth firebombs, say IRA,” Press Association, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: IRA planted a second bomb next to a pier in Bournemouth, which failed to explode. The bomb was discovered at 8:50 a.m. attached to one of the pier's iron girders directly beneath the theater.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199308140004, 199308140006, 199308140007, 199308140008, 199308140009). The IRA planted a total of 8 explosive devices in Bournemouth.
scite1: Peter Burden and Suzanne O’Shea, “IRA’s damp squib,” Daily Mail (London), August 14, 1993.
scite2: Chris Parkin and Paul Edwards, “We planted Bournemouth firebombs, say IRA,” Press Association, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: Two firebombs planted by the IRA exploded at 3:27 a.m. inside a 40,000 square foot department store in the seaside resort of Bournemouth, but fire doors allowed for minimal damage. No one was killed or injured.
weapdetail: Two firebombs
propcomment: The basement and ground floor were damaged. The other floors had little more than smoke damage.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199308140004, 199308140005, 199308140007, 199308140008, 199308140009). The IRA planted a total of 8 explosive devices in Bournemouth.
scite1: Peter Burden and Suzanne O’Shea, “IRA’s damp squib,” Daily Mail (London), August 14, 1993.
scite2: Chris Parkin and Paul Edwards, “We planted Bournemouth firebombs, say IRA,” Press Association, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: Two firebombs planted by the IRA exploded at 3:08 a.m. at a bookshop in the seaside resort of Bournemouth. No one was killed or injured in the attack.
weapdetail: Two firebombs
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199308140004, 199308140005, 199308140006, 199308140008, 199308140009). The IRA planted a total of 8 explosive devices in Bournemouth.
scite1: Peter Burden and Suzanne O’Shea, “IRA’s damp squib,” Daily Mail (London), August 14, 1993.
scite2: Chris Parkin and Paul Edwards, “We planted Bournemouth firebombs, say IRA,” Press Association, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: A firebomb planted by the IRA was found at a clothes shop in the seaside resort of Bournemouth. No one was killed or injured.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199308140004, 199308140005, 199308140006, 199308140007, 199308140009). The IRA planted a total of 8 explosive devices in Bournemouth.
scite1: Peter Burden and Suzanne O’Shea, “IRA’s damp squib,” Daily Mail (London), August 14, 1993.
scite2: Chris Parkin and Paul Edwards, “We planted Bournemouth firebombs, say IRA,” Press Association, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: A firebomb planted by the IRA exploded at 4:12 a.m. at a furniture shop in the seaside resort of Bournemouth. No one was killed or injured.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf. 199308140004, 199308140005, 199308140006, 199308140007, 199308140008).The IRA planted a total of 8 explosive devices in Bournemouth.
scite1: Peter Burden and Suzanne O’Shea, “IRA’s damp squib,” Daily Mail (London), August 14, 1993.
scite2: Chris Parkin and Paul Edwards, “We planted Bournemouth firebombs, say IRA,” Press Association, August 14, 1993.

summary: 08/14/1993: Militants massacred Hindu passengers on a bus in Kashmir amid celebrations of Pakistan's national day. Minutes into the drive from Kishtwar to Jammu, Muslim militants commandeered the bus, ordered all 20 Muslim passengers off, then drove the remaining Hindu passengers to a remote spot and shot them. Fourteen died instantly, and of the two passengers that were badly wounded, one later died in the hospital.
target1: Indian bus with Hindu passengers in Kishtwar
motive: Revenge for the killing of 4 militants in Kishtwar by security forces.
scite1: ““Gruesome and selective massacre” of Hindu bus passengers condemned in Kashmir,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, August 18, 1993.
scite2: “Kashmir on red alert as Moslem militants gun down 15 Hindus,” Agence France Presse, August 14, 1993.

location: KLM airplane en route from Tunis to Amsterdam
summary: 08/15/1993: An Egyptian man claiming to have a bomb hijacked a Dutch airliner traveling from Tunisia to Amsterdam and demanded the release of Sheik Omar Abdel-Rahman, who had been charged in the February bombing of the World Trade Center in New York. The hijacker released all 131 passengers and 7 crew members soon after the plane landed safely in Dusseldorf, Germany.
target1: KLM Boeing 737-400 flight from Tunis, Tunisia to Amsterdam, Netherlands
motive: Demand for the release of Sheik Omar Abdul-Rahman and the implementation of UN sanctions against Serbia.
scite1: Andreas Renhult, “Egyptian Seizes KLM Plane; Seek Sheik’s Freedom,” The Associated Press, August 15, 1993.
scite2: “Egyptian KLM hijacker advocate of Bosnian Moslem rights,” Agence France Presse, August 17, 1993.

location: The target was a tour ship traveling along the Nile River
summary: 08/16/1993: Shots were fired by suspected Muslim militants at an Egyptian tour ship 200 miles south of Cairo along the Nile River. The ship was carrying mostly British tourists. No one was injured.
addnotes: Three tourists had been killed and a dozen injured in political violence in the area over the last 18 months.
scite1: “Nile gunman opens fire on Britons,” Daily Mail (London), August 17, 1993.
scite2: Peter Bakogeorge, “Gunfire rattles Egypt’s tourist industry again,” The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec) (Montreal, Quebec), August 18, 1993.

location: The incident occurred along the banks of a river in Central Peru
summary: 08/18/1993: Shining Path guerillas massacred Ashaninka Indian communities situated along the banks of a river valley in the Amazon jungle in central Peru. Sixty-two were killed.
target1: Ashaninka Indian communities along the banks of the Amazon jungle
motive: To punish the natives for deserting the Shining Path's ranks.
weapdetail: Spears, machetes and axes
scite1: “Indians massacred in Peru; Maoist rebels kill up to 62, injure 34,” Seattle Post-Intelligencer, August 21, 1993.
scite2: “Shining Path attack raises questions about pacification program,” Agence France Presse, August 20, 1993.
scite3: “Suspects in massacre seized,” The Herald (Glasgow), August 30, 1993.

summary: 08/18/1993: Two men on motorcycles, members of the revolutionary Talaeh al-Fatah (Vanguard of the Conquest), detonated an explosive device as the Egyptian Interior Minister's motorcade drove by Tahrir Square in Cairo, killing 7 people and injuring 16.
addnotes: The revolutionary group Talaeh al-Fatah (Vanguard of the Conquest) claimed responsibility for the attack by fax. The two would-be assassins were members of the group.
scite1: “Bombers were members of Islamic fundamentalist group,” Agence France Presse, August 21, 1993.
scite2: “Egypt – Aftermath of attack on minister; Interior Ministry statement naming second dead suspect in attack on minister,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, August 21, 1993.
scite3: “Bomb Targeted at Minister Kills Five,” Facts on File World News Digest, August 26, 1993.

summary: 08/18/1993: A car bomb exploded at 1:30 p.m. in a shopping mall parking garage in Caracas. No one was injured.
target1: Shopping mall parking garage in Caracas
motive: An effort by paramilitary forces to provoke a government military response and destabilize Venezuela.
propcomment: The blast destroyed 5 cars and damaged 18 others
scite1: “Bomb blast shakes Caracas shopping mall,” Agence France Presse, August 18, 1993.
scite2: Alberto Garnica, “Venezuelan politicians fear conspiracy in car bombs,” United Press International, August 19, 1993.
scite3: “Car bomb provocation,” Pittsburgh Post-The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec), August 20, 1993.

summary: 08/18/1993: A bomb exploded at 4:30 p.m. (local time) behind a double-decker bus parked in front of Hotel Tanim in Istanbul. Eight people were injured.
propcomment: The blast broke the bus' rear window and caused minor damage to the rear frame.
addnotes: PKK Kurdish rebels are suspected of carrying out the attack. The blast injured 4 Turks, 3 Hungarians and an Azerbaijani.
scite1: Jonathan Rugman, “Bomb in Istanbul injures eight,” The Guardian (London), August 19, 1993.
scite2: “Bomb Injures Three Hungarians in Istanbul,” MTI Econews, August 18, 1993.

summary: 08/19/1993: Former "Contra" rebels kidnapped three members of parliament and two senior officers in Caulata, 200 km north of Managua. No one was killed or injured.
motive: To demand the removal of General Humberto Ortega, the Sandinista defense minister.
addnotes: FSLN parliamentarian Doris Tijerino, as well as Major Ivan Portocarrero and 12 other officers of the Special Disarmament Brigade were also targeted. Former Nicaraguan Resistance (RN), or 'Contra," rebels conducted the kidnapping operation.
scite1: “Nicaragua: Former “Contra” rebels kidnap parliamentarians,” IPS-Inter Press Service, August 19, 1993.
scite2: Tracy Wilkinson, “Nicaragua’s dual hostage dramas near peaceful resolution; Central America: Rearmed Contras free last five captives, and Sandinista gunmen vow to do the same,” Los Angeles Times, August 26, 1993.

summary: 08/19/1993: A hand grenade was thrown into a café in Turkey, killing one and injuring seven.
scite1: “Security reports from eastern and south-eastern Turkey,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, August 25, 1993.

summary: 08/19/1993: Seven tourists -- two Germans, two Italians, two Swiss nationals and a New Zealander -- were kidnapped in eastern Turkey on August 19 by hardliners from the main Kurdish rebel party, the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). They were released on 09/14/1993.
target1: Tourists from Germany (2), Italy (2), Switzerland (2) and New Zealand (1)
scite1: “Kurdish rebels release foreign tourists: reports," Agence France Presse, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Kurdish rebels release foreign tourist: ministries," Agence France Presse, September 14, 1993
scite3: “Seven captured tourists freed in Turkey," Agence France Presse, September 14, 1993.

summary: 08/19/1993: Four United Nations soldiers were slightly injured when their truck hit a remote controlled land mine in Mogadishu, Somalia. The perpetrators in this incident were unknown.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/19/1993: An assailant opened fire on Dr. George Tiller outside an abortion clinic in Wichita, Kansas, United States. Dr. Tiller, an abortion doctor, was injured in both arms. An anti-abortion extremist, identified as Rachelle "Shelley" Shannon, was convicted for carrying out the attack.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in Kansas.
weapdetail: A .32-caliber gun was used in the attack.
addnotes: Shannon was also convicted for carrying out several firebomb attacks on abortion clinics in Caliornia, Nevada, and Oregon in 1992.
scite1: Ronald J. Ostrow and James Risen, "U.S. to Act in 10 Abortion Clinic Attacks : Indictments: Charges are expected against an extremist in prison for attempted murder. Authorities hope action will lead to names of others," Los Angeles Times, October 23, 1994.
scite2: Dirk Johnson, "Abortions, Bibles and Bullets, And the Making of a Militant," The New York Times, August 28, 1993.
scite3: Harriet Ryan, "Kopp fifth clinic shooter to face trial," Court TV, March 11, 2003.

summary: 08/20/1993: Palestinians killed an Israeli private security guard in the West Bank.
scite1: Jon Immanuel, “IDF faults company in guard’s killing; Police: Russian immigrant victim of terror attack,” The Jerusalem Post, August 23, 1993.
scite2: Jonathan Ferziger, “Palestinians kill Israeli guard in West Bank,” United Press International, August 22, 1993.

summary: 08/20/1993: The IRA claimed responsibility for firing three mortars at courthouse in Northern Ireland, injuring 10 people.
propcomment: The blast shattered windows in several buildings, as well as damaged a courthouse wall and several cars.
scite1: Ian Graham, “IRA mortar attack injures 10,” Press Association, August 20, 1993.
scite2: 2. “IRA admits bombings,” Sunday Mail (SA), August 22, 1993.

summary: 08/20/1993: Pro-Sandinista gunmen seized the vice president and other opposition leaders and vowed to hold them hostage until former "Contra" rebels released government and security personnel, which were kidnapped the previous day. No one was killed or injured.
motive: In retaliation for the kidnapping of pro-Sandinista government and security personnel
addnotes: Other opposition leaders, including Alfredo Cesar, were also targeted.
scite1: Eloy O. Aguilar, “Pro-Sandinista Gunmen Seize Hostages in Reprisal for Contra Abductions,” The Associated Press, August 21, 1993.
scite2: Tracy Wilkinson, “Nicaragua’s dual hostage dramas near peaceful resolution; Central America: Rearmed Contras free last five captives, and Sandinista gunmen vow to do the same,” Los Angeles Times, August 26, 1993.

summary: 08/21/1993: Muslim fundamentalists ambushed and killed former Algerian Prime Minister Kasdi Merbah along with four others in the Algerian city of Bordj el-Bahri.
scite1: Cynthia Hanson, “Algerian Militants Kill Former Prime Minister,” Christian Science Monitor, August 23, 1993.
scite2: “Former Algerian PM shot dead,” Financial Times, August 23, 1993.

summary: 08/21/1993: Two British and two Afghani tourists were kidnapped in Kozluk by members of the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK). The victims escaped during a rescue operation on August 23, 1993.
addnotes: The victims were: Anna Young, Michael Paterson (UK); Haci Muhammad Yusufi, Abdulkadir Yusufi (Afghanistan).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/21/1993: Members of the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) kidnapped seven tourists in the Agri Mountains of Turkey at gunpoint. The victims were released on September 15, 1993.
addnotes: The victims of this kidnapping were the following: Angelo Palego, Anna D'Andrea (Italian); Anna di Nico Pianta (Swiss); Henry Butler, Christoph Lehmann (German); Paul Thompson (New Zealand).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/22/1993: Muslim separatists ambushed a train in Thailand just 40 kilometers (25 miles) from the Malaysian border. An unidentified number of gunmen from the Pattani United Liberation Organisation (PULO) opened fire on the train and planted two bombs, which failed to explode due to a malfunction. One person was killed and eight injured.
target1: Train line linking Bangkok with to Malaysia and Singapore
motive: To demand a separate independent state in Thailand's southern Pattani province.
weapdetail: Two bombs were planted, but failed to detonate due to malfunction.
scite1: “Police say Moslem separatists responsible for train attack in south,” Agence France Presse, August 22, 1993.
scite2: “Muslim separatists ambush train on Thai-Malaysian border; one killed,” BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, August 24, 1993.

summary: 08/22/1993: In Mogadishu, Somalia, six U.S. soldiers were injured when a remote controlled landmine destroyed their truck. The unknown perpetrators then used mortars, grenades and firearms to attack the rest of the 22-vehicle convoy.
weapdetail: Remote-controlled land mine
propcomment: The truck in which the victims were riding was destroyed.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/23/1993: An unidentified gunman opened fire at a workers' hostel in Johannesburg, killing 12 and injuring 20.
scite1: Keith B. Richburg and Phillip van Niekerk, “Gunman Kills 12 Blacks in S. Africa,” The Washington Post, August 23, 1993.

summary: 08/23/1993: A bomb planted by the IRA exploded outside a branch of the Northern Bank in south Belfast. No injuries were reported.
propcomment: The blast caused extensive damage to the wall of the bank and shattered windows in several nearby buildings.
scite1: “Policeman wounded, bank bombed in separate attacks,” United Press International, August 24, 1993.
scite2: Suzanne Breen, “Bomb alert inadequate, says RUC,” The Irish Times, August 25, 1993.

summary: 08/23/1993: Unidentified militants in a passing red Fiat hurled a bomb into the stolen vehicle division of a police station in east-central Caracas. No one was injured.
motive: Possibly to destroy evidence pertaining to a car bomb that exploded in a shopping mall parking garage the previous week.
propcomment: The interior of the police station was severely damaged; most of the stolen vehicle archives were destroyed.
scite1: “Bomb thrown into police building causes damage,” Agence France Presse, August 24, 1993.
scite2: “Venezuela: Tensions increase after police station bomb,” IPS-Inter Press Service, August 24, 1993.
scite3: Alberto Garnica, “Former Venezuelan president rejects bomb accusations,” United Press International, August 24, 1993.

summary: 08/24/1993: A police officer was injured when terrorists in a hijacked car opened fire on a checkpoint outside a police station in Belfast before speeding away from the scene.
addnotes: The gunmen's stolen vehicle was later found ablaze in the predominantly Catholic Lower Falls area of the city.
scite1: “Policeman wounded in gun attack,” Press Association, August 24, 1993.
scite2: “Policeman wounded, bank bombed in separate attacks,” United Press International, August 24, 1993.

summary: 08/25/1993: A pipe bomb left by the Red Hand Commandos inside a pub in Northern Ireland was defused by security forces.
weapdetail: Pipe bomb
addnotes: The outlawed loyalist paramilitary group Red Hand Commandos claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: Ian Graham, “Army Defuses Ulster Pub Bomb,” Press Association, August 26, 1993.
scite2: Dick Grogan, “UDA warns civil servants but folk fans get reprieve,” The Irish Times, August 28, 1993.

summary: 08/25/1993: Separatist tribal militants attacked soldiers and civilians in Manipur's capital city of Imphal, killing six and injuring seven others.
addnotes: The most active separatist tribal group in the region in the National Socialist Council of Nagaland.
scite1: “Six killed in terrorist strike in eastern India,” Agence France Presse, August 25, 1993.

summary: 08/25/1993: Four unknown perpetrators dressed as Turkish Security Officers kidnapped Iranian dissident, Mohammad Khaderi from his home in Turkey. Khaderi was found on September 4, 1993.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/25/1993: Six German tourists and their Turkish guide were injured when an unknown assailant threw a Molotov cocktail at their group in Istanbul, Turkey.
addnotes: The German victims were identified as Zilheim Plitt, Ludwig (no other name given), Wilhelm Peter, Margaret Alaska, Ute Hanse, and Ann Christine and the Turkish guide was Gursel Torba.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: In this incident the target, UN trucks, were on their way to Cambambo and Cabal.
summary: 08/26/1993: Unknown men attacked a 75-truck World Food Programme convoy in a government controlled area in Huambo Province, Angola. One person was killed another wounded and the trucks and their cargo were destroyed.
target1: World Food Programme convoy of 75 trucks and 1,970 tons of foodstuffs
propcomment: Three trucks and their cargo were destroyed.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/27/1993: Gunmen in South Africa opened fire on a luxury double-decker bus carrying predominantly white passengers, in an attack that may be racially motivated. The attack took place 280 kilometers northeast of Cape Town. Eight passengers were injured.
target1: Luxury double-decker bus in Beaufort West
scite1: Tom Cohen, “Gunmen Wound Eight in Bus Attack,” The Associated Press, August 27, 1993.
scite2: Peter Younghusband, “Eight are shot in desert bus attack,” Daily Mail (London), August 28, 1993.

location: This incident occurred near Golahun village.
summary: 08/27/1993: United Revolutionary Front gunmen killed two nurses from the International Committee of the Red Cross and wounded another while traveling in a convoy near Golahun village in Sierra Leone. The gunmen kidnapped the truck drivers and destroyed their vehicles. The perpetrators also kidnapped the convoy's two Gambian drivers.
corp1: International Committee of the Red Cross
target1: An Red Cross two-truck aid convoy
propcomment: The trucks were burned.
addnotes: The Red Cross victims were: Susanne Buser, 36, a Swiss citizen, and Sarah Leomy, 36, of Sierra Leone were killed. Bernadette Peterhans, a Swiss nurse, was wounded in the arm. The fate of the kidnapped Gambian drivers was unknown. The International Committee of the Red Cross suspended its operations in the area after this incident.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/28/1993: IRA planted a pocket-sized bomb inside London's "security ring." The device was planted behind a billboard in Wormwood Street in Bishopsgate. No one was injured.
scite1: Michael Smith, “City security tighter after bomb find,” Financial Times, August 31, 1993.
scite2: Peter Rose, “Police expected IRA’s semtex ‘calling card,’” Daily Mail (London), August 30, 1993.

summary: 08/28/1993: Iranian dissident, Behram Azadfer, was assassinated by unknown perpetrators in Ankara, Turkey.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 08/29/1993: In Sri Lanka, Tamil Tigers carried out a suicide attack on a navy gunboat near Point Pedro, killing 15 navy personnel.
target1: Israeli-built Dovra-class navy gunboat in Colombo
scite1: “Tigers claim navy gunboat sunk in suicide attack,” Agence France Presse, August 30, 1993.
scite2: “Tigers sink Israeli-built gunboat, Sri Lanka violence escalates,” Agence France Presse, August 29, 1993.

summary: 08/30/1993: Forty to fifty unidentified gunmen set fire to a shoe factory in Algiers after ordering the workers to their knees at gunpoint. No one was reportedly killed or injured.
addnotes: The factory employed 430 people. It was unclear whether the attack was connected to recent Islamic extremist violence.
scite1: “Gunmen Destroy Shoe Factory,” The Associated Press, August 30, 1993.

location: This incident occurred on a road on the outskirts of San Ramon.
summary: 08/31/1993: Forty former soldiers of the previous Sandinista government kidnapped 200 civilians and seized 20 vehicles en route to San Ramon village, Nicaragua. The rebels demanded to talk to the Organization of American States (OAS) monitors of the Nicaraguan truce accord and to the government's Special Disarmament Brigades. During a rescue operation on September 1, 1993, three rebels were killed and the kidnap victims were released.
target1: 200 civilians in 20 vehicles en route to San Ramon village
motive: The perpetrators wanted to discuss the truce accord with OAS members.
addnotes: Government troops staged a pre-dawn raid on September 1st, killing three rebels and freeing the hostages. Many other rebels escaped.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 09/02/1993: In Colombia, the leftist guerrilla campaign called "Black September," waged by the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and the National Liberation Army (ELN), left 38 soldiers dead in a display of force aimed at bringing the Colombian government back to the negotiating table. The total number of injuries was unknown.
addnotes: Rebels announced the "Black September" terrorist offensive, saying they planned to kidnap public figures, attack the military and police and sabotage the country's infrastructure. (This one of two related attacks [cf: 199309020003]).
scite1: “‘Black September’ Rebel Offensive Leaves 30 Security Forces Dead," Agence France Presse, September 3, 1993.
scite2: “Police Blame Guerrillas For Bombings and Kidnapping," Inter-Press Service, September 6, 1993.
scite3: “Security Stepped Up in Colombia Against Rebel Offensive," Agence France Presse, September 9, 1993.

summary: 09/02/1993: In Colombia, a total of 33 soldiers and policemen were killed in ambushes when the Revolutionary Armed Forces of Colombia (FARC) and the National Liberation Army (ELN) launched their "Black September" offensive. The total number of injuries was unknown.
addnotes: FARC leadership reportedly decided to step up its attacks to pressure the government in the run-up to general elections. (This one of two related attacks [cf: 19930902000]).
scite1: “‘Black September’ Rebel Offensive Leaves 30 Security Forces Dead," Agence France Presse, September 3, 1993.
scite2: “Police Blame Guerrillas For Bombings and Kidnapping," Inter-Press Service, September 6, 1993.
scite3: “Security Stepped Up in Colombia Against Rebel Offensive," Agence France Presse, September 9, 1993.

summary: 09/03/1993: In Israel, an Israeli Defence Forces (IDF) soldier was killed and another injured when their vehicle was shot at by HAMAS gunmen waiting in a car on a roadside in the Hebron area. No other injuries or fatalities were reported.
target1: Military Jeep carrying 2 IDF soldiers (Sgt. Zion Elkobi killed)
propcomment: The military jeep flipped off of the road after the driver was killed in the attack.
scite1: “Killing of IDF Soldier Near Hebron Will ‘Not Affect Peace Process,'" BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 4, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen Kill IDF Soldier in Ambush Near Hebron," The Jerusalem Post, September 3, 1993.
scite3: “Palestinian Gunmen Kill Israeli Soldier," United Press International, September 3, 1993.

summary: 09/03/1993: Prison Officer Jim Peacock was shot in his home by the Ulster Volunteer Force in Belfast, Northern Ireland. No one was injured in the attack.
scite1: “Dismay at Warder’s Killing," The Guardian (London), September 3, 1993.
scite2: “Plea to End Loyalist Killing Spate," The Herald, September 2, 1993.
scite3: “UVF Threatens More Killing After Prison Officer Dies,” The Herald, September 3, 1993.

summary: 09/03/1993: In Bombay, India, a powerful firecracker exploded inside a toilet in the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) building, causing no damage or injuries but triggering a panic. The perpetrator group was unknown.
target1: Restroom facility in the Bombay Stock Exchange
scite1: “Bomb Explodes at Bombay Stock Exchange," United Press International, September 3, 1993.
scite2: “Firecracker in Loo Flushes out Bombay Brokers," Agence France Presse, September 3, 1993.

summary: 09/03/1993: Three members of the Red Brigades (BR) attacked the United States-NATO Air Force Base. According to reports, seven shots and a hand grenade caused slight damage to the sleeping quarters at the base. No one was injured in the incident.
target1: United States - NATO Air Force Base
propcomment: Windows were shattered on the base, but no major damage was reported.
addnotes: Combination attack included explosive-hand grenade and shooting.
scite1: “U.S. Base in Italy Fired Upon," Chicago Tribune, September 4, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen Fire at Building Tied to NATO Base," Agence France Presse, September 3, 1993.
scite3: Nation/World Briefings, Chicago Sun-Times, September 3, 1993.

summary: 09/04/1993: Two South Lebanon Army soldiers were slightly wounded when a mine exploded in the Jezzine region of Lebanon, north of the security zone, amid an escalation of Hizballah attacks. The number of injured was unknown.
scite1: “Two SLA Soldiers Wounded in Mine Blast," The Jerusalem Post, September 5, 1993

summary: 09/06/1993: A militiaman of the South Lebanon Army was wounded in a roadside bomb explosion in southern Lebanon. No other injuries or fatalities were reported.
scite1: “SLA Man Wounded in Bomb Blast," The Jerusalem Post, September 7, 1993.
scite2: “Israeli-Allied Militiaman Wounded in Roadside Bomb Blast," The Associated Press, September 6, 1993.
scite3: “Explosive charge wounds SLA militiaman," United Press International, September 6, 1993.

summary: 09/06/1993: Unknown assailants shot dead Abdul Wahid Khilji, an influential leader of Awami National Party, a Pakistani left-leaning party, and injured two others. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
addnotes: Khilji's younger brother and another guest who were sitting with him on the lawns of the house were critically wounded.
scite1: “Pakistani Leftist Party Leader Shot Dead," Agence France Presse, September 6, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen Kill Leftist Political Leader in Pakistan," The Associated Press, September 6, 1993.
scite3: “Quetta city Awami National Party President Assassinated," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 7, 1993.

summary: 09/07/1993: Loyalist gunmen in Belfast shot dead a Catholic hairdresser in his salon. The Ulster Defence Association claimed responsibility for the killing. No one was injured in the attack.
addnotes: Mr. Hughes was the third shop-owner murdered by loyalists in the same area during the past two years.
scite1: “Loyalist Gun Gang Murder Fifth Victim," Daily Mail (London), September 8, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen Claim Fifth Victim Since Monday," The Independent (London), September 8, 1993.
scite3: “Concern grows as another Catholic is killed - Loyalist gunmen claim fifth victim in a week of murder," The Irish Times, September 08, 1993.

summary: 09/08/1993: Unidentified gunmen killed at least 19 and wounded 22 as the victims waited to catch taxis near Johannesburg in Wadeville, South Africa. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
addnotes: Taxi vans were a major mode of transport for blacks, and attacks on black commuters were part of the political violence which killed thousands of blacks and hindered reforms.
scite1: “Gunmen Kill 19 Blacks in Taxi Queue," The Herald, September 9, 1993.
scite2: “More Troops Deployed in East Johannesburg Townships to Curb Violence," Xinhua General News Service, September 9, 1993.
scite3: “27 People Killed Today in Johannesburg," Xinhua General News Service, September 8, 1993.

summary: 09/08/1993: Four marchers were killed and seven people wounded, including a U.N. soldier, when an anti-personnel mine exploded near the northern Croatian town of Pakrac. There was no claim of responsibility for the attack.
addnotes: The UNPROFOR spokesman said that organizers of the ceremony had not heeded warnings from U.N. soldiers in the sector that the sector might be mined.
scite1: “Four marchers killed by mine in Croatia," Agence France Presse, September 8, 1993.
scite2: “Four marchers killed by mine in Croatia: UNPROFOR," Agence France Presse, September 8, 1993.
scite3: “Croatian Premier Says U.N. Partly to Blame for Fatal Blast," Press Association, September 8, 1993.

summary: 09/09/1993: A bomb exploded in the new Guatemala City headquarters of the Mutual Support Group (GAM), an anti-corruption activist group that was seeking the mass resignation of the entire Guatemalan Congress. No one was injured in the attack and no group claimed responsibility.
target1: Mutual Support Group (GAM) headquarters in Guatemala City
propcomment: The blast caused serious damage to the group's office and minor damage to small shops nearby.
addnotes: The GAM is one of many social organizations that joined new Guatemalan President Ramiro De Leon Carpio in calling for the resignations of all legislators in an effort to purge corrupt members.
scite1: “Human Rights Office Bombed in Wave of Terrorism," Inter-Press Service, September 11, 1993.
scite2: “Bomb explodes in new Guatemalan office of rights activists," United Press International, September 10, 1993.

summary: 09/09/1993: In one of three attacks, a bomb was set off at a McDonald's in Santiago, Chile. A man claiming to be a member of the Revolutionary Left (MIR) claimed credit for the incident. There were no reports of damage or injuries.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (c.f. 199309090002-4).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 09/09/1993: In one of three attacks, a terrorist bomb was successfully disarmed at a Kentucky Fried Chicken Restaurant in Santiago, Chile. A man claiming to be a member of the Revolutionary Left (MIR) claimed credit for the incident. There were no reports of damage or injuries.
target1: A Kentucky Fried Chicken restaurant in Santiago
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (c.f. 199309090002-4).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 09/09/1993: In one of three attacks, a  bomb was set off at a second McDonald's in Santiago, Chile. A man claiming to be a member of the Revolutionary Left (MIR) claimed credit for the incident. There were no reports of damage or injuries.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (c.f. 199309090002-4).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: Bomb placed in a flowerbed underneath the front entrance widows
summary: 9/10/1993: Unknown perpetrators bombed the Family Planning Associates clinic in Newport Beach, California, United States. There were no casualties but the building sustained around $3,500 in damages.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in California.
weapdetail: Authorities were unsure of exactly what type of explosive device was used, but a plastic gas can filled with liquid was discovered at the scene.
propcomment: Two windows shattered
addnotes: The bombing took place overnight and the abortion clinic was forced to open late the following day.  One day after the incident, the healthcare facility received a bomb threat.  Authorities were unsure whether this threat was related to the bombing.
scite1: Greg Hernandez, "Newport Beach: Threat Follows Blast at Abortion Clinic," Los Angeles Times, September 15, 1993.
scite2: Greg Hernandez and Eric Young, "Bombing Hits Newport Beach Abortion Clinic," Los Angeles Times, September 11, 1993.
scite3: "Attacks on the West Coast," The Oregonian, January 31, 1994.

summary: 09/11/1993: Two fire bombs were found near Windsor Castle in England at the offices of Burlington Publishing, which produces Shooting Times and The Field. The Hunt Retribution Squad, which advocates violence, claimed responsibility. No one was injured and the bombs were defused.
scite1: “Bombing Marks Return of Anti-Hunt Terrorists," Press Association, September 12, 1993.
scite2: “Army Defuses Windsor Bombs," Sunday Times, September 12, 1993.
scite3: “Anti-hunting Bombs Defused," The Independent (London), September 12, 1993.

summary: 09/11/1993: Muslim extremists from the group Jamaat-e-Islami killed two policemen as they waited for a bus in southern Egypt. The policemen were standing at the bus station in Dayrut when they were shot. The four assailants escaped and no one else was injured in the attack.
addnotes: Ahmad Abdel Hakim died in the hospital following the attack.
scite1: “Militants Kill Two Policemen in South Egypt," Agence France Presse, September 11, 1993.
scite2: “Two Policemen Killed in Upper Egypt," Xinhua General News Service, September 11, 1993.
scite3: “Suspected Extremists Kill Two Policemen," The Associated Press, September 11, 1993.

summary: 09/11/1993: Four South Lebanon Army soldiers were wounded in Hizballah mortar attacks on two SLA outposts in Southern Lebanon. There were no fatalities in the attack.
addnotes: Israel and the United States formally recognized the Palestine Liberation Organization on Friday September 10th.
scite1: “Hizbullah Fire Wounds Four SLA Soldiers in Zone," The Jerusalem Post, September 12, 1993.
scite2: “As PLO Pact Is Sealed, Unrest Mounts," Chicago Sun-Times, September 11, 1993.
scite3: “Hezbollah attacks Israeli posts in south Lebanon to protest accord," Agence France Presse, September 14, 1993.

summary: 09/12/1993: HAMAS rebels ambushed three Israeli soldiers and killed them in their military jeep in Gaza City. No one was injured in the attack.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf: [199309120002] and [199309120003]).
scite1: “Three IDF soldiers killed; buses attacked: Israeli, Palestinian," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Hamas Claims Responsibility for Terrorist Attacks in Gaza," CBS Morning News, September 12, 1993.
scite3: “Jihad Kills Three Israelis on Eve of Peace Deal," The Guardian (London), September 13, 1993.

summary: 09/12/1993: A man stabbed to death an Israeli bus driver and was then shot dead by an IDF soldier in Gaza City. The perpetrator was a member of HAMAS. No one else was injured in the attack.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf: [199309120001] and [199309120003]).
scite1: “Three IDF soldiers killed; buses attacked: Israeli, Palestinian," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Foes of Mideast accord blamed in 7 deaths; Violence flares in occupied territories as Arafat goes to Washington," The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec) (Montreal, Quebec), September 13, 1993.
scite3: “Jihad Kills Three Israelis on Eve of Peace Deal," The Guardian (London), September 13, 1993.

summary: 09/12/1993: A 20-year-old HAMAS member rammed his car into a bus and died in the collision in Gaza City. Two Israelis on the bus were injured. His car was loaded with gasoline cans, as it was an unsuccessful suicide attack. There were no other fatalities in the attack.
weaptype1_txt: Vehicle (not to include vehicle-borne explosives, i.e., car or truck bombs)
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf: [199309120001] and [199309120002]).
scite1: “Three IDF soldiers killed; buses attacked: Israeli, Palestinian," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Foes of Mideast accord blamed in 7 deaths; Violence flares in occupied territories as Arafat goes to Washington," The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec) (Montreal, Quebec), September 13, 1993.
scite3: “Jihad Kills Three Israelis on Eve of Peace Deal," The Guardian (London), September 13, 1993.

summary: 09/12/1993: In Port-au-Prince, Haiti, a prominent supporter of Haiti's exiled President Jean-Bertrand Aristide was dragged from church and assassinated. Another person was killed and a third was stabbed and wounded during the attack. No one claimed responsibility for the attack.
addnotes: No additional information was provided concerning the second and third casualties.
scite1: “Aristide Backer Dragged From Haiti Church, Slain," Chicago Sun-Times, September 12, 1993.
scite2: Bowers, Faye. “Events," Christian Science Monitor, September 13, 1993

location: Ulster (Province). Passenger train between Belfast and Dublin
summary: 09/12/1993: The UVF claimed responsibility for partially detonating a bomb on a passenger train between Belfast and Dublin. Two people were injured. The explosion caused minor damage.
target1: Irish passenger train between Belfast and Dublin
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 09/12/1993: HAMAS gunmen fired on an Israeli bus driver in Halhoul in the Hebron District of the West Bank, wounding him.
target1: Bus traveling near in Halhoul, West Bank
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 09/13/1993: At least two people were seriously wounded as the result of several dynamite attacks against six separate banks in Lima. The attacks were carried out by Shining Path rebels, and came on the first anniversary of the capture of Shining Path leader Abimael Guzman.
addnotes: This was one of six related attacks (cf:[199309130002, 199309130003, 199309130004, 199309130005, 199309130006]). There were 2 injuries in these six attacks, but more specific information was not provided. In order to preserve statistical accuracy, the injuries were divided across the linked cases.
scite1: “Two Injured in Bomb Attacks in Lima; Police say Attack on Congress was Planned," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 15, 1993.
scite2: “Bombs explode at telephone company and bank in Lima," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 18, 1993.
scite3: “Shining Path kills two police officers, bombs six banks," Agence France Presse, September 17, 1993.
