summary: 09/13/1993: The Protestant Red Hand Commandos shot and killed Vernon Bailey, 41, outside his home near Newtownards in Ulster Province, Northern Ireland. No one was injured in the attack.
scite1: “We Killed ‘Informer’ – Terror Group," Press Association, September 14, 1993
scite2: “Outlawed Paramilitary Group Killed ‘Informer,'" Agence France Presse, September 15, 1993.

summary: 09/13/1993: Two people were wounded when an explosion rocked the embassy of the United Arab Emirates in Moscow. There were no fatalities in the attack, but the explosion did cause minor damage. There was no information on the perpetrators involved.
target1: United Arab Emirates Embassy in Moscow
propcomment: The blast shattered window glass on the ground floor and disrupted telephone communications.
scite1: “Explosion in UAE Embassy," Russian Press Digest, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Two wounded in explosions at UAE embassy in Moscow," Agence France Presse, September 13, 1993

provstate: National Capital Territory of Delhi (Union Territory)
summary: 09/13/1993: A car bomb exploded in central New Delhi, India, in an attempt to assassinate a top politician, Maninder Singh Bitta. He escaped with shrapnel wounds to the chest, but at least eight people were killed and 36 wounded. No group claimed responsibility for this attack.
corp1: President of the Congress Party's Youth Wing
propcomment: The vehicle housing the bomb was destroyed.
addnotes: No one immediately claimed responsibility for the bombing, but police suspected Sikh terrorists. Bitta, a Sikh from Punjab, had been the target of several attacks by rebels from the northern state.
scite1: “New Delhi car bomb blast sparks concern over Sikh militancy," Agence France Presse, September 13, 1993.
scite2: “India to Probe Car Bombs," Financial Times, September 13, 1993.
scite3: “A Car Bomb in New Delhi Kills 8 and Wounds 36," The New York Times, September 12, 1993.

summary: 09/13/1993: A policeman was injured when a car bomb exploded in Belfast, Northern Ireland, badly damaging a hotel. No one was killed and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
propcomment: The blast damaged the side and rear of the hotel.
scite1: “Policeman Injured in Car Bomb Blast," Agence France Presse, September 13, 1993.
scite2: “Car bomb blast injures police officer," United Press International, September 13, 1993.

summary: 09/14/1993: In Gaza City, HAMAS member Ismael Sheber, 21, climbed the stairs of the Gaza City municipal building to a rooftop lookout held by Israeli soldiers. Holding a Koran and a knife he stabbed one soldier, then was shot dead by another. The stabbed soldier was slightly injured. No one else was killed or injured in the attack.
addnotes: Leaflets were distributed claiming responsibility for the attacks.
scite1: “2 Palestinians Die in Gaza Incidents Claimed by Militant Group," The Washington Post, September 15, 1993.
scite2: “Clashes Leave Two Dead In Occupied Territories," The Washington Post, September 12, 1993.

summary: 09/14/1993: In Gaza City, HAMAS member Baha Awad Najar, 20, walked into the courtyard of the police station in Gaza City with four bombs strapped to his waist. A policeman shot him, detonating the explosives and killing him instantly. No one else was hurt or killed in the attack.
addnotes: Leaflets were distributed claiming responsibility for the attacks.
scite1: “2 Palestinians Die in Gaza Incidents Claimed by Militant Group," The Washington Post, September 15, 1993.
scite2: “Clashes Leave Two Dead In Occupied Territories," The Washington Post, September 12, 1993.

summary: 09/14/1993: In an apparent suicide attack in Gaza City, an Arab man blew himself up when the electric gate of the police station opened to let out a car. The attacker was killed and no one else was injured or killed.
scite1: “Bomb, Knife Attacks Follow Peace Treaty," The Associated Press, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Two Palestinians Die In Attacks In Gaza Strip," The Associated Press, September 14, 1993.

summary: 09/14/1993: Soldiers shot dead a Palestinian man who lunged at an Israeli trooper with a knife during a guard change at an observation post in Gaza City. The soldier was slightly injured and there were no fatalities.
scite1: “Bomb, Knife Attacks Follow Peace Treaty," The Associated Press, September 14, 1993.
scite2: “Two Palestinians Die In Attacks In Gaza Strip," The Associated Press, September 14, 1993.

summary: 09/15/1993: Islamic gunmen hijacked a passenger jet over Azerbaijan and forced the pilot to fly the plane to Norway. The 52 people onboard were unharmed and the 2 terrorists were arrested in Oslo. No one was killed in the attack.
target1: Tupolev-134 jet, with 46 passengers and 6 crew.
scite1: “Contact established with hijackers at Oslo airport," Agence France Presse, September 15, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen Hijack Passenger Jet," The Associated Press, September 15, 1993.
scite3: “Hijackers request asylum," Agence France Presse, September 15, 1993.

summary: 09/16/1993: The IRA shot dead a Catholic man at his home on the outskirts of Lisburn, County Antrim, Northern Ireland. Gunmen entered his bungalow in an isolated area, and opened fire, hitting him five times. No one else was injured or killed in the attack.
scite1: “Man shot dead by IRA in Lisburn," The Irish Times, September 16, 1993.
scite2: Johnson, Paul. “The Time to Talk is Now," The Guardian (London), September 18, 1993.

summary: 09/17/1993: A woman suffered minor injuries when a crude bomb went off on the platform of the busy Dadar railway station in Mumbai, India. No one else was injured or killed, and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Two crude bombs explode in Bombay," United Press International, September 17, 1993.
scite2: “Two bombs explode in Bombay, woman hurt," Agence France Presse, September 17, 1993.

summary: 09/17/1993: In Mumbai, India, a bomb, resembling a pipe, exploded outside an office of the Hindu militant Shiv Sena (Shiva's Army) group after a boy who was examining it threw it away. Nobody was hurt in the explosion and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
target1: Hindu militant Shiv Sena (Shiva's Army) group.
scite1: “Two crude bombs explode in Bombay," United Press International, September 17, 1993.
scite2: “Two bombs explode in Bombay, woman hurt," Agence France Presse, September 17, 1993.

summary: 09/18/1993: In Egypt, suspected Muslim extremists killed a high-ranking police officer with a fusillade of automatic fire as he drove home in the southern town of Aswan. No one else was injured or killed, and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Suspected Muslim Extremists Kill Senior Police Officer," The Associated Press, September 18, 1993.
scite2: “General assassinated in Aswan," BBC Summary of World Broadcasts, September 20, 1993.
scite3: “Senior Officer Killed by Suspected Extremists," Xinhua General News Service, September 18, 1993.

summary: 09/19/1993: A powerful car bomb ripped through a police station in Catania, Italy, wounding at least four police officers, one of them seriously. Officials said the bomb appeared to have been set by the Mafia, though no group claimed responsibility for the attack. No one was killed in the attack.
scite1: “4 police officers injured in Italy blast Officials attribute car bomb to Mafia," The Dallas Morning News, September 19, 1993.
scite2: “Police Station in Sicily Bombed; Mafia Suspected," The New York Times, September 19, 1993.
scite3: “Car Bomb Wounds Four Police," The Associated Press, September 17, 1993.

summary: 09/19/1993: Seven IDF soldiers were killed and two wounded by guerilla bombs in South Lebanon. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Guerrillas Attack Israeli-Backed Militia In South Lebanon," The Associated Press, September 20, 1993.
scite2: “Seven IDF soldiers killed in South Lebanon," Mideast Mirror, September 19, 1993.

summary: 09/19/1993: Unknown perpetrators threw a bomb at the Mexican Embassy in San Salvador. No injuries were reported. The explosion caused minor damage.
weapdetail: 10 pound bomb
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 09/19/1993: Police thwarted an assassination attempt on Yasser Arafat at the entrance of the Arab League building in Cairo, Egypt. Four al-Jihad Organization perpetrators were arrested in the attempted car bombing plot. There were no casualties in this incident.
weapdetail: Booby-trapped car bomb
addnotes: The explosive device was discovered by Egyptian State Security four hours prior to the scheduled Arab Foreign Ministers Meeting.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 09/20/1993: HAMAS gunmen shot dead two armed Palestinians in Jabalya, in the Gaza Strip, for collaborating with Israel. The gunmen ambushed two in a car and took their Israeli-issued weapons. Villagers said the men, Jamal Abu Warda and Jamal Shahda, were well-known as collaborators with the army and General Security Service. No one else was injured or killed in the attack.
scite1: “Fatah gunmen claim execution of two Gaza informers," The Jerusalem Post, September 20, 1993.
scite2: “Gaza killing bursts transition bubble," The Jerusalem Post, September 24, 1993.
scite3: “Killing blamed on Fatah feud; Signs of Palestinian political vacuum at local level," The Independent (London), September 23, 1993.

summary: 09/21/1993: Gunmen believed to be Muslim militants shot dead a Coptic Christian teacher in Dayrut, Egypt. No one else was injured or killed, and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Coptic teacher, policeman slain in south Egypt," Agence France Presse, September 21, 1993.
scite2: “Coptic teacher slain in south Egypt," Agence France Presse, September 21, 1993.
scite3: “Two killed in Moslem extremist attacks," Xinhua General News Service, September 21, 1993.

summary: 09/21/1993: Gunmen believed to be Muslim militants shot and killed a policeman in the southern province of Asyut, in Egypt. No one else was killed or injured in the attack, and no group claimed responsibility.
scite1: “Coptic teacher, policeman slain in south Egypt," Agence France Presse, September 21, 1993.
scite2: “Two killed in moslem extremist attacks," Xinhua General News Service, September 21, 1993.
scite3: “Policeman Is Slain in Egypt; Security Aides Cite Militants," The New York Times,  September 26, 1993.

summary: 09/21/1993: A soldier was injured in a terrorist bomb attack on a military patrol in Belfast, Northern Ireland. Police said the soldier was hurt when a device was thrown at the patrol in the nationalist Ardoyne area. A civilian was also treated for shock after the attack. No group claimed responsibility for the attack, and there were no fatalities.
scite1: “Soldier Wounded in Terror Blast," Press Association, September 21, 1993.
scite2: “Terror Threat," The Independent (London), September 22, 1993.

summary: 09/21/1993: Three employees of a French-owned utility company were taken hostage by unknown perpetrators in Tlelac, Algeria. The Moroccan hostage was set free while the two French hostages were found with their throats cut.
target1: Two French employees of a French-owned utility company
target2: Moroccan employee of a French-owned utility company
addnotes: One of the victims was Francois Barthelet, age 32.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 9/21/1993:  Unknown perpetrators ignited a fire the Family Planning Associates clinic in Bakersfield, California, United States. There were no casualties but the abortion clinic was destroyed and two adjacent buildings were also damaged. In total, the damages amounted to $1,400,000.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in California.
propcomment: The abortion clinic was destroyed and two adjacent buildings were damaged.
addnotes: The firefighters first arrived on the scene at 3:40 AM and the blaze was extinguished 1.5 hours later.  The abortion clinic, the only one in Bakersfield, was the target of many previous protests.
scite1: Joe Bigham, "Bakersfield Abortion Clinic Burned.  Facility Owner has Riverside Tie," The Press-Enterprise, September 21, 1993.
scite2: "California City's Abortion Clinic Burns, and Police Suspect Arson," New York Times, September 21, 1993.
scite3: "Attacks on the West Coast," The Oregonian, January 31, 1994.

summary: 09/24/1993: An Israeli man was stabbed to death by HAMAS rebels near Tel Aviv, Israel. Yigal Waknin, 21, was killed while driving a tractor in an orchard near Batzna. No one else was injured or killed in the attack.
addnotes: A leaflet signed by Hamas was found near the body claiming responsibility for the killing.
scite1: “Israeli stabbed to death by HAMAS activists, PLO stops fighting," Agence France Presse, September 24, 1993.
scite2: “Israeli stabbed to death by HAMAS activists," Agence France Presse, September 24, 1993.
scite3: “Israeli Stabbed to Death," Newsday, September 25, 1993.

summary: 09/25/1993: A major gun battle broke out in Ulster when the IRA tried to shoot down an Army helicopter. Terrorists using heavy machine guns mounted on a flat-bed truck opened fire on a Puma helicopter as it took off from a military base at Crossmaglen. No one was injured or killed in the attack.
propcomment: The helicopter was hit by gunfire, but the extent of damage was not significant.
addnotes: The Puma was joined by two more Army helicopters and a ten-minute battle took place. The gunmen abandoned their vehicles in the village of Cullyhanna, close to the border with the Irish Republic, and hijacked several cars to escape.
scite1: “Terrorists Flee in Helicopter Shoot-out," Daily Mail (London), September 24, 1993.
scite2: “IRA Drop Guns and Flee," The Herald, September 25, 1993.

summary: 09/25/1993: A British soldier was injured in an IRA bomb attack on a joint police army patrol in west Belfast, Northern Ireland. The device was detonated by a command wire from the side of the Glen Road in the Suffolk estate as the four-vehicle patrol passed. No one else was injured, and there were no fatalities in the attack.
scite1: “Soldiers hurt in IRA ambush of patrol on housing estate," The Irish Times, September 25, 1993.

provstate: National Capital Territory of Delhi (Union Territory)
summary: 09/25/1993: Sikh Militants attacked a bus in Delhi, India, killing three members of the governing Congress Party as they traveled to a mass rally against terrorism and religious intolerance. No one was injured in the attack, and no group claimed responsibility.
target1: Bus transporting Congress Party Members and CP President Maninder Singh Bitta
propcomment: The bus was fired at extensively, and the extent of damages is unknown.
scite1: “3 Killed in Sikh Attack," Newsday, September 25, 1993.
scite2: “Rally in New Delhi; Sikh Militants Kill 3 Congress Party Members," The Associated Press, September 24, 1993.

summary: 9/26/1993: Randal Maske firebombed the National Health Care Services Clinic in Peoria, Illinois, United States. There were no casualties, but the clinic sustained $10,000 in damages.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in Illinois.  Furthermore, Randal Maske claimed that God commanded him to commit the attack.
weapdetail: Firebomb
propcomment: Entrance and outside sidewalk damaged.
addnotes: Randal Maske did not confess to the firebombing until around nine years after the incident.
scite1: "Man Who Confessed to Peoria Bombing Sentenced to Prison," Associated Press, June 18, 2002.
scite2: "Planned Parenthood Office Firebombed," Associated Press, September 29, 1993.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 09/27/1993: In Sri Lanka, five soldiers were killed and another one was wounded in an operation against separatist Tamil guerrillas in the country's northwest section of Vankalai.
scite1: “Five solders killed, one wounded in terrorist attack," United Press International, September 27, 1993.
scite2: “Two airmen killed in Tamil separatist attack," United Press International, September 26, 1993.
scite3: “Sri Lankan guerrilla attack kills four policemen," United Press International, September 25, 1993.

summary: 09/28/1993: The body of Yigal Vaknin, 22, was found on Yom Kippur Eve lying face down under a grapefruit tree in a citrus grove at Moshav Batzra, five kilometers north of Ra'anana in the Gaza Strip. HAMAS rebels perpetrated the attack, and no one else was injured or killed.
scite1: “Gaza man confesses to murdering Vaknin," The Jerusalem Post, September 28, 1993.
scite2: “Terror victim buried; 'killers had national and criminal motives,'" The Jerusalem Post, September 27, 1993.
scite3: “Hamas claims responsibility for citrus grove murder," The Jerusalem Post, September  26, 1993.

summary: 09/28/1993: While three Baltic Presidents, from Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania, were meeting with President Bill Clinton of the U.S., a bomb exploded behind the U.S. Embassy. No casualties were reported.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 09/28/1993: Angolan rebels occupied the Danish Embassy in Dar es Salaam. They were finally arrested after spending over a week in the Embassy. No injuries were reported.
target1: Danish Embassy in Dar es Salaam
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 09/28/1993: A bomb planted near the U.S. Embassy and British Embassy was detonated, causing relatively minor damage to the area, knocking out satellite communications and breaking nearby windows.
propcomment: There was relatively minor damage to the area, knocking out satellite communications and breaking nearby windows.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 09/29/1993: A policeman was killed and another was wounded when suspected Muslim militants fired on a Coptic church in the southern town of Dayrut, Egypt. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
addnotes: Most churches in Egypt have been guarded by police since incidents of sectarian strife began in the 1980's.
scite1: “Gunmen Kill Church Guard in South," The Associated Press, September 29, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen Kill Church Guard," The Associated Press, September 29, 1993.

summary: 09/29/1993: Gunmen assassinated the former leader of Pakistan's largest province. Ghulam Hyder Wyne, an ally of former Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif, was ambushed as he drove in his home village of Mian Channu. No one else was injured or killed in the attack, and no group claimed responsibility.
scite1: “Gunmen Kill Former Provincial Governor In Pakistan," The Associated Press, September 29, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen kill former high-ranking official in Pakistan," United Press International, September 29, 1993.

summary: 09/30/1993: A Lancaster, Pennsylvania, Planned Parenthood clinic that does not offer abortion services was burned extensively in an arson attack that caused an estimated $130,000 in damage. No one was injured and no group claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Clinic Arson; Nation’s Third Attack in 10 Days," Abortion Report, September 30, 1993.
scite2: “Clinic Firebombed in Pennsylvania," The New York Times, September 30, 1993.
scite3: “3rd clinic in 10 days is attacked / Abortion backers: Feds must act now," USA TODAY, September 30, 1993.

summary: 09/30/1993: In South Africa, four people were killed and 16 were wounded when gunmen opened fire on passengers disembarking from a crowded train at a station in Johannesburg's Soweto black township. No group claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: “Gunmen Attack Commuters in Black Township; Four Killed," The Associated Press, September 30, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen kill four in train attack," Agence France Presse, September 30, 1993.

summary: 10/02/1993: Four men and a woman, all in their 20s, were cut by flying glass and suffered shock from the four blasts which the IRA exploded in Finchley Road, North London, shortly before 12.30am.

motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to derail peace talks.

summary: 10/2/1993: Richard Joseph Campos, the sole member of the Aryan Liberation Front, threw two Molotov cocktails at the offices of the Japanese American Citizens League in Sacramento, California, United States. There were no casualties but one firebomb was thrown through the front door of the building and gutted the offices. The other firebomb did not ignite.
target1: Japanese American Citizens League offices, Sacramento
motive: Richard Joseph Campos adopted the racist ideology of the White Aryan Resistance (WAR) and wanted to create an all-White society.
weapdetail: Two Molotov cocktails with a towel as a wick
propcomment: Office was gutted
addnotes: The incident took place at 1:45 AM.  Richard Joseph Campos bombed four other buildings in the Sacramento area including the NAACP headquarters, a synagogue, the home of city councilman Jimmie Yee, and the state Office of Fair Employment and Housing building (199307250005, 199310050004, and 199310140009).  After he firebombed the house of Jimmie Yee, Campos called the Sacramento television station KOVR claiming that the Aryan Liberation Front carried out the firebombing of the Japanese American Citizens League.  Campos was the only member of the Aryan Liberation Front.  Before carrying out his bombing campaign, Campos called the White Aryan Resistance (WAR) hotline 34 times to listen to messages from the organizations leader Tom Metzger.  Campos had a WAR poster in his bedroom when he was arrested.
scite1: Ann Bancroft, "Councilman's Home Attacked In Sacramento," San Francisco Chronicle, October 6, 1993.
scite2: "Attack On Japanese-American League Latest Violence Against Ethnic Group," Associated Press, October 3, 1993.
scite3: Mareva Brown, "Racist's Rampage Was 'Wake-Up Call.'  The White Supremacist Convicted in '93 Bombings is Out of Prison," Sacramento Bee, July 7, 2003.

summary: 10/03/1993: Aideed's bloody assault on U.S.-led U.N. peacekeepers in Mogadishu resulted in 12 American deaths. 78 were wounded and others were missing and/or held hostage.
motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to avenge a recent U.S. Attack on Aideed's forces.

scite2: Keith B. Richburg, “Somali Warlord turns Vietnam Tactics on U.S.; Aidid Wins even when he Loses,” Hamilton Spectator, October 7, 1993.

summary: 10/04/1993: A Palestinian driving a car packed with explosives blew himself up in a suicide attack on an Israeli commuter bus outside the Israeli Army headquarters in the West Bank. Thirty passengers were wounded.

gname: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP)
motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to derail peace talks.

scite2: Jon Immanuel, “Suicide Bomber Wounds 30,” The Jerusalem Post, October 5, 1993.
scite3: David Horovitz, “Car Bomb Injures 30 Israelis,” Financial Times, October 5, 1993.

summary: 10/04/1993: In a series of attacks on London five bombs went off at intervals just after 6.30am and one was defused. None of the devices caused serious injuries. In this incident two of the bombs exploded near a YMCA in Crouch End. Two more exploded about a mile to the west on the main A1.
motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to derail peace talks.
weapdetail: Each device was composed of less than one pound of high explosive with a 1 hour timing device
propcomment: Each blast blew out shop-front windows, scattering glass over a wide area, but structural damage was light
addnotes: This was one of four related attacks (cf. 199310040003; 199310040004; 199310040005).
scite1: Michael Harvey and David Mason, “More Bombs Rock London Streets—Without Warning,” Press Association, October 4, 1993.
scite2: Terry Kirby, “Police find Sixth Unexploded Device in North London ; 'Sinister Change of Strategy' by IRA over Bomb Warnings,” The Independent (London), October 5, 1993.
scite3: Duncan Campbell, “IRA Blasts Mark ‘Sinister Change of Tactics,’” The Guardian (London), October 5, 1993.

summary: 10/04/1993: A small bomb detonated outside the French Cultural Center in Lome, Togo. Three passersby were injured and substantial damage was caused. No one had claimed responsibility for this incident.
weapdetail: The device was a low-power bomb.
propcomment: The bomb left a 20-centimeter hole in the wall of the French Cultural Center, crumpled roofing sheets, shattered windows, broke the windshield of a parked car, and damaged a home 150 meters away.

addnotes: The incident took place at 3:30  AM.  Richard Joseph Campos bombed four other buildings in the Sacramento area including the NAACP headquarters, a synagogue, the Japanese American Citizens League, and the home of city councilman Jimmie Yee (199307250005, 199310020003, and 199310050004).  Forty-five minutes after the  firebombing of the government facility, Campos called the Sacramento television station KCRA and claimed the incident on behalf of the Aryan Liberation Front.  The Fair Employment and Housing Department handled claims of discrimination.  Campos was the only member of the Aryan Liberation Front.  Before carrying out his bombing campaign, Campos called the White Aryan Resistance (WAR) hotline 34 times to listen to messages from the organizations leader Tom Metzger.  Campos had a WAR poster in his bedroom when he was arrested.
scite1: Steve Geissinger, "Another Firebombing Shakes California's Capital," Associated Press, October 15, 1993.
scite2: "Man Convicted Of 2 Bombings Tied to Racism," New York Times, August 31, 1994.
scite3: Mareva Brown, "Racist's Rampage Was 'Wake-Up Call.'  The White Supremacist Convicted in '93 Bombings is Out of Prison," Sacramento Bee, July 7, 2003.

summary: 10/15/1993: At least 11 people had been killed over the previous 48 hours in subversive actions across Chuquibamba conducted by Shining Path militants. The Mayor and Governor of Accha district were targeted in this incident.
target1: Mayor Rogelio Huaman of Accha District
target2: Governor Aurelio Bacafuer of Accha District
addnotes: This was one of four related attacks (Cf. 199310140003;199310140004;199310140005)
scite1: "Shining Path Violence; State of Emergency Extended in Several Provinces,” British Broadcasting Corporation, October 18, 1993.

summary: 10/16/1993: Two senior Russian military officers were assassinated in Laghouat, Algeria. The attack was apparently part of a new phase of a two-year-old terror campaign by Muslim fundamentalists. The United Company of Holy War claimed responsibility.
target1: Russian Military Specialists Teaching at a military school in Laghouat
motive: The perpetrators wanted to drive diplomats and Military out of country.
scite1: "2 Russians in Algeria are Slain by Militants,” The New York Times, October 20, 1993.

summary: 10/16/1993: A bomb exploded at the Military Governor's office on Ejercito Avenue in Pamplona, Spain, injuring a National Police Corps officer. There was a prior warning made by an unknown perpetrator.
weapdetail: The device was a parcel bomb.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 10/17/1993: Two policemen were slain by attackers believed to be from a guerrilla group blamed for killing whites and government security forces. The attack occurred in their station at Pongweni, near the southeastern Natal town of Kokstad.
target1: South African Police station at Pongweni
motive: The perpetrators wanted to disrupt peace talks.
scite1: Tina Susmsn, “Two Policemen Killed as Anger over Army Raid Grows,” The Associated Press, October 17, 1993.

summary: 10/17/1993: A Protestant man in his 30s was fighting for his life in the hospital after he was shot by IRA gunmen at his mother's house in South Belfast.
target1: Civilian in Belfast (at a private residence on Walmour Street, near the Ormeau Road)
motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to derail peace talks.
scite1: Gerry Moriarty, “Belfast Man Shot in Attack by IRA Critical,” The Irish Times, October 18, 1993.

summary: 10/18/1993: A unidentified group of Muslim militants holed up in Kashmir's holiest mosque threatened to blow it up if the Indian government did not lift the siege by soldiers which on October 18th had entered its third day.
motive: Militants demand the Indian army end its siege of the mosque and permit people to enter.
scite1: "India: Stalemate in Kashmir, Militants Threaten Mosque,” Inter Press International, October 18, 1993.
scite2: "Muslim Rebels in Kashmir Refuse to Leave Mosque,” Japan Economic Newswire, October 21, 1993.
scite3: "Indian Media, Opposition want Kashmir Mosque Protected,” Agence France Presse, October 19, 1993.

summary: 10/18/1993: A soldier was killed and eight people (7 civil servants and 1 private citizen) were abducted when terrorists attacked their vehicle in the Aralik District of eastern Igdir Province. The Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) carried out the attack.
target3: A Civilian in the car with the soldier and civil servants
scite1: "Soldier Killed, Eight Abducted in Igdir,” British Broadcasting Corporation, October 21, 1993.

summary: 10/18/1993: A member of KAKH threw a grenade under a truck in the main square of a Nabulus market, injuring four people. Israeli soldiers in the vicinity opened fire on the area from where the grenade was thrown. Four people were "lightly" injured in this incident.
target1: A truck traveling in the main square of the Nabulus market
weapdetail: Hand grenade
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 10/19/1993: A Spanish Air Force general was shot dead. In a separate incident, a car bomb exploded in two separate attacks in central Madrid which authorities blamed on the Basque separatist organization ETA.
target1: Spanish Air Force General in Madrid
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199310190002).
scite1: Jane Walker, “General Shot Dead by ETA in Madrid,” The Guardian (London), October 20, 1993.
scite2: "ETA Blamed as General Shot, Car Bomb Explodes in Madrid, Agence France Presse, October 19, 1993.

summary: 10/19/1993: The National Industry Institute, a state holding company, was targeted by an ETA car bomb. In a separate incident a Spanish Air Force general was shot dead in central Madrid.
target1: National Industry Institute, a state holding company
weapdetail: A booby-trapped vehicle, which was double-parked, was the same car used by the general's attackers
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199310190001).
scite1: Jane Walker, “General Shot Dead by ETA in Madrid,” The Guardian (London), October 20, 1993.
scite2: "ETA Blamed as General Shot, Car Bomb Explodes in Madrid, Agence France Presse, October 19, 1993.

summary: 10/19/1993: Members of the Armed Islamic Group kidnapped and killed three foreign technicians of an Italian construction firm in Tiaret, Algeria.
target1: Three foreign technicians from an Italian construction firm
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 10/21/1993: A prominent moderate in the Palestine Liberation Organization's Fatah wing and associate of Chairman Yasser Arafat was slain by masked gunmen. The gunmen were suspected members of the Arab Palestine Organization.
motive: The attack was carried out in an effort to gain political control of Gaza.
scite1: "Adherent to PLO Chief’s Policy Killed in Gaza,” Tass, October 21, 1993.
scite2: Ethan Bronner, “PLO Moderate Slain in Blow to Peace Pact,” Boston Globe, October 22, 1993.
scite3: David Hoffman, “Senior PLO Leader Slain in Gaza Strip; Palestinians, Israelis Set Prisoner Exchange,” The Washington Post, October 22, 1993.

summary: 10/22/1993: A bomb exploded in a courthouse in the northern Italian town of Padua early Friday. The bomb, which caused serious damage but no injuries, was placed in the office of the court secretariat. The Italian Mafia claimed responsibility for the attack.
scite1: "Bomb Explodes in Padua Courthouse,” Agence France Presse, October 22, 1993.
scite2: "Bomb Explodes in Padua Courthouse, Mafia Suspected,” Agence France Presse, October 22, 1993.
scite3: "Mystery Group Claims Padua Courthouse Blast,” Agence France Presse, October 22, 1993.

summary: 10/23/1993: Nine people were killed and more than 50 injured when the outlawed Irish Republican Army set off a bomb in the Protestant section of Belfast. The bomb was placed near a fishmonger's shop on Shankill Road and was targeted against a meeting of Ulster Freedom Fighters members.
target1: A meeting of UFF members taking place in an office above a fishmonger's shop on Shankill Road
motive: The perpetrators believed the targeted building was being used for a meeting of the UFF.
scite1: William Tuohy, “IRA Bombing Kills 9, Injures 50 in Belfast,” Chicago Sun Times, October 24, 1993.
scite2: David McKittrick, “Nine Die in IRA Bombing; Loyalist Promise Vengeance after Attack without Warning on Belfast Paramilitary HQ,” The Independent (London), October 24, 1993.
scite3: William Tuohy, “9 Die, 50 Hurt as IRA Bomb hits Belfast Protestant Area; Attackers Claim Targeted Building was Being used by Outlawed Ulster Freedom Fighters,” Los Angeles Times, October 24, 1993.

summary: 10/23/1993: Three unknown, armed men attempted to kidnap an employee of the Japanese firm, NEC. The perpetrators fled after security troops, who were passing the scene by chance, fired on them. The driver of the car was injured in this incident.
target1: NEC Corporation employee in a car in Blida Province
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: An unspecified location in the Gaza Strip.
summary: 10/24/1993: Militants shot and stabbed two Israeli soldiers to death in the occupied Gaza Strip. HAMAS claimed responsibility.
target1: Two Soldiers in the Gaza Strip
motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to derail peace talks.
scite1: Carole Simpson, “ÁBC News Transcripts,” ABC News, October 24, 1993.
scite2: "Two Israeli Soldiers Killed by Islamic Militants,” ABC News, October 24, 1993.
scite3: Michael Parks, “Islamic Group Kills 2 Soldiers in Gaza, Israeli Army Says; Mideast: Pair Apparently Hitched Ride in Stolen Car with Israeli Plates. Attack is Aimed against Peace Accord,” Los Angeles Times, October 25, 1993.

summary: 10/24/1993: A self-proclaimed guerrilla movement, the Armed Islamic Group (GIA), claimed responsibility for the kidnapping of three French consular workers in Central Algiers.
target1: Three French consular workers in central Algiers
motive: The perpetrators suspected foreigners of cooperating with the Algerian authorities.
scite1: "Islamic Group Reports Kidnap of three French Consular Staff," Agence France Presse, October 28, 1993.
scite2: "Algerian Forces Free Two French Hostages, Third still Missing,”  Agence France Presse, October 31, 1993.
scite3: Richard Khiari, “Three French Captives Freed," The Associated Press, October 31, 1993.

summary: 10/24/1993: A pipe bomb suddenly exploded on Tel Aviv's Frishman beach, just opposite the French Embassy and the Dan Hotel. The bomb, which had been buried half a meter underground, caused no injuries or property damage. Kahane Chai was suspected in this incident.
target1: Tourists on Tel Aviv's Frishman beach
motive: Opposition to Arafat's visit to France.
weapdetail: The device was a pipe bomb
scite1: Allison Kaplan, “Bomb Explodes on Tel Aviv Beach,” The Jerusalem Post, October 25, 1993.

summary: 10/24/1993: A bomb exploded on the track outside the Reading Railroad Station, causing no injuries. A signal tower was destroyed. The Irish Republican Army (IRA) was held responsible for the attack.
propcomment: A signal tower was destroyed.
addnotes: This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199310240003).
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 10/24/1993: Suspected Macoute sympathizers shot and killed Dona St. Plite outside of Edison Middle School in Miami, Florida, United States. Plite hosted Haitian radio programs on WKAT and WLQY in Miami and was an outspoken critic of Haiti's military regime. This incident occurred a week before Haiti's Military Junta was supposed to transfer power to the democratically elected Jean-Bertrand Aristide.
corp1: Haitian Radio host supporting Haitian democracy
motive: To protest Haitian supporters of Jean-Bertrand Aristide's presidency and critics of Haiti's Military Junta.
addnotes: Dona St. Plite was gunned down at 9:40 PM.  He was also robbed and authorities were unsure whether this incident was politically motivated.  That being said, Plite had previously received three death threat letters and when he was shot he was leaving a benefit for Fritz Dor, a pro-Aristide Haitian radio broadcaster who was gunned down in Miami two years earlier (199103150023).  Another Haitian broadcaster, Jean Claude Olivier, was also assassinated in Miami around the same time (199102180013).  Frenchy St. Louis Joseph was convicted of driving the getaway car.  Joseph originally accused Edy Pierre and Jean-Jacques Macton of being the shooters, but he refused to testify against them.
scite1: Michael Kirkland, "FBI Joins Probe Into Murder of Haitian Radio Commentator," United Press International, October 27, 1993.
scite2: Richard Cole, "One Arrested, Others Sought in Haitian Broadcaster's Death," Associated Press, December 7, 1993.
scite3: Sabrina Walters, "Getaway Driver Sentenced to Life in Murder of Haitian Radio Host," Miami Herald, February 24, 1996.

summary: 10/25/1993: The Movement for the Advancement of Democracy claimed responsibility for the hijacking of a Nigerian Airways jetliner. Most of the 159 passengers were released in Niger while four to six hijackers remained with as many as 34 hostages.
gname: Movement for the Advancement of Democracy (MAD)
motive: The attack was carried out as a protest against the military's voiding of the results of the June 12 presidential election.
addnotes: Most of the 159 passengers were released in Niger including a Nigerian General. The hijackers only negotiated with officials from Niger and refused to speak to Nigerian authorities.
scite1: Dalatou Mamane, “Group Claims Responsibility for Hijacking,” The Associated Press, October 27, 1993.

summary: 10/25/1993: The IRA planted three bombs - one of which exploded on the rail network west of London, causing no injuries but disrupting transport. The bomb that exploded was close to Reading Railway Station in Berkshire.
target1: British Rail Reading station at Berkshire
motive: The perpetrators wanted to  intimidate the government into accepting the IRA’s proposals.
scite1: "New Bomb Outrage,” Herald Sun, October 26, 1993.
scite2: Charles Batchelor, “IRA Explosion causes Rail Chaos in South: Bomb Damage Delays 40,000 Commuters - Belfast Holds Silent Memorial / Ulster's economic image dented,” Financial Times, October, 26, 1993.
scite3: David Wallen, “IRA Blast Disrupts Commuters in London,” South China Morning Post, October 26, 1993.

summary: 10/25/1993: Two people died and at least seven others were injured when suspected Maoist rebels detonated a powerful car bomb in the parking lot of Peru's Jorge Chavez International Airport. The bomb, placed under a minibus, exploded near the Departure area one person and injuring 20. The American Airlines cargo office sustained damage during the attack.
target1: Parking lot of Jorge Chavez International Airport
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 199310260004-5).
scite1: "Bomb Kills 2 at Lima Airport In Raid Laid to Shining Path,” The New York Times, October 27, 1993.
scite2: "Killed, 7 Hurt In Peru Blast,” Newsday, October 26,1993.
scite3: "Bomb Attacks on Airport Car Park and Lima Municipal Office Reported,” British Broadcasting Corporation, October 29, 1993.

summary: 10/25/1993: The IRA exploded a device on a road bridge above the London Marylebone to Banbury line at Brill, Buckinghamshire. There were no injuries.
target1: British Rail Marylebone to Banbury line at Brill
motive: The attack was aimed at intimidating government into accepting IRA’s proposals.
scite1: "Transport Chaos as Bombers Close Second Rail Line,” The Irish Times, October 26, 1993.

summary: 10/25/1993: Loyalist terrorists shot dead a Catholic man in his 70s at a house in North Belfast. The attack was in retaliation for the Shankill Road bombing.
target1: Catholic man at a private residence in North Belfast
motive: The attack was perpetrated as revenge for IRA attacks.
scite1: Ian Graham, “Loyalists Kill Man, 70, in Revenge Attack,” Press Association, October 25, 1993.

summary: 10/25/1993: Two United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) members were injured when their armored personnel carrier came under attack by unknown assailants in the UNIFIL Security Zone in southern Lebanon.
corp1: United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL)
target1: Two United Nations Interim Force in Lebanon (UNIFIL) soldiers
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 10/25/1993: Four unnamed perpetrators hijacked a Nigerian airliner carrying 137 passengers en route from Lagos to Abuja, Nigeria. The plane diverted to Niger, and after initial negotiations the hijackers let out more than 100 passengers. After fruitless additional negotiations, Nigerian police stormed the plane on October 28, 1993. Aside from two victims killed in a rescue operation, all were eventually rescued. The four hijackers surrendered, but one of the crew and one of the hijackers were killed during the rescue operation.
addnotes: The hijackers had originally wanted to go to Frankfurt, Germany, but when they were refused entry into the N'djamena Airport in Chad for refueling, they diverted to Niger instead. Among the passengers were four members of a Chinese bank delegation, led by the bank's Vice Governor Tu Jianji. Three other foreigners were also on the plane.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 10/26/1993: A gunman opened fire on diners at a luxury hotel on the River Nile, killing three people--two of them Americans--and wounding five.
target1: Coffee shop of the Semiramis Intercontinental Hotel
addnotes: American, French, Syrian and Italian citizens also fell victim to the attack.
scite1: Kim Murphy, “Cairo Killings not Linked to Terror Campaign, Officials Say,” Los Angeles Times, October 28, 1993.
scite2: "Cairo Gunman Kills 2 Americans and Frenchman,” The New York Times, October 27, 1993.
scite3: Caryle Murphy, “Egyptian Kills Tourists in Cairo Luxury Hotel,” The Washington Post, October 27, 1993.

summary: 10/26/1993: Two Ulster Freedom Fighters gunmen fired their automatic weapons at workers at the council depot in West Belfast. Two workers were killed and five others were wounded.
target1: Workers at the council depot in West Belfast
motive: The attack was perpetrated as revenge for IRA Attacks.
scite1: Graeme Wilson, “Hooded Gunmen Kill Workers at Council Depot,” The Scotsman, October 27, 1993.

summary: 10/26/1993: Suspected Shining Path guerrillas bombed a improvised Eastern Lima neighborhood in a wave of assaults that began with the bombing earlier in the week of the Lima airport.
target1: Civilians of a poor eastern Lima neighborhood
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 199310250003; 199310260005 ).
scite1: "Shining Path Attacks Kill One, Injure Dozens,” United Press International, October 26, 1993.

summary: 10/26/1993: Suspected Shining Path guerrillas shot Mayor Carlos Ramos in a wave of assaults that began with the bombing earlier in the week of the Lima airport.
addnotes: This was one of three related attacks (cf. 199310250003; 199310260004).
scite1: "Shining Path Attacks Kill One, Injure Dozens,” United Press International, October 26, 1993.

summary: 10/27/1993: Sendero Luminoso was responsible for detonating a bomb at the Interbanc branch of the U.S. Occidental Oil Company in San Isidro, causing minor damage.
target1: Interbanc branch of the U.S. Occidental Oil Company
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 10/28/1993: Loyalist paramilitary gunmen entered an isolated farmhouse in County Down and shot dead two Catholic brothers.
target1: Civilians in a County Down farmhouse
motive: The attack was perpetrated as revenge for IRA attacks.
scite1: Stewart Payne, “Girl who Saw her Brothers Shot Dead; Terrorists Struck as Girl Celebrated Birthday,” The Evening Standard, October 29, 1993.
scite2: "Brothers Gunned Down in their House,” The Herald, October 29, 1993.
scite3: John Mullin, “Killing of Catholic Brothers Brings Death Toll to o16 in Five Days,” The Guardian (London), October 29, 1993.

location: Royal Borough of Kensington and Chelsea (London Borough)
summary: 10/29/1993: A car exploded in Kensington, West London. The explosive device ripped apart the car but injured no-one. The IRA was suspected.
motive: A continuation of the ongoing conflict with Loyalists.
weapdetail: It was an improvised device
scite1: "Blast Wrecks Car,” The Independent (London), October 30, 1993.
scite2: "Bomb Blast Blamed on the IRA,” Press Association, October 30, 1993.
scite3: "Car Blast Hits West London,” Agence France Presse, October 29, 1993.

summary: 10/29/1993: Police said they recovered 2,300 electronic detonators and 165 pounds (75 kg) of gelatin a day after a powerful homemade bomb wrapped in a shopping bag exploded on a crowded Mumbai train. The explosion killed two passengers and wounded 44. Pakistani Militants were suspected.
target1: The second-class car of a Mumbai commuter train.
weapdetail: A powerful homemade bomb wrapped in a shopping bag.
addnotes: It was suspected that Pakistan's military-run Inter-Services Intelligence (ISI) were involved in this attack. There was no further information on this, however.
scite1: "Two Wounded in Bombay Train Blast Die in Hospital,” United International Press, October 30, 1993.
scite2: "Bombay Police Reports Busting New Bombing Plot,” United Press International, October 31, 1993.

summary: 10/29/1993: An Israeli settler was stabbed in the neck, abducted and killed by three masked HAMAS gunmen near Ramallah.
target1: Israeli settler at a chicken farm near Ramallah
motive: The attack was perpetrated in an effort to derail peace talks.
weapdetail: Settler was found stabbed the next day, along with his burned out car.
scite1: Michael Parks, “Israeli Settler Stabbed in the Neck by Palestinians,” Los Angeles Times, October 30, 1993.
scite2: "Abducted West Bank Settler found Dead” Agence France Presse, October 30, 1993.

summary: 10/30/1993: Three unknown Palestinian terrorists stabbed and shot to death Palestinian land dealer Ahmed Oudeh outside a flower-gift shop in Kalkilya.
motive: The victim was considered "a big collaborator" who sold land to Jewish settlers.
weapdetail: The victim was shot in the eye with his own gun.
scite1: Jon Immanuel, “Terrorists Kill Palestinian Land Dealer,” The Jerusalem Post, October 31, 1993.

summary: 10/30/1993: Terrorists joked "trick or treat" as they shot seven dead and injured 11 in the Rising Sun pub at Greysteel, County Londonderry. The Ulster Freedom Fighters were suspected.
target1: Rising Sun pub at Greysteel in Londonderry
motive: The attack was perpetrated as revenge for IRA attacks.
scite1: David McKittrick, “Five more Die in Gunman’s Reply to Ulster Peace Calls,” The Independent (London), October 31, 1993.
scite2: Tim Miles, “’Trick or Treat’ Killers Gun Down Seven,” Press Association, October 31, 1993.
scite3: "Five Shot Dead in Ulster Bar,” Press Association, October 30, 1993.

summary: 10/31/1993: Suspected Islamic militants shot and killed a plainclothes policeman in the southern region of Asyut.
target1: A plainclothes policeman in the southern region of Asyut
motive: The attack was perpetrated as revenge for death sentences handed down against fellow extremists.
scite1: "Suspected Islamic Militants Gun Down Policeman,” The Associated Press, October 31, 1993.

summary: 10/31/1993: Unknown perpetrators threw a bomb onto the roof of the Bureau of Land Management building in Reno, Nevada, United States. There were no casualties but a three foot hole was blown into the roof and the building sustained an estimated $100,000 in damages.
target1: Bureau of Land Management building, Reno Nevada
weapdetail: Homemade bomb placed in a leather briefcase or satchel thrown onto the roof of the building
propcomment: Hole blown into the roof and six offices damaged
addnotes: The bombing took place at 12:45 AM.
scite1: Tom Gardner, "Bomb Rips Hole in Federal Office in Reno; No Injuries," Associated Press, November 1, 1993.
scite2: "Bomb Explodes At Land Office," Plain Dealer, November 1, 1993.
scite3: Christopher Hewitt, "Political Violence and Terrorism in Modern America: A Chronology," Praeger Security International, 2005.

summary: 11/00/1993: A judge was shot in Algeria by unknown assailants during a week of extreme violence.
scite1: “Judge, 12 militants killed in latest Algerian violence,” Orlando Sentinel, November 22, 1993.
scite2: Rachel Khiari, “Judge killed, leading doctor attacked; 12 militants killed,” The Associated Press, November 21, 1993.

summary: 11/03/1993: A terrorist group called 15th May Arab Organization destroyed two cars in Athens, one of which belonged to a police officer. No one was killed or injured.
target1: Two cars, one of which belonged to a police officer
weapdetail: Homemade bomb
scite1: “New terrorist group claims responsibility for fires,” ER Radio (Athens), November 3, 1993.

summary: 11/04/1993: In a large-scale coordinated attack across Western Europe, members of the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK were responsible for firebombing and sabotaging a number of Turkish-owned businesses and targets. In this attack, perpetrators firebombed the Turkish Embassy in Berne, resulting in no injuries.
motive: Police said they found leaflets protesting "Turkish genocide" on the scene.
addnotes: This was one attack of around 60 that occurred at Turkish establishments across Europe. (cf. 199311040001-22).
scite1: “Germany clamps down on Kurds after bombings,” Press Association, November 5, 1993.
scite2: “1 killed as Kurds attack Turk-owned businesses,” St. Louis Post Dispatch, November 5, 1993.
scite3: Tyler Marshall, “1 killed as Turkish targets are attacked across Europe; terrorism: separatists Kurds are apparently responsible for violence in more than 30 cities. Consulates, businesses are hit,” Los Angeles Times, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/04/1993: A Turkish bank was attacked in Vienna, Austria. There were no fatalities, but it is unknown whether there were any injuries. It was thought that the attacks were carried out by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), but the PKK refused to comment.
motive: Police said they found leaflets protesting "Turkish genocide" on the scene.
weapdetail: Baseball bats
addnotes: This was one attack of around 60 that occurred at Turkish establishments across Europe. (cf. 199311040001-22).

scite2: “1 killed as Kurds attack Turk-owned businesses,” St. Louis Post Dispatch, November 5, 1993.
scite3: Tyler Marshall, “1 killed as Turkish targets are attacked across Europe; terrorism: separatists Kurds are apparently responsible for violence in more than 30 cities. Consulates, businesses are hit,” Los Angeles Times, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/04/1993: A Turkish restaurant was attacked in Wiesbaden, Germany. One person was killed and 8 were injured. It was thought that the attacks were carried out by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), but the PKK refused to comment.
motive: Police said they found leaflets protesting "Turkish genocide" on the scene.
addnotes: This was one attack of around 60 that occurred at Turkish establishments across Europe. (cf. 199311040001-22).
scite1: “Germany clamps down on Kurds after bombings,” Press Association, November 5, 1993.
scite2: “1 killed as Kurds attack Turk-owned businesses,” St. Louis Post Dispatch, November 5, 1993.
scite3: Tyler Marshall, “1 killed as Turkish targets are attacked across Europe; terrorism: separatists Kurds are apparently responsible for violence in more than 30 cities. Consulates, businesses are hit,” Los Angeles Times, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/04/1993: A Turkish newspaper, the Hurriyet, was attacked in Frankfurt, Germany. No one was killed and one person was injured. It was thought that the attacks were carried out by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), but the PKK refused to comment.
motive: Police said they found leaflets protesting "Turkish genocide" on the scene.
weapdetail: Sledgehammers
addnotes: This was one attack of around 60 that occurred at Turkish establishments across Europe. (cf. 199311040001-22).

scite3: Tyler Marshall, “1 killed as Turkish targets are attacked across Europe; terrorism: separatists Kurds are apparently responsible for violence in more than 30 cities. Consulates, businesses are hit,” Los Angeles Times, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/04/1993: A Turkish language cable station was attacked in Berlin, Germany. No one was killed and one person was injured. It is thought that the attacks were carried out by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), but the PKK refused to comment.
target1: Turkish Language cable station in Germany
motive: Police said they found leaflets protesting "Turkish genocide" on the scene.
weapdetail: Bomb and Club
addnotes: This was one attack of around 60 that occurred at Turkish establishments across Europe. (cf. 199311040001-22).

scite2: “1 killed as Kurds attack Turk-owned businesses,” St. Louis Post Dispatch, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/04/1993: A Turkish bank was attacked in London, England. No one was killed, however 5 people were injured. It was thought that the attacks were carried out by the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK), but the PKK refused to comment.
target1: Ziraat Bankasi Turkish Bank in the United Kingdom
motive: Police said they found leaflets protesting "Turkish genocide" on the scene.
propcomment: Although the target was a Turkish Bank, a facility next door (British Telecom) received more damage.
addnotes: This was one attack of around 60 that occurred at Turkish establishments across Europe. (cf. 199311040001-22).

scite2: “1 killed as Kurds attack Turk-owned businesses,” St. Louis Post Dispatch, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/05/1993: The Vice President of the Colombian Senate was shot to death by a group calling itself Death to Protectors of the Cali Cartel. His driver was injured in the attack as well.
gname: Death to Protectors of the Cali Cartel
motive: The Senator was killed for his role in helping write a new law offering leniency to drug traffickers.
addnotes: Although the group Death to Protectors of the Cali Cartel claimed responsibility for the crime and their claimed was confirmed, some thought it was committed by the National Liberation Army.
scite1: Andrew Selsky, “Senate Vice President of Senate Shot, Critically Wounded,” The Associated Press, November 5, 1993.
scite2: “Senator Londono dies of gunshot wounds; prosecutor general to head investigation,” Agence France Presse, November 9, 1993.
scite3: “Colombia,” Miami Herald, November 8, 1993.

summary: 11/05/1993: An Arab Israeli was stabbed by Palestinian attackers.
scite1: “Night watchman killed in suspected terror attack,” Agence France Presse, November 5, 1993.

summary: 11/7/1995: Unknown perpetrators tossed an incendiary onto the roof of the Family Planning Associates clinic in Ventura, California, United States. There were no casualties, but the building sustained $500 in damages.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in California.
weapdetail: Flare bundled with what is believed to be a quick start fire log thrown onto the roof of the building.
propcomment: Roof sustained minor damage
addnotes: Fifteen months after this incident, there was an attack at the same abortion clinic (199502090009).  The Family Planning Associates clinic was the target of many demonstrations.
scite1: Julie Fields, "Ventura: Medical Center Roof Fire Investigated," Los Angeles Times, November 9, 1993.
scite2: Julie Fields, "2nd Arson Fire at Ventura Clinic Probed," Los Angeles Times, February 10, 1995.
scite3: "Across the USA: News From Every State," USA Today, November 9, 1993.

summary: 11/08/1993: Members of the Hezb-i-Islami militia kidnapped 30 individuals near the village of Tagab, including one American and one New Zealander. No other injuries or fatalities were reported. The westerners were released one week later.
addnotes: The journalists were not intentionally targeted for kidnapping and were released one week later.  The source said nothing about the main targets - the 28 Afghans captured with the reporters.  It is unknown whether these citizens were civilian or military.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 11/09/1993: Terrorists stole a garbage truck and crushed an Israeli man to death. There were no claims of responsibility or injuries.
weaptype2_txt: Vehicle (not to include vehicle-borne explosives, i.e., car or truck bombs)
weapdetail: 3 men stole a garbage truck using knives and crashed the garbage truck into another car.
scite1: Jon Immanuel, “Terrorists in stolen garbage truck crush Beduin to death. 3 masked men were looking for Israeli to attack,” The Jerusalem Post, November 10, 1993.
scite2: “Rabin says he won’t abandon Jewish settlers; Mideast: Prime Minister assures Israelis in occupied territories that they’re safe. Meeting follows riots in Gaza and West Bank,” Los Angeles Times, November 10, 1993.
scite3: “Palestinians kill Israeli Arab, Rabin confers with settlers,” The New York Times, November 10, 1993.

summary: 11/09/1993: In one of two related attacks, perpetrators from the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MKO) attacked the French Embassy in Tehran. There were no fatalities or injuries during the incident, however the two perpetrators were killed at a later date.
addnotes: The attack was originally claimed by a group calling itself victims of the MKO crimes, however it was later discovered to have been caused by the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MKO). The MKO also attacked an Air France Office the same day (cf. 1993110900003).
scite1: “Bomb at French facilities in Iran, police arrest several suspects,” Tehran Times, November 10, 1993.
scite2: “Iranian media demand economic action against France, Mideast Mirror, November 10, 1993.
scite3: “French embassy, Air France office attacked in Tehran,” The Associated Press, November 9, 1993.

summary: 11/09/1993: In one of two related attacks, perpetrators from the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MKO) threw a bomb at an Air France office causing slight damage and injuring one person.
addnotes: The attack was originally claimed by a group calling itself victims of the MKO crimes, however it was later discovered to have been caused by the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MKO). The MKO also attacked the French Embassy the same day (cf. 1993110900002).
scite1: “Bomb at French facilities in Iran, police arrest several suspects,” Tehran Times, November 10, 1993.
scite2: “Iranian media demand economic action against France, Mideast Mirror, November 10, 1993.
scite3: “French embassy, Air France office attacked in Tehran,” The Associated Press, November 9, 1993.

summary: 11/10/1993: Unknown militants in Egypt attacked and killed a police officer.
motive: The militants say they are seeking revenge for colleagues tortured in jail and ordered hanged by military courts
scite1: “Suspected militants shoot policeman, steal gun,” The Associated Press, November 10, 1993.
scite2: “Muslim militants kill policeman in Egypt,” Times-Picayune, November 13, 1993.

summary: 11/11/1993: Two German border police were killed on a train while trying to arrest two criminals. No one was injured.
target1: Two German Border Policeman in Linz
scite1: “2 are captured in killings of 2 German border police,” Orlando Sentinel, November 12, 1993.
scite2: Anna Tomforde In Bonn, “2 German border guards killed in train by gangsters,” The Guardian (London), November 12, 1993.
scite3: “Canadian plane crash investigated,” St. Petersburg Times, November 12, 1993.

summary: 11/11/1993: The Tamil Tigers invaded and took over the Pooneryn Military base in Sri Lanka. All in all there were at least 970 deaths and 400 wounded. 900 soldiers were held hostage until the incident was resolved on 11/15/1993.
target1: Pooneryn Military Base in Sri Lanka
propcomment: The perpetrators destroyed the base and stole equipment.
scite1: “Sri Lanka camp toll set to reach 1,000,” Agence France Presse, November 15, 1993.
scite2: Keith Noyahr, “Sri Lankan troops rescue 900 trapped comrades, retake key base,” The Associated Press, November 14, 1993
scite3: “Sri Lanka reports ending rebel siege at base,” The New York Times, November 14, 1993.

location: Molotov cocktails thrown into porch at rear of building
summary: 11/11/1993: Unknown perpetrators threw three Molotov cocktails into the Hillcrest Women's Medical Center in York, Pennsylvania, United States. The firebombs failed to ignite but did shatter windows and damage supplies resulting in $500 in damages.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in Pennsylvania.
weapdetail: Three Molotov cocktails consisting of bottles filled with gasoline with birthday candles used as a wick
propcomment: Windows shattered.  Also, curtains and office were supplies damaged by gasoline.
scite1: "Gasoline Bottles Thrown into Abortion Clinic," Reading Eagle, November 12, 1993.
scite2: "Firebombs Hit Pennsylvania Abortion Clinic," Austin American-Statesman, November 12, 1993.
scite3: "Chronological History of Arsons and Bombings Against Abortion Providers," National Abortion Federation.

summary: 11/13/1993: A bomb was defused at the Christian Democratic Party Office in Chile. No one was killed or injured since the bomb never went off. It is suspected that the bomb was placed by the Free Fatherland People's Guerrilla Army.
target1: Christian Democratic Party Office in Chile
weapdetail: 350 grams of ANFO (Ammonium Nitrate Fuel Oil)
scite1: “Police defuse bomb at Christian Democratic Party Office,” Radio Cooperativa, November 13, 1993

summary: 11/13/1993: Carjackers killed a US civilian, injured 2 foreigners and kidnapped another. One attacker was eventually killed and the kidnap victim was released.
addnotes: The kidnap victim was in one of the stolen cars. The victim was released 700 meters from where they started.
scite1: “Carjackers kill US civilian in Somali capital,” Los Angeles Times, November 14, 1993.
scite2: “Somalis kill US civilian worker for UN,” Commercial Appeal, November 14, 1993.
scite3: “Bandit Attack on convoy leaves 15 Somalis dead,” Houston Chronicle News Service, November 15, 1993.

summary: 11/14/1993: A US Convoy was attacked in Somalia, but the Convoy fired back, preventing the carjacking from occurring. There were no injuries or fatalities.
scite1: “US convoy attacked,” United Press International, November 15, 1993.
scite2: “Armed Somalis attack private convoy under US protection,” Agence France Presse, November 15, 1993.

summary: 11/14/1993: Militants attacked a convoy of 14 trucks in Somalia. 15 people were killed and 13 were injured. The militants escaped with 10 of the 14 trucks.
scite1: “Bandit attack on convoy leaves 15 Somalis dead,” Houston Chronicle News Service, November 15, 1993.
scite2: “15 die in bold strikes by bandits; Somalia slips back into anarchy,” Hamilton Spectator, November 15, 1993.
scite3: Aidan Hartley, “15 civilians die in Somali ambush; 10 trucks grabbed from convoy,” Chicago Sun Times, November 15, 1993.

summary: 11/14/1993: Charles M. Walton, a US citizen, was kidnapped on Pangutaran Island by unidentified Muslim guerrillas. He was released unharmed on December 7, 1993.
motive: The group wanted the withdrawal of Christian missionaries from the southern islands.
addnotes: Additional motives for the kidnapping included the desire for a ban on foreign fishing in the area, a ban on the translation of the Bible, and the restoration of Muslim barter trade to the area.  The source info listed the victim's last name as both Walton or Watson.  Abu Sayyaf (ASG) was suspected of the kidnapping.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 11/15/1993: A bomb exploded destroying a retired police general's car. No one was hurt or injured. The 15th of May Arab Organization claimed responsibility.
motive: An unidentified caller told a private radio station the group would continue attacking police property until the police ''stops supporting extreme right-wing groups."
scite1: “UPI spotlight: bomb destroys car of retired police general,” UPI Spotlight, November 15, 1993.
scite2: “Bomb destroys car of retired police general,” United Press International, November 15, 1993.

summary: 11/15/1993: An Israeli was attacked in Hebron by two militants from the Popular Front for Liberation of Palestine. 1 attacker was killed and the Israeli escaped with just an injury. HAMAS also claimed responsibility for the attack.
gname: Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine (PFLP)
addnotes: Arraham Zarbir shot one of his attackers with a pistol and managed to escape.
scite1: Jon Immanuel, “Ax-Wielding terrorists wound Hebron settler,” The Jerusalem Post, November 16, 1993.
scite2: “PFLP claims responsibility for attack on Jewish settler in Hebron,” BBC, November 17, 1993.
scite3: “Palestinian shot dead by settler,” Advertiser, November 16, 1993.

summary: 11/15/1993: The senior aide to Yasser Arafat was shot in Lebanon. He was the only fatality and there were no injuries. Although there was no claim of responsibility, it was thought that the attack was conducted by Abu-Nidal Fatah-Revolutionary Council.
addnotes: This was the fifth PLO official killed since the Israeli-Palestinian peace accord was signed
scite1: “Arafat aide shot dead, 5th PLO official, killed since peace agreement,” Commercial Appeal, November 16, 1993.
scite2: “Gunmen assassinate Arafat loyalist in Lebanon,” The Gazette (Montreal, Quebec), November 16, 1993.
scite3: David Rudge, “Gunmen kill Fatah’s top man in Lebanon,” The Jerusalem Post, November 16, 1993.

summary: 11/18/1993: The president of the National Federation of Private Physicians was stabbed by unknown militants. The doctor was left in critical condition. No one else was injured.

scite2: Rachel Khiari, “Judge killed, leading doctor attacked; 12 militants killed,” The Associated Press, November 21, 1993.

summary: 11/22/1993: A Palestinian suicide bomber rammed a stolen garbage truck into an army vehicle in Gaza city. The suicide vest he was wearing failed to go off, and he was eventually shot and killed. No one else was killed or injured. HAMAS was the suspected perpetrator of this incident.
weaptype2_txt: Vehicle (not to include vehicle-borne explosives, i.e., car or truck bombs)

scite1: “Suicide bomber badly hurt,” Agence France Presse, November 22, 1993.
scite2: “Army shoots dead Moslem suicide bomber,” Agence France Presse, November 22, 1993.
scite3: “Terrorist killed after trying to ram IDF convoy in stolen garbage,” The Jerusalem Post, November 23, 1993.

summary: 11/23/1993: Unknown gunmen attacked an United Nations convoy of relief workers in Mogadishu. No fatalities and 3 injured.
addnotes: The identities or affiliations of the gunmen were not known. The American, Debbie Owen, was slightly wounded.  Two other Somali guards were also wounded.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 11/24/1993: Nine policemen were killed in an ambush by unknown militants in Algeria. Two other were injured in the attack.
scite1: “Nine policemen killed in ambush: report,” Agence France Presse, November 25, 1993.
scite2: “Nine policemen killed in ambush, arrests made in Setif, arms and leaflets seized,” BBC, November 27, 1993

summary: 11/25/1993: There was a failed assassination attempt on the Egyptian Prime Minister. The attack injured 20 and killed 1. The attack was claimed by both Vanguards of Victory and Islamic Jihad.
propcomment: Damage to a nearby school
scite1: “Police arrest 190 in attempt on Egypt PM,” Commercial Appeal, November 27, 1993.
scite2: “Girl buried as Egypt urges support to fight extremists,” Houston Chronicle, November 27, 1993.
scite3: “Remote-control bomb used in attack on Sedki: police,” Agence France Presse, November 26, 1993.

summary: 11/25/1993: The U.S. Director of Information Services in Yemen, Haynes Mahoney, was kidnapped in Sana'a by Yemini tribesmen. He was released unharmed on November 29, 1993.
motive: The group was demanding revenue from American oil pumps on their property
addnotes: The kidnapping was a result of infighting between rivaling factions in Yemen and not political in nature.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 11/25/1993: A bomb threat was issued regarding the U.S. Embassy in Asunción. No device was found and no specific group was suspected.
addnotes: This was a threat of terrorism against the U.S. Department of State.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: at Saks Fifth Avenue department store in Chicago
summary: 11/27/1993: Two incendiary devices made of matchbooks and timers attached to 9-volt batteries were tightly wrapped in paper bags and secured with paper clips, and planted in the Saks Fifth Avenue department store in downtown Chicago, Illinois, in the United States. One device was found by a store clerk, on a seventh floor shelf, and erupted as a security guard tried to open the bag. Later in the evening, a the second incendiary started a fire on the sixth floor in the Christmas tree department. There were no casualties in the incident, and the fire caused minor damage. This incident is linked to three others in which altogether nine incendiary devices were placed in four department stores in Chicago on the same day and the following day. On November 29, the Animal Liberation Front (ALF) sent out a communiqué to the Chicago Sun Times as well as faxed the statement to PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) claiming responsibility for the incident and stating the "action signals the start of a new, more intense campaign of economic sabotage against stores that sell fur."
target1: Saks Fifth Avenue department store in Chicago, Illinois
motive: Specifically to activate the store's sprinkler system, causing water damage to the store and its inventory as a campaign against stores that sell clothing made from animal fur.
weapdetail: incendiaries made from matchbooks and timers attached to  9-volt batteries and secured tightly inside brown paper bags
propcomment: minor damage
addnotes: The incident occurred at 7:00pm. This incident is linked to three others in which altogether nine incendiary devices were placed in four department stores in Chicago on the same day and the following day (1128932, 1128933, 1128934).
scite1: FBI, "Terrorism in the United States: 1993," Terrorist Research and Analytical Center, National Security Division, FBI, 1993.
scite2: "Anti-fur Activists Take Responsibility for Planting Fire-starters at Stores," Associated Press, November 30, 1993.
scite3: "Animal rights group claims responsibility for fires," United Press International, November 29, 1993.

summary: 11/28/1993: 25 Kurdish citizens forced their way into the Nuremberg Kurdistan Arts and Cultural Center and occupied the building. No one was killed or injured.
target1: Kurdistan Arts and Cultural Center Facilities in Nuremberg
motive: In protest of the banning of the Kurdistan Workers' Party by the German government
propcomment: Windows in the Center were smashed
addnotes: This occupation coincided with demonstrations in Frankfurt and Ingolstadt by hundreds of Kurdish citizens.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

location: at Marshall Field's department store in Chicago
summary: 11/28/1993:  Three incendiary devices made of matchbooks and timers attached to 9-volt batteries were tightly wrapped in paper bags and secured with paper clips, and planted in the Marshall Field's department store in downtown Chicago, Illinois, in the United States. One device started a fire on the eighth floor of the store, which was subsequently extinguished by the sprinkler system, and a second device was later discovered by police about 35 feet from the fire; the second incendiary was rendered safe. The third device was not initially found. There were no casualties in the incident, and the fire caused minor damage. On November 29, the Animal Liberation Front (ALF) sent out a communiqué to the Chicago Sun Times as well as faxed the statement to PETA (People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals) claiming responsibility for the incident and stating the "action signals the start of a new, more intense campaign of economic sabotage against stores that sell fur."  On December 2, the third device was finally found, on the eighth floor of the store as officials were conducting interviews; it was rendered safe and did not ignite. This incident is linked to three others in which altogether nine incendiary devices were placed in four department stores in Chicago on the same day and the previous day.
target1: Marshall Field's department store in Chicago, Illinois
motive: Specifically to activate the store's sprinkler system, causing water damage to the store and its inventory as a campaign against stores that sell clothing made from animal fur.
weapdetail: incendiaries made from matchbooks and timers attached to  9-volt batteries and secured tightly inside brown paper bags
propcomment: minor damage
addnotes: The incident occurred at 2:00am. This incident is linked to three others in which altogether nine incendiary devices were placed in four department stores in Chicago on the same day and the previous day (112893, 1128932, 1128934).
scite1: FBI, "Terrorism in the United States: 1993," Terrorist Research and Analytical Center, National Security Division, FBI, 1993.
scite2: "Anti-fur Activists Take Responsibility for Planting Fire-starters at Stores," Associated Press, November 30, 1993.

This incident is linked to three others in which altogether nine incendiary devices were placed in four department stores in Chicago on the same day and the previous day.

summary: 11/29/1993: An Iranian attempting to gain political asylum hijacked an Iranian plane and flew to Iraq. No one was killed or injured. 38 people were on the plane. Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MKO) also claimed responsibility for the incident, but the Iranian denied MKO-affiliation.
motive: The perpetrator wanted to flee repression and gain political asylum.
addnotes: The man who hijacked the plane claimed he had no affiliation with the Mujahedeen-e-Khalq (MKO). He said he had only personal reasons (political asylum) for hijacking the plane. However, the MKO also claimed responsibility for the hijacking.
scite1: “MKO takes blame for hijacking plane to Basra,” Moneyclips, November 30, 1993.
scite2: “Iranian hijacker was fireman fleeing repression,” Agence France Presse, November 30, 1993.
scite3: “Passengers, crew of hijacked plane arrived in Baghdad,” Agence France Presse, November 30, 1993.

summary: 11/29/1993: Unknown gunmen shot and wounded the senior fuel coordinator for the Australian organization CARE in Atrush. No fatalities and one injury were reported.
addnotes: The source information does not provide much detail about the incident.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 11/30/1993: A Catholic worker was killed by gunmen representing Ulster Freedom Fighters. No one else was killed or injured.
motive: To disrupt peace in Northern Ireland
scite1: Deric Anderson, “Loyalist killers admit murdering catholic,” Press Association, November 30, 1993.
scite2: “Amid governments IRA contacts, loyalists kill again,” The Associated Press, November 30, 1993.

summary: 12/00/1993: A house occupied by Turkish workers in Darmstadt, Germany, was fire-bombed by unknown perpetrators. There was no information available about whether any casualties resulted from this incident.
weapdetail: Firebomb
propcomment: A house in Darmstadt was firebombed.
addnotes: There were a number of attack on foreigners living in Germany and/or foreign-owned establishments, most employing arson as the attack type in May and June of 1993 (cf. 199305300001-2; 199306010004; 199306030001; 199306040001; 199306070002-5; 199306070008; 199305290004-5; 199306060004; 199306110003; 199306120004; 199306170005).
