summary: 12/0/1993: Janet Smith threw two Molotov cocktails at a Family Planning/Gynecologist Clinic in Brooklyn, New York, United States. There were no casualties but the abortion clinic sustained $150 in damages.
motive: To protest the practice of abortion and to sabotage abortion facilities operating in New York.
weapdetail: Two Molotov cocktails
scite1: Laurie Goodstein and Pierre Thomas, "Clinic Killings Follow Years of Antiabortion Violence," Washington Post, January 17, 1995.
scite2: "Chronological History of Arsons and Bombings Against Abortion Providers," National Abortion Federation.
scite3: Scott Holleran, "Abortion and the Death of Dr. George Tiller," Capitalism Magazine, June 1, 2009.

summary: 12/01/1993: A bomb exploded on a bus in KwaZulu-Natal province, Durban, South Africa, killing 1 and injuring 6. The bus was traveling from the city center to a white suburb that is considered politically conservative. Another explosion took place nine hours later at a hotel in Port Edward, 100 miles south of Durban, injuring two people.
propcomment: Bus was destroyed from the explosion
addnotes: There were no immediate assertions of responsibility for either explosion. Political violence in Natal is largely tied to the rivalry between the African National Congress and the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party.  This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199312010001 - 02).
scite1: “2 Explosions in South Africa Kill Man and Hurt 8 Others,” The New York Times, December 1, 1993.

summary: 12/01/1993: A bomb exploded at a hotel in Port Edwards, 100 miles south of Durban, South Africa, injuring two civilians. Another explosion took place nine hours earlier on a public bus in Durban, killing one and injuring six people.
propcomment: Hotel experienced some damage
addnotes: There were no immediate assertions of responsibility for either explosion. Political violence in Natal is largely tied to the rivalry between the African National Congress and the Zulu-dominated Inkatha Freedom Party.  This was one of two related attacks (cf. 199312010001 - 02).
scite1: “2 Explosions in South Africa Kill Man and Hurt 8 Others,” The New York Times, December 1, 1993.

summary: 12/01/1993: Iparretarrak members were responsible for bombing a post office in Saint-Jean-Pied-de-Port, causing minor damage.
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

location: This incident occurred in the El Henancha region between Khemis Miliana and Berrouaghia.
summary: 12/02/1993: The Armed Islamic Group (GIA) was suspected of robbing and killing a Spanish citizen in the El Henancha region in Algeria after a threat against foreigners was issued by the group.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/03/1993: A letter bomb exploded injuring a Roman Catholic priest, August Janisch, age 51. He suffered hand and face injuries. Janisch heads the papal relief mission in Syria. He had recently spoken out in a television interview on behalf of ethnic Albanian refugees from the Serbian province of Kosovo. Vienna's Mayor, Mayor Helmut Zilk, was also targeted and injured from an attack of similar nature. Police arrested two right-wing extremists, Peter B. and Alexander W., for mailing the letter bombs.
motive: Possibly in protest of the programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia
addnotes: At least 10 letter bombs were sent, four exploded and six were defused over a four-day period ending on December 6, 1993. All of the recipients were involved in programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia or other parts of Eastern Europe. Both accused perpetrators have ties to neo-Nazi groups in Germany. This was one of 4 related attacks (199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002).
scite1: “Vienna Mayor Wounded by Letter Bomb,” Sun-Sentinel, December 6, 1993.
scite2: Ken Olsen, “Alert Clerk, Border Guards and Luck Led to Letter Bomb Arrests,” The Associated Press, December 10, 1993.

summary: 12/03/1993: A letter-bomb exploded injuring the journalist, Silvana Meixner, age 35, who suffered severe head injuries and facial wounds The letter, addressed to Meixner, was mailed to the television headquarters in Vienna. Meiner is a native of the former Yugoslav republic of Croatia and anchors a weekly program for ethnic minorities in Austria, titled ''Homeland, Foreign Homeland.'' Vienna's Mayor, Mayor Helmut Zilk, was also targeted and injured from an attack of similar nature. Police arrested two right-wing extremists, Peter B. and Alexander W., for mailing the letter bombs.
motive: Possibly in protest of the programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia
addnotes: At least 10 letter bombs were sent, four exploded and six were defused over a four-day period ending on December 6, 1993. All of the recipients were involved in programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia or other parts of Eastern Europe. Both accused perpetrators have ties to neo-Nazi groups in Germany. This was one of 4 related attacks (199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002).
scite1: “Fourth Letter Bomb in Three Days Uncovered,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 5, 1993.
scite2: Ken Olsen, “Alert Clerk, Border Guards and Luck Led to Letter Bomb Arrests,” The Associated Press, December 10, 1993.

summary: 12/04/1993: A letter bomb, which was mailed to Helmut Schueller, president of the humanitarian relief agency Caritas, was uncovered and defused. Caritas was heavily involved in aiding victims of the wars in Bosnia and Croatia. In addition to this incident, Vienna's Mayor, Mayor Helmut Zilk, was also targeted and injured from an attack of similar nature. Police arrested two right-wing extremists, Peter B. and Alexander W., for mailing the letter bombs.
motive: Possibly in protest of the programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia
addnotes: At least 10 letter bombs were sent, four exploded and six were defused over a four-day period ending on December 6, 1993. All of the recipients were involved in programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia or other parts of Eastern Europe. Both accused perpetrators have ties to neo-Nazi groups in Germany. This was one of 4 related attacks (199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002).
scite1: “Fourth Letter Bomb in Three Days Uncovered,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 5, 1993.
scite2: Ken Olsen, “Alert Clerk, Border Guards and Luck Led to Letter Bomb Arrests,” The Associated Press, December 10, 1993.

summary: 12/04/1993: Hunt Oil Company employee, M. Kohnert, was kidnapped by Bakil tribe members in Sana'a, Yemen. He was released unharmed two days later.
target1: M. Kohnert, a German employee of the US-owned Hunt Oil Company
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/04/1993: Members of the Armed Islamic Group claimed credit for injuring Agnello Castaldo, an Italian businessman, by shooting him in the face outside his residence in Algiers, Algeria.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.
scite2: "Italian wounded in gun attack,” Agence France Presse, December 4, 1993.

summary: 12/05/1993: Khaled Awad Shahada, a Palestinian from the Jabalya refugee camp in the Gaza Strip, got out of a car at a highway bus stop in Holon, just outside Tel Aviv, boarded a crowded intercity bus armed with an AK-47 assault weapon and fired at the passengers, killing one and injuring another. Bus driver Moshe Benita, age 28, jumped from his seat and knocked Shahada off the bus. An Israeli soldier then shot and killed Shahada. Police launched a massive manhunt for the attacker's accomplice who apparently fled the scene in a waiting car that was reported stolen earlier in the day.
propcomment: Windows on the bus were shattered
addnotes: The Islamic Jihad, which is opposed to the Middle East peace process, took responsibility for the attack in leaflets distributed in the Gaza Strip. They identified the Shahada as a martyr for their cause. This attack came eight days before Israel was to begin transferring power to the Palestine Liberation Organization in the Gaza Strip and the West Bank town of Jericho.
scite1: “Gunman, Passenger, Die in Israeli Bus Hijack Attempt,” United Press International, December 5, 1993.
scite2: Ethan Bronner, “Bus Hijacking Attempt Kills 2 in Israel,” The Boston Globe, December 6, 1993.

summary: 12/05/1993: Mayor Helmut Zilk of Vienna was seriously wounded when a letter bomb exploded when Zilk, age 66, opened his mail after returning home from a trip to Switzerland. He was taken to a hospital in Vienna where he had two fingers on his left hand amputated. Police arrested two right-wing extremists, Peter B. and Alexander W., for mailing the letter bombs.
motive: Possibly in protest of the programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia
addnotes: At least 10 letter bombs were sent, four exploded and six were defused over a four-day period ending on December 6, 1993. All of the recipients were involved in programs to aid refugees from war-torn Yugoslavia or other parts of Eastern Europe. Zilk was regarded as a champion of minority rights and was instrumental in the recent opening of Vienna's first postwar Jewish museum. Both accused perpetrators have ties to neo-Nazi groups in Germany. This was one of 4 related attacks (199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002).
scite1: “Mail Bomb in Austria Hits Mayor; Anti-Refugee Groups Suspected in Attack,” St. Louis Post-Dispatch, December 6, 1993.
scite2: Maud S. Beelman, “Vienna Mayor Injured in Fifth Letter Bomb Attack in Three Days,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 5, 1993.
scite3: Ken Olsen, “Alert Clerk, Border Guards and Luck Led to Letter Bomb Arrests,” The Associated Press, December 10, 1993.

summary: 12/05/1993: Members of the Ulster Freedom Fighters carried out a drive-by attack in front of a taxi office in north Belfast, killing a man and a 16-year-old. The attackers drove by and opened fire on the two victims, who were in a car outside the office.
addnotes: The attack occurred in a predominantly Roman Catholic area on the outskirts of north Belfast.
scite1: “2 Killed in North Belfast Drive-by,” Chicago Tribune, December 6, 1993.

summary: 12/05/1993: Police intercepted a letter bomb addressed to Floor Leader, Madeleine Petrovic, a member of the Green Party in Austria. The perpetrators of this incident were unknown.
weapdetail: The device was a parcel bomb.
addnotes: There were a series of letter bombs that were sent over a four-day period, ending on December 6, 1993. (cf. 199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002; 199312050004; 199312060007-9).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/05/1993: The Armed Islamic Group claimed responsibility for killing a Russian woman named Larissa Ayadi in Algiers, Algeria, with a silenced pistol.
weapdetail: The weapon was a silenced gun.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/06/1993: Members of HAMAS opened fire on an Israeli vehicle in the occupied West Bank on Monday, killing a Jewish settler and his 19-year-old son and wounding three of his other children.
addnotes: HAMAS took responsibility and issued leaflets threatening more attacks.
scite1: "Two Killed, Three Wounded in Palestinian Ambush of Israeli Car,” The Associated Press World Stream, December 6, 1993.
scite2: Ethan Bronner, “2 Jews slain in West Bank; Attack by Palestinians spurs more antigovernment rioting by Israeli settlers,” The Boston Globe, December 7, 1993.
scite3: “HAMAS Killings” The Jerusalem Report, December 30, 1993

summary: 12/06/1993: A bomb exploded on a bus in the Kishtwar town of Jammu-Kashmir, injuring eight people. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, however officials suspect religious extremists who condemned the demolition of the mosque in the holy town of Ayodhya on Dec. 6, 1992 by Hindu radicals.
propcomment: Bus was damaged from the blast
scite1: Dilip Ganguly, “Bombs Explode Around India on Mosque Demolition Anniversary,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 6, 1993.
scite2: “India bombs mark anniversary of riots,” The Toronto Star December 6, 1993.

location: Along train tracks between Hyderabad and New Delhi
summary: 12/06/1993: A bomb exploded on the Andhra Pradesh Express Train, traveling from the southern city of Hyderabad for New Delhi. One person was killed and nine were injured. Ten more people were injured in four other explosions in a dining car, a sleeper coach, and under seats while the trains were traveling to Bombay, Calcutta and New Delhi. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, however officials suspect religious extremists who condemned the demolition of the mosque in the holy town of Ayodhya on Dec. 6, 1992 by Hindu radicals.
propcomment: Train was damaged from the blast and service was disrupted
addnotes: This was one of 3 related attacks ( cf. 199312060003 - 05).
scite1: Dilip Ganguly, “Bombs Explode Around India on Mosque Demolition Anniversary,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 6, 1993.
scite2: “India bombs mark anniversary of riots,” The Toronto Star December 6, 1993.

location: Along train tracks between Surat city and Bombay
summary: 12/06/1993: A bomb exploded on the Flying Ranee Express, a commuter train traveling from Surat city in the western state of Gujarat to Bombay. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, however officials suspect religious extremists who condemned the demolition of the mosque in the holy town of Ayodhya on December 6, 1992 by Hindu radicals. In addition to this attack, four trains and a bus were also bombed.
propcomment: Train was damaged from the blast and service was disrupted
addnotes: Due to news reports, the exact number of injuries for this attack was not reported. Reports did indicate that 10 people, in total, were injured on trains traveling to Bombay, Calcutta and New Delhi. This was one of 3 related attacks ( cf. 199312060003 - 05).
scite1: Dilip Ganguly, “Bombs Explode Around India on Mosque Demolition Anniversary,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 6, 1993.
scite2: “India bombs mark anniversary of riots,” The Toronto Star December 6, 1993.

provstate: National Capital Territory of Delhi (Union Territory)
location: Along train tracks in the area
summary: 12/06/1993: Three explosions occurred on Rajdhani Express trains traveling to New Delhi, India. No one claimed responsibility for the attack, however officials suspect religious extremists who condemned the demolition of the mosque in the holy town of Ayodhya on Dec. 6, 1992 by Hindu radicals. In addition to this attack, two trains and a bus were also bombed.
propcomment: Train was damaged from the blast and service was disrupted
addnotes: Due to news reports, the exact number of injuries for this attack was not reported. Reports did indicate that 10 people, in total, were injured on trains traveling to Bombay, Calcutta and New Delhi. This was one of 3 related attacks ( cf. 199312060003 - 05).
scite1: Dilip Ganguly, “Bombs Explode Around India on Mosque Demolition Anniversary,” The Associated Press Worldstream, December 6, 1993.
scite2: “India bombs mark anniversary of riots,” The Toronto Star December 6, 1993.

scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

addnotes: There were a series of letter bombs that were sent over a four-day period, ending on December 6, 1993. (cf. 199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002; 199312050004; 199312060007-9).

summary: 12/06/1993: A letter bomb exploded in the Vienna, Austria, office of Dr. Danek in Schulerstrasse, seriously injuring a clerk. The perpetrators in this incident were unknown.
weapdetail: The device was a parcel bomb.
addnotes: There were a series of letter bombs that were sent over a four-day period, ending on December 6, 1993. (cf. 199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002; 199312050004; 199312060007-9).
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/06/1993: A letter bomb addressed to Women's Minister Dohnal was intercepted by police in Vienna, Austria. Several neo-Nazis were arrested as suspects in the crime.
weapdetail: The device was a parcel bomb.
addnotes: There were a series of letter bombs that were sent over a four-day period, ending on December 6, 1993. (cf. 199312030001-02, 199312040001, 199312050002; 199312050004; 199312060007-9).

summary: 12/09/1993: Suspected Muslim extremists threw dynamite and fired automatic weapons at side-by-side movie houses in Helwan, Egypt, killing a policeman and injuring at least six other people. Two of the men threw sticks of dynamite, one at each theater before escaping by car.
propcomment: Movie theater was damaged
scite1: “Gunmen Kill One, Wound Six in Attack on Movie Theaters,” The Associated Press, December 13, 1993.

summary: 12/10/1993: Members of Kach killed three Palestinian men who were sitting in a parked car, claiming they carried out the murder to avenge the shooting deaths earlier that week of two Jews. Reports stated that the Palestinian men were returning home from work in Israel in a station wagon when the perpetrators, in a car with Israeli license plates, opened fire on the vehicle.
motive: To avenge the shooting deaths of two Jews earlier that week
propcomment: The car experienced some damage
addnotes: Israel Radio said a caller announced that the attack was to avenge Monday's killing of the father and son. Television reports said the militant, ultranationalist Kach movement took responsibility for the triple murder.
scite1: David Hoffman, “3 Palestinians Killed in West Bank; Rising Violence Linked to Efforts To Block Pullout,” The Washington Post, December 11, 1993.
scite2: “Police Minister: No Signs Of New Jewish Terror Group,” The Associated Press, December 11, 1993.
scite3: Bill Hutman, “Police have lead on killers of three Palestinians, says Shahal. Car involved in attack found near Beit Shemesh,” The Jerusalem Post, December 12, 1993.

summary: 12/10/1993: An Algerian man attempted to hijack an Air France flight heading to Nice. After attempting to force the plane to fly to Tripoli, the man was apprehended on the ground in France. No injuries were reported.
target1: Air France flight from Paris to France
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 12/12/1993: The Mujahedeen-e-Khalq announced that it had mistakenly killed Caglar Yucel and injured Huseiyn Kerimoglu, two employees of the Turkish Embassy in Baghdad, Iraq. The group had meant to target Iranian Embassy employees.
target1: Embassy employee of the Iranian government
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/13/1993: Israeli soldiers killed a Palestinian suicide bomber who drove a stolen ambulance packed with explosives at them near the Nahal Oz crossing point in the Gaza Strip. The attacker, who was a member of the Islamic Jihad, crashed the vehicle into an army jeep and one soldier was injured in the resulting blast.
motive: In opposition of the PLO autonomy pact
scite1: “Troops shoot dead Palestinian suicide bomber,” Agence France Presse, December 13, 1993.
scite2: Neil MacFarquhar, “More Violence as Start of Withdrawal Delayed,” The Associated Press, December 13, 1993.

summary: 12/13/1993: Unidentified gunmen attacked a bus on a highway on the island of Mindanao in Buluan, Philippines, killing nine and injuring at least 15 people. Survivor and witness, Maria Judith Enriquez, age 30, reported that the bus was surrounded by a group of 50-armed men when it stopped. The gunmen ordered the passengers to get out and separate into groups according to religion. When they refused, the men ordered them to lie on the road, took their valuables and then shot them.
scite1: “Gunmen Kill 8, Injure 10 in Attack on Bus in Mindanao,” Japan Economic Newswire, December 13, 1993.

summary: 12/13/1993: One person was killed and six were injured when a bomb destroyed the Handicap International-run relief center in Sulaymaniyah, Iraq. The perpetrators in this incident were unknown.
target1: Relief center run by Handicap International in Sulaymaniyah
propcomment: The attack destroyed the relief center.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/14/1993: Twelve technicians, all Christian, from Croatia and Bosnia and Herzegovina were killed in a surprise attack on their living quarters at a construction site in Blida, Algeria. The victims' throats were slit while about 50 attackers took control of the compound for about two hours.
motive: To rid Algeria of foreign elements
addnotes: In September, two French surveyors working on a pipeline in western Algeria became the first foreigners believed to have been killed by Muslim militants. In October, three French consular employees were kidnapped, then freed with a note threatening all foreigners with death if they did not leave by Dec. 1, 1993. Since Dec. 1st, 16 foreigners had been killed, including a Frenchman, a Russian, a Briton and a Spaniard.
scite1: “12 Foreign Workers Slain at Algerian Building Site,” The New York Times, December 16, 1993.

summary: 12/19/1993: Four people, three of them children, were taken to a hospital suffering from shock after a landmine went off on the Buncrana Road, in Londonderry. The explosion occurred just moments after a security patrol passed the scene. Officials suspected the Irish Republican Army (IRA).
propcomment: It shattered windows in dozens of nearby houses and a boys' grammar school, and blasted a huge crater in the road.
addnotes: It was the first explosion in Ulster since the British and Irish governments announced a joint peace initiative five days ago and came as the IRA considered its response to the plan.
scite1: Ian Graham, “Children Escape as IRA Bomb Rocks City,” Press Association, December 19, 1993.
scite2: “Four Treated in Hospital after Ulster Bomb Blast,” The Independent (London), December 20, 1993.

summary: 12/20/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) detonated an explosive device in the republican Suffolk area of Belfast as a military patrol consisting of two Land-Rovers passed waste ground at a road junction. The soldier suffered cuts and the civilian suffered back injuries.
propcomment: A car and the road was damaged
scite1: “Two Hurt in Belfast Bomb Blast,” The Herald, December 21, 1993.

summary: 12/20/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) was suspected of placing an incendiary device in a pub at Victoria bus station. The device exploded, causing a small fire but no injuries.
propcomment: There was some fire damage.
scite1: “Two Hurt in Belfast Bomb Blast,” The Herald, December 21, 1993.

summary: 12/20/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) was suspected of placing an incendiary device at a Royal Mail sorting office in Farringdon Road. The device exploded, causing a small fire but no injuries.
target1: Royal Mail Sorting Office in London
propcomment: There was some fire damage.
scite1: “Two Hurt in Belfast Bomb Blast,” The Herald, December 21, 1993.

summary: 12/20/1993: A bomb exploded in the headquarters office of the rightist Phalangist Party, Lebanon's largest Christian political party, during a leadership meeting, killing two people and wounding 90 others. No group claimed responsibility.
target1: Headquarters of the Phalangist Party in Beirut
propcomment: The 2-story building was destroyed.
scite1: “Bombing of a Lebanese Christian Party Kills 2,” The New York Times, December 21, 1993.

summary: 12/21/1993: Police received a series of bomb threats during rush hour causing authorities to close more than three dozen train stations in Southeast England and suspending service on two London subway lines. Thousands of commuters were stranded or delayed by the closures. The Irish Republican Army (IRA) was suspected of making the calls. There were no bombs found.
addnotes: Due to the bomb threats, all six London railway stations served by the line - Victoria, Blackfriars, London Bridge, Charing Cross, Cannon Street and Waterloo East - were also closed. On the London Underground, service was halted on the Central and Northern lines, two of the busiest lines into the business and shopping districts.
scite1: “Bomb Alerts Close Dozens of Train, Subway Stations,” The Associated Press, December 21, 1993.
scite2: Tony Maguire, “Bomb Alerts Cause Chaos; IRA Warnings Sabotage Tube and Rail Rush Hour,” The The Evening Standard, December 21, 1993.
scite3: John von Radowitz, “IRA Bomb Alerts Bring Rail Travel Chaos,” The Press Association, December 21, 1993.

summary: 12/22/1993: Members of Amal attacked a South Lebanon Army position south of Barasheet village, Lebanon. The attackers used mortars, Sagger anti-tank missiles, rocket propelled grenades and automatic weapons. Reports did not indicate the degree of damage or whether there were casualties.
target1: South Lebanon Army Post near Barasheet
weapdetail: The attackers used mortars, Sagger anti-tank missiles, rocket propelled grenades and automatic weapons.
scite1: David Rudge, “Amal claims responsibility for latest attack in security zone,” The Jerusalem Post, December 23, 1993.

summary: 12/22/1993: HAMAS gunmen in a passing car shot and killed two Jewish settlers in Beitunia in the West Bank. Leaflets were left at the scene, stating that HAMAS was avenging the murder of their commander, Imad Akel.
motive: The group said it was avenging the murder of its commander, Imad Akel.
scite1: Edward F. Mickolus, Terrorism, 1992-1995: A Chronology of Events and a Selectively Annotated Bibliography, Westport, CT: Greenwood Press, 1997.

summary: 12/23/1993: Four masked and armed men entered the grounds of School No. 25, in the southern city of Rostov-on-Don, in a mini-van and forced 12 students and their teacher into a bus. The attackers took the hostages and commandeered a military helicopter to fly them to Tehran, Iran. Before taking off, the gunmen forced a bus driver on board, but released three students as well as a soldier who had been seized during negotiations. During the incident the perpetrators demanded a $10 million ransom. After authorities paid the kidnappers, they dumped the stolen military helicopter and its two pilots, their last remaining captives, in Dagestan, Russia. On December 27, 1993 officials captured the four assailants and retrieved the $10 million.
target1: Children and a school teacher from Russian School No. 25 in Rostov-on-Don
addnotes: Russian news agencies police recovered the $ 10 million ransom paid to the kidnappers. The police seized $ 6.5 million when they arrested two of the gunmen on December 26, 2006 after a brief shootout. The remainder was recovered when the other two were arrested on December 27, 1993 near Makhachkala, capital of the Russian republic of Dagestan. Russian television said the gunmen had told authorities during negotiations that they were each infected with the AIDS virus and had "nothing to lose." The victims were all released at various periods.
scite1: Christopher Boian, “Gunman Seize Students, Flee in Helicopter,” Agence France Presse, December 23, 1993.
scite2: Richard Balmforth, “Russian Kidnappers Hold Child Hostages,” The Guardian (London), December 24, 1993.
scite3: Vanora Bennett, “A $ 10 Million Chase in Russia; All 4 Kidnappers Reported Captured,” Chicago Sun-Times, December 27, 1993.

summary: 12/23/1993: A group of heavily armed gunmen opened fire at random after entering the Krishna Road squatter camp in Durban, South Africa, killing 8 and injuring 4.
target1: Krishna Road Squatter Camp in Durban
motive: Possibly to attack rival political factions
addnotes: Police said the motive for the attack was believed to be a power struggle between rival black political factions, possibly within the African National Congress (ANC).
scite1: “Gunmen Kill 7 Adults, Baby At S. Africa Squatter Camp,” Chicago Tribune, December 25, 1993.

summary: 12/23/1993: Two Somali guards were injured when attackers threw grenades into Catholic Relief Services buildings in the southern city of Baidoa, Somalia. The attacks came after an anonymous group claiming to represent "Muslims who are ready to die for the sake of Islam," issued a written warning to the United Nations and private Christian voluntary organizations. The group accused UN workers and aid groups of passing out bibles in the Somali language and distributing items prohibited by Islam, including pornography, alcohol, pork and hashish.
target1: Catholic Relief Services (CRS) offices in Baidoa
motive: To prevent the spread of Christianity
scite1: “Western Charities Attacked After Somali Muslim Threat,” Chicago Tribune, December 27, 1993.

summary: 12/25/1993: Al-Fatah claimed responsibility for detonating a bomb aboard the Jrush Shalom, an Israeli ship docked at the port of Eilat. 11 people were injured in the attack.
target1: Jrush Shalom (Israeli ship) docked at port of Eilat
scite1: Center for Terrorism and Intelligence Studies, Critical Infrastructure Terrorist Attack Database, San Jose, CA: Akribis Group, July 7 2006.

summary: 12/26/1993: Two grenades and a homemade bomb were used to attack the San Pedro Catholic Cathedral during Sunday Mass in Davao, Philippines. The attack killed six people and injured 151 others. No group claimed responsibility, however officials suspected Muslim extremists.
scite1: “Philippines: Bomb Blasts Threaten Talks with Muslim Rebels,” IPS-Inter Press Service, December 27, 1993.
scite2: “Death toll from church bombing in southern Philippines rises to six,” Agence France Presse, December 27, 1993.
scite3: “Police detain two suspects in bombing of Catholic Church,” United Press International, December 29, 1993.

summary: 12/26/1993: Muslim militants used rifles to attack and kill four policemen and a civilian bystander in Asyut, Egypt. No group claimed responsibility for this attack.
scite1: Bahaa Elkoussy, “Suspected Muslim militants kill 4 policemen in Egypt,” United Press International, December 26, 1993.

summary: 12/27/1993: Two grenades were fired at a mosque in Davao, Philippines. A rifle-fired grenade exploded 50 meters (yards) short of the empty mosque before dawn, causing no injuries. Another grenade reached the mosque but failed to explode. Authorities suspected that this attack was in retaliation for the bomb attack on San Pedro Catholic Cathedral, which occurred on December 26, 1993.
scite1: “Mosque attacked after cathedral bombing leaves six dead,” Agence France Presse, December 27, 1993.

summary: 12/27/1993: The Irish Republican Army (IRA) planted a bomb near a police station in Fintona, Northern Ireland, 16 minutes after the end of the Irish Republican Army's (IRA) Christmas cease-fire. The device exploded, and a man and a woman suffered minor injuries.
scite1: Stephen Bates, “IRA Ends Three-Day Truce with Police Station Bomb,” The Guardian (London), December 27, 1993.
scite2: “With police saying gas leak caused London explosion,” The Associated Press Worldstream December 27, 1993.

summary: 12/27/1993: Suspected Islamic extremists from Al-Jama a al-Islamiyya (Islamic Group) used explosives and firearms to attack a bus carrying Austrian tourists who were visiting an ancient church site in Cairo, Egypt. Eight tourists were wounded, three of them seriously, and another eight bystanders were injured.
scite1: Youssef M. Ibrahim, “16 Are Injured In Cairo Attack On a Tourist Bus,” The New York Times, December 28, 1993.
scite2: Kim Murphy, “Attack on Tourist Bus Hurts 16 in Cairo; Islamic Extremists Suspected,” Los Angeles Times, December 28, 1993.

summary: 12/27/1993: A member of the Irish Republican Army (IRA) was suspected of firing shots from a passing car at a Territorial Army base at Charles Street, Portadown, County Armagh, Northern Ireland. A woman suffered minor injuries, however the base was not damaged.
target1: Territorial Army Base at Charles Street
scite1: Suzanne Breen, “Army base attacked by gunmen,” The Guardian (London), December 27, 1993

summary: 12/28/1993: Two vehicles carrying a total of 506 pounds of explosives were driven up to the exterior wall of a building in Lima, which houses Peru's anti-terrorist police, and detonated. The drivers and passengers fled from the vehicles shortly before the bombs went off, knocking down a section of the wall and injuring at least 21 people. Police suspect Maoist guerrillas, however no one claimed responsibility.
target1: Peruvian Police Anti-Terrorist Division office in Lima
weapdetail: Two vehicles carrying 506 lb of explosives
propcomment: The building was heavily damaged.
addnotes: This is one of 2 related attacks (cf. 199312280001 - 02).
scite1: “Police Station, Funeral Home are Bombed are Bombed in Peru,” Orlando Sentinel, December 29, 1993.
scite2: “Guerillas Hit Hard at Capital of Peru,” The Record, December 29, 1993.

summary: 12/28/1993: A vehicle containing 50 pounds of explosives detonated outside a funeral home, which was in a building shared by Peru's air force and navy in Lima, Peru. The drivers and passengers fled from the vehicles shortly before the bombs went off, destroying the funeral home, damaging nearby houses and buildings, and killing 2 and injuring 6. The air force and navy offices are believed to be the target of this incident. Police suspected Maoist guerrillas, however no one claimed responsibility.
weapdetail: One vehicle carrying 50 lb of explosives
propcomment: The building and nearby businesses and vehicles were damaged.
addnotes: This is one of 2 related attacks (cf. 199312280001 - 02).
scite1: “Police Station, Funeral Home are Bombed are Bombed in Peru,” Orlando Sentinel, December 29, 1993.
scite2: “Guerillas Hit Hard at Capital of Peru,” The Record, December 29, 1993.

summary: 12/30/1993: Members of the Irish Republican Army (IRA) were suspected of firing a mortar a military personnel's Land Rover near the city center of West Belfast, Northern Ireland. The soldier inside the vehicle was injured from the attack; this was one of three attacks which occurred in this area.
propcomment: The vehicle was damaged
addnotes: This is one of 3 related attacks (cf. 199312300001 - 03).
scite1: Deric Henderson, “Troops Escape Injury in Landmine Explosion,” Press Association, December 30, 1993.

summary: 12/30/1993: Members of the Irish Republican Army (IRA) were suspected of detonating a land mine near the city center of West Belfast, Northern Ireland. Police and troops, however, escaped unhurt when land mine exploded. This was one of three attacks which occurred in this area.
target1: Military/ Police Personnel in West Belfast
propcomment: The road was damaged from the explosion
addnotes: This is one of 3 related attacks (cf. 199312300001 - 03).
scite1: Deric Henderson, “Troops Escape Injury in Landmine Explosion,” Press Association, December 30, 1993.

summary: 12/30/1993: A sniper and member of the Irish Republican Army (IRA) was suspected of killing a soldier near the city center of West Belfast, Northern Ireland. This was one of three attacks which occurred in this area.
target1: Military/ Police Personnel in West Belfast
addnotes: This is one of 3 related attacks (cf. 199312300001 - 03).
scite1: “Police Think IRA To Blame for Wave of Belfast Terror,” Orlando Sentinel, December 31, 1993.

summary: 12/30/1993: Unidentified gunman attacked a tavern in Cape Town, South Africa, killing four people. According to reports, the gunmen were black and the patrons in the tavern were white.
propcomment: The tavern was damaged from this attack.
scite1: “De Klerk condemns "barbaric" attack on tavern,” Agence France Presse, December 31, 1993.
